title: Optimizing Classification of Infrequent Labels by Reducing Variability in Label Distribution
comment: Accepted and presented at 6th International Conference on Emerging research in electronics, computer science and technology ( ICERECT)
summary: This paper presents a novel solution, LEVER, designed to address the challenges posed by underperforming infrequent categories in Extreme Classification (XC) tasks. Infrequent categories, often characterized by sparse samples, suffer from high label inconsistency, which undermines classification performance. LEVER mitigates this problem by adopting a robust Siamese-style architecture, leveraging knowledge transfer to reduce label inconsistency and enhance the performance of One-vs-All classifiers. Comprehensive testing across multiple XC datasets reveals substantial improvements in the handling of infrequent categories, setting a new benchmark for the field. Additionally, the paper introduces two newly created multi-intent datasets, offering essential resources for future XC research.

AI.tldr: LEVER is a Siamese-style knowledge-transfer framework that improves learning for infrequent labels in extreme classification (XC) and introduces two multi-intent datasets.
AI.motivation: Extreme Classification (XC) suffers from infrequent categories with sparse samples and high label inconsistency, which degrades performance and limits benchmarks.
AI.method: LEVER uses a robust Siamese-style architecture to enable knowledge transfer, reducing label inconsistency and enhancing One-vs-All classifiers for infrequent labels.
AI.result: Comprehensive experiments across multiple XC datasets show substantial improvements in handling infrequent categories and establish a new benchmark.
AI.conclusion: LEVER addresses label inconsistency for rare labels in XC and provides two newly created multi-intent datasets to support future XC research.

title: Slimmable NAM: Neural Amp Models with adjustable runtime computational cost
comment: 2 pages, 2 figures. Accepted to NeurIPS 2025 workshop on AI for Music
summary: This work demonstrates "slimmable Neural Amp Models", whose size and computational cost can be changed without additional training and with negligible computational overhead, enabling musicians to easily trade off between the accuracy and compute of the models they are using. The method's performance is quantified against commonly-used baselines, and a real-time demonstration of the model in an audio effect plug-in is developed.

AI.tldr: Slimmable Neural Amp Models let users adjust model size and compute cost on the fly without retraining, enabling real‑time, accuracy–compute tradeoffs in musical audio processing; demonstrated in a real-time audio plugin.
AI.motivation: Musicians and audio processing workflows demand flexible, low-latency models that can adapt to varying hardware and latency constraints. Traditional approaches require maintaining multiple fixed models or retraining for different budgets, which is impractical for real-time use.
AI.method: Introduce slimmable Neural Amp Models whose size and computational cost can be changed dynamically without additional training and with negligible overhead. The approach is evaluated against common baselines and demonstrated in a real-time audio effect plug‑in to show practical viability.
AI.result: The models offer controllable tradeoffs between accuracy and compute with negligible overhead, performing favorably compared to baselines. A real-time plug-in demonstration attests to practical feasibility for musical applications.
AI.conclusion: The work shows the feasibility of on-demand resource-aware neural audio effects for musicians, enabling adaptive fidelity under real-time constraints; future work could explore broader effects, latency budgets, and deployment on diverse hardware.

title: Towards Personalized Quantum Federated Learning for Anomaly Detection
comment: Accepted at IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
summary: Anomaly detection has a significant impact on applications such as video surveillance, medical diagnostics, and industrial monitoring, where anomalies frequently depend on context and anomaly-labeled data are limited. Quantum federated learning (QFL) overcomes these concerns by distributing model training among several quantum clients, consequently eliminating the requirement for centralized quantum storage and processing. However, in real-life quantum networks, clients frequently differ in terms of hardware capabilities, circuit designs, noise levels, and how classical data is encoded or preprocessed into quantum states. These differences create inherent heterogeneity across clients - not just in their data distributions, but also in their quantum processing behaviors. As a result, training a single global model becomes ineffective, especially when clients handle imbalanced or non-identically distributed (non-IID) data. To address this, we propose a new framework called personalized quantum federated learning (PQFL) for anomaly detection. PQFL enhances local model training at quantum clients using parameterized quantum circuits and classical optimizers, while introducing a quantum-centric personalization strategy that adapts each client's model to its own hardware characteristics and data representation. Extensive experiments show that PQFL significantly improves anomaly detection accuracy under diverse and realistic conditions. Compared to state-of-the-art methods, PQFL reduces false errors by up to 23%, and achieves gains of 24.2% in AUROC and 20.5% in AUPR, highlighting its effectiveness and scalability in practical quantum federated settings.

AI.tldr: Personalized quantum federated learning (PQFL) tailors models to heterogeneous quantum clients for anomaly detection, yielding strong gains in AUROC, AUPR, and reduced false errors.
AI.motivation: Anomaly detection benefits from distributed learning but labeled data are scarce and anomaly distributions are context-dependent. In real quantum networks, clients differ in hardware, circuit design, noise, and data encoding, creating heterogeneity that makes a single global model ineffective, especially with non-IID data.
AI.method: Introduce PQFL that uses parameterized quantum circuits and classical optimizers for local training, plus a quantum-centric personalization strategy to adapt each client to its hardware and data representation, enabling effective federated learning under heterogeneity.
AI.result: Experimental results show significant improvements: false errors reduced by up to 23%, AUROC gains of 24.2%, and AUPR gains of 20.5%, demonstrating improved anomaly-detection performance.
AI.conclusion: PQFL is effective and scalable for practical quantum federated anomaly detection in heterogeneous settings, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Multivariate Variational Autoencoder
summary: We present the Multivariate Variational Autoencoder (MVAE), a VAE variant that preserves Gaussian tractability while lifting the diagonal posterior restriction. MVAE factorizes each posterior covariance, where a \emph{global} coupling matrix $\mathbf{C}$ induces dataset-wide latent correlations and \emph{per-sample} diagonal scales modulate local uncertainty. This yields a full-covariance family with analytic KL and an efficient reparameterization via $\mathbf{L}=\mathbf{C}\mathrm{diag}(\boldsymbolσ)$. Across Larochelle-style MNIST variants, Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100, MVAE consistently matches or improves reconstruction (MSE~$\downarrow$) and delivers robust gains in calibration (NLL/Brier/ECE~$\downarrow$) and unsupervised structure (NMI/ARI~$\uparrow$) relative to diagonal-covariance VAEs with matched capacity, especially at mid-range latent sizes. Latent-plane visualizations further indicate smoother, more coherent factor traversals and sharper local detail. We release a fully reproducible implementation with training/evaluation scripts and sweep utilities to facilitate fair comparison and reuse.

AI.tldr: MVAE extends VAE with a full-covariance posterior by factoring covariance into a global coupling matrix C and per-sample diagonal scales, enabling tractable KL and efficient reparameterization L = C diag(sigma). It improves calibration and unsupervised structure while preserving reconstruction across standard datasets; released reproducible code.
AI.motivation: To overcome diagonal posterior limitations in VAEs and capture dataset-wide latent correlations without sacrificing tractability, enabling better calibration and representation learning.
AI.method: Introduce MVAE with posterior covariance factorization: global C and per-sample diag(sigma); analytic KL; reparameterization via L = C diag(sigma); evaluate on Larochelle-style MNIST variants, Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10/100; compare to diagonal-cov VAEs with matched capacity.
AI.result: MVAE achieves equal or better MSE across datasets; provides robust gains in calibration metrics (NLL, Brier, ECE) and in unsupervised structure metrics (NMI, ARI), especially at mid-range latent sizes; latent-plane traversals show smoother, more coherent factor changes; code released.
AI.conclusion: MVAE offers a tractable full-covariance VAE with improved calibration and latent structure representations without sacrificing reconstruction quality; practical and reproducible approach for learning correlated latent representations.

title: CAVER: Curious Audiovisual Exploring Robot
summary: Multimodal audiovisual perception can enable new avenues for robotic manipulation, from better material classification to the imitation of demonstrations for which only audio signals are available (e.g., playing a tune by ear). However, to unlock such multimodal potential, robots need to learn the correlations between an object's visual appearance and the sound it generates when they interact with it. Such an active sensorimotor experience requires new interaction capabilities, representations, and exploration methods to guide the robot in efficiently building increasingly rich audiovisual knowledge. In this work, we present CAVER, a novel robot that builds and utilizes rich audiovisual representations of objects. CAVER includes three novel contributions: 1) a novel 3D printed end-effector, attachable to parallel grippers, that excites objects' audio responses, 2) an audiovisual representation that combines local and global appearance information with sound features, and 3) an exploration algorithm that uses and builds the audiovisual representation in a curiosity-driven manner that prioritizes interacting with high uncertainty objects to obtain good coverage of surprising audio with fewer interactions. We demonstrate that CAVER builds rich representations in different scenarios more efficiently than several exploration baselines, and that the learned audiovisual representation leads to significant improvements in material classification and the imitation of audio-only human demonstrations. https://caver-bot.github.io/

AI.tldr: CAVER is a robot that learns rich audiovisual representations for object interaction, using a novel end-effector to evoke audio, a combined visual-audio representation, and a curiosity-driven exploration strategy to efficiently cover surprising sounds and improve material classification and imitation of audio-only demonstrations.
AI.motivation: To enable robust multimodal perception in robotics by learning correlations between visual appearance and object-generated sounds during interactions, facilitating tasks like material classification and imitation from audio signals alone.
AI.method: 1) A 3D-printed end-effector attaches to parallel grippers to excite objects’ audio responses; 2) an audiovisual representation fuses local/global appearance features with sound features; 3) a curiosity-driven exploration algorithm prioritizes high-uncertainty objects to efficiently cover surprising audio with fewer interactions.
AI.result: CAVER builds rich audiovisual representations more efficiently than several exploration baselines and improves material classification and the imitation of audio-only human demonstrations.
AI.conclusion: Integrating a purpose-built end-effector, joint audiovisual representations, and curiosity-driven exploration enables efficient learning of audiovisual knowledge for manipulation tasks, with tangible gains in material understanding and ability to imitate audio demonstrations.

title: Analysing Environmental Efficiency in AI for X-Ray Diagnosis
summary: The integration of AI tools into medical applications has aimed to improve the efficiency of diagnosis. The emergence of large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT and Claude, has expanded this integration even further. Because of LLM versatility and ease of use through APIs, these larger models are often utilised even though smaller, custom models can be used instead. In this paper, LLMs and small discriminative models are integrated into a Mendix application to detect Covid-19 in chest X-rays. These discriminative models are also used to provide knowledge bases for LLMs to improve accuracy. This provides a benchmark study of 14 different model configurations for comparison of accuracy and environmental impact. The findings indicated that while smaller models reduced the carbon footprint of the application, the output was biased towards a positive diagnosis and the output probabilities were lacking confidence. Meanwhile, restricting LLMs to only give probabilistic output caused poor performance in both accuracy and carbon footprint, demonstrating the risk of using LLMs as a universal AI solution. While using the smaller LLM GPT-4.1-Nano reduced the carbon footprint by 94.2% compared to the larger models, this was still disproportionate to the discriminative models; the most efficient solution was the Covid-Net model. Although it had a larger carbon footprint than other small models, its carbon footprint was 99.9% less than when using GPT-4.5-Preview, whilst achieving an accuracy of 95.5%, the highest of all models examined. This paper contributes to knowledge by comparing generative and discriminative models in Covid-19 detection as well as highlighting the environmental risk of using generative tools for classification tasks.

AI.tldr: A benchmark study comparing generative LLMs and small discriminative models for Covid-19 detection in chest X-rays within a Mendix app, evaluating 14 configurations. Smaller models reduce carbon footprint but bias toward positive diagnoses with low confidence; constraining LLM outputs to probabilistic certainty lowers performance; GPT-4.1-Nano greatly reduces footprint but still higher than discriminative models; Covid-Net offers the best accuracy (95.5%) with substantially lower footprint than large LLMs. Overall, the study cautions against treating generative models as universal classifiers and highlights environmental considerations.
AI.motivation: To quantify trade-offs between generative LLMs and lightweight discriminative models for medical image classification, assessing accuracy and environmental impact within an integrated app workflow.
AI.method: Integrate LLMs and small discriminative models into a Mendix application for Covid-19 detection from chest X-rays. A knowledge-base mechanism uses discriminative models to inform LLMs. Evaluate 14 model configurations on accuracy and environmental footprint, examining output biases and probability-only constraints.
AI.result: Small discriminative models reduce carbon footprint but introduce bias toward positive diagnoses and low confidence. For LLMs, restricting outputs to probabilistic values degrades both accuracy and environmental metrics. GPT-4.1-Nano cuts footprint by 94.2% relative to large models but remains less efficient than discriminative models. The Covid-Net discriminative model achieves 95.5% accuracy with a footprint 99.9% smaller than GPT-4.5-Preview, representing the most efficient configuration among those tested.
AI.conclusion: The work provides a comparative framework for generative vs discriminative approaches in Covid-19 detection and underscores environmental risks of using generative tools for classification. It also suggests that a lightweight discriminative model (e.g., Covid-Net) can offer superior efficiency and accuracy, challenging the notion of LLMs as universal, go-to classifiers.

title: Knowledge-Guided Textual Reasoning for Explainable Video Anomaly Detection via LLMs
summary: We introduce Text-based Explainable Video Anomaly Detection (TbVAD), a language-driven framework for weakly supervised video anomaly detection that performs anomaly detection and explanation entirely within the textual domain. Unlike conventional WSVAD models that rely on explicit visual features, TbVAD represents video semantics through language, enabling interpretable and knowledge-grounded reasoning. The framework operates in three stages: (1) transforming video content into fine-grained captions using a vision-language model, (2) constructing structured knowledge by organizing the captions into four semantic slots (action, object, context, environment), and (3) generating slot-wise explanations that reveal which semantic factors contribute most to the anomaly decision. We evaluate TbVAD on two public benchmarks, UCF-Crime and XD-Violence, demonstrating that textual knowledge reasoning provides interpretable and reliable anomaly detection for real-world surveillance scenarios.

AI.tldr: A language-driven, weakly supervised video anomaly detection framework that uses captions and semantic slots to detect anomalies and explain decisions entirely in text.
AI.motivation: Conventional weakly supervised video anomaly detection relies on visual features, but this can limit interpretability and robustness. A text-based approach aims for interpretable, knowledge-grounded reasoning by leveraging language to represent video semantics.
AI.method: Three-stage pipeline: (1) convert video content into fine-grained captions via a vision-language model; (2) build structured knowledge by organizing captions into four semantic slots—action, object, context, environment; (3) generate slot-wise explanations indicating which semantic factors most influence the anomaly decision.
AI.result: Evaluated on UCF-Crime and XD-Violence, showing that textual knowledge reasoning yields interpretable and reliable anomaly detection for real-world surveillance scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Text-based knowledge reasoning can provide interpretable and reliable weakly supervised video anomaly detection, with potential for broader applicability and further extension to richer semantic slots and cross-modal explanations.

title: Euclidean k-center Fair Clusterings
summary: Many approximation algorithms and heuristic algorithms to find a fair clustering have emerged. In this paper we define a new and natural variant of fair clustering problem and design a polynomial time algorithm to compute an optimal fair clustering. Let P be a set of n points on a plane, and each point has a color in C, corresponding to a group. For each color q in C, a lower bound l(q) and an upper bound u(q) are given. Then we define the fair clustering problem as follows. The fair k-clustering problem is to find a partition of P into a set of k clusters with a minimum cost such that each cluster contains at least l(q) and at most u(q) points in P with color q. By l(q) and u(q) each cluster cannot contain too few or too many points with a specific color. If we regard a color to a gender or a minority ethnic group, the clustering corresponds to a fair clustering.

AI.tldr: Defines a natural fair clustering variant with per-cluster color quotas l(q) and u(q) and gives a polynomial-time algorithm to compute an optimal k-clustering under these constraints.
AI.motivation: To enforce fairness in clustering by guaranteeing representation of each color (group) within every cluster, addressing limitations of prior approximation/heuristic approaches.
AI.method: Formulates the fair k-clustering problem with color-wise lower and upper bounds for each cluster and develops a polynomial-time algorithm to compute an optimal solution.
AI.result: An optimal fair clustering can be computed in polynomial time under the proposed color-quota constraints per cluster.
AI.conclusion: Color-based quotas (e.g., gender or minority groups) in clustering yield a principled fair clustering framework; with this model, per-cluster quotas ensure fair representation across clusters.

title: RELEAP: Reinforcement-Enhanced Label-Efficient Active Phenotyping for Electronic Health Records
comment: 20 pages, 5 figures, 1 table. Includes supplementary material. Submitted to JAMIA Open. † These authors contributed equally. *Corresponding author: Chuan Hong
summary:
Objective: Electronic health record (EHR) phenotyping often relies on noisy proxy labels, which undermine the reliability of downstream risk prediction. Active learning can reduce annotation costs, but most rely on fixed heuristics and do not ensure that phenotype refinement improves prediction performance. Our goal was to develop a framework that directly uses downstream prediction performance as feedback to guide phenotype correction and sample selection under constrained labeling budgets.
  Materials and Methods: We propose Reinforcement-Enhanced Label-Efficient Active Phenotyping (RELEAP), a reinforcement learning-based active learning framework. RELEAP adaptively integrates multiple querying strategies and, unlike prior methods, updates its policy based on feedback from downstream models. We evaluated RELEAP on a de-identified Duke University Health System (DUHS) cohort (2014-2024) for incident lung cancer risk prediction, using logistic regression and penalized Cox survival models. Performance was benchmarked against noisy-label baselines and single-strategy active learning.
  Results: RELEAP consistently outperformed all baselines. Logistic AUC increased from 0.774 to 0.805 and survival C-index from 0.718 to 0.752. Using downstream performance as feedback, RELEAP produced smoother and more stable gains than heuristic methods under the same labeling budget.
  Discussion: By linking phenotype refinement to prediction outcomes, RELEAP learns which samples most improve downstream discrimination and calibration, offering a more principled alternative to fixed active learning rules.
  Conclusion: RELEAP optimizes phenotype correction through downstream feedback, offering a scalable, label-efficient paradigm that reduces manual chart review and enhances the reliability of EHR-based risk prediction.

AI.tldr: RELEAP: a reinforcement-learning–based active phenotyping framework that uses downstream prediction performance as feedback to guide phenotype correction and sample selection under labeling constraints, improving EHR-based risk prediction.
AI.motivation: EHR phenotyping often uses noisy proxy labels, degrading downstream risk prediction. There is a need for label-efficient methods that directly optimize predictive performance.
AI.method: RELEAP integrates multiple querying strategies within a reinforcement learning framework and updates its sampling policy based on feedback from downstream models (logistic regression and penalized Cox). Evaluated on a DUHS cohort (2014–2024) for incident lung cancer risk prediction, compared to noisy-label baselines and single-strategy active learning.
AI.result: RELEAP outperformed baselines with logistic AUC improving from 0.774 to 0.805 and survival C-index from 0.718 to 0.752; showed smoother, more stable gains under the same labeling budget.
AI.conclusion: Linking phenotype refinement to downstream prediction outcomes yields a principled, scalable, label-efficient approach that reduces manual chart review and enhances the reliability of EHR-based risk prediction.

title: Time-Aware Policy Learning for Adaptive and Punctual Robot Control
summary: Temporal awareness underlies intelligent behavior in both animals and humans, guiding how actions are sequenced, paced, and adapted to changing goals and environments. Yet most robot learning algorithms remain blind to time. We introduce time-aware policy learning, a reinforcement learning framework that enables robots to explicitly perceive and reason with time as a first-class variable. The framework augments conventional reinforcement policies with two complementary temporal signals, the remaining time and a time ratio, which allow a single policy to modulate its behavior continuously from rapid and dynamic to cautious and precise execution. By jointly optimizing punctuality and stability, the robot learns to balance efficiency, robustness, resiliency, and punctuality without re-training or reward adjustment. Across diverse manipulation domains from long-horizon pick and place, to granular-media pouring, articulated-object handling, and multi-agent object delivery, the time-aware policy produces adaptive behaviors that outperform standard reinforcement learning baselines by up to 48% in efficiency, 8 times more robust in sim-to-real transfer, and 90% in acoustic quietness while maintaining near-perfect success rates. Explicit temporal reasoning further enables real-time human-in-the-loop control and multi-agent coordination, allowing robots to recover from disturbances, re-synchronize after delays, and align motion tempo with human intent. By treating time not as a constraint but as a controllable dimension of behavior, time-aware policy learning provides a unified foundation for efficient, robust, resilient, and human-aligned robot autonomy.

AI.tldr: A reinforcement learning framework that treats time as a first-class variable by adding remaining time and time ratio as inputs to the policy, enabling adaptable tempo and improved efficiency, robustness, and human alignment across robotic manipulation tasks.
AI.motivation: Robot learning largely ignores time, hindering long-horizon planning, human-robot interaction, and real-time adaptation. Explicit temporal reasoning promises more flexible, punctual, and robust behavior.
AI.method: Introduce time-aware policy learning: augment policies with remaining time and time ratio signals; jointly optimize for punctuality and stability; enable behavior that scales from rapid to cautious execution; claims improved sim-to-real transfer and human-in-the-loop coordination without reward redesign.
AI.result: Reported improvements include up to 48% efficiency gains, 8x more robust sim-to-real transfer, and 90% acoustic quietness with near-perfect success across domains such as long-horizon pick-and-place, granular-media pouring, articulated-object handling, and multi-agent delivery.
AI.conclusion: Treating time as a controllable dimension of policy behavior yields efficient, robust, resilient, and human-aligned robot autonomy and provides a unified foundation for time-aware control across tasks.

title: Agentic Educational Content Generation for African Languages on Edge Devices
summary: Addressing educational inequity in Sub-Saharan Africa, this research presents an autonomous agent-orchestrated framework for decentralized, culturally adaptive educational content generation on edge devices. The system leverages four specialized agents that work together to generate contextually appropriate educational content. Experimental validation on platforms including Raspberry Pi 4B and NVIDIA Jetson Nano demonstrates significant performance achievements. InkubaLM on Jetson Nano achieved a Time-To-First-Token (TTFT) of 129 ms, an average inter-token latency of 33 ms, and a throughput of 45.2 tokens per second while consuming 8.4 W. On Raspberry Pi 4B, InkubaLM also led with 326 ms TTFT and 15.9 tokens per second at 5.8 W power consumption. The framework consistently delivered high multilingual quality, averaging a BLEU score of 0.688, cultural relevance of 4.4/5, and fluency of 4.2/5 across tested African languages. Through potential partnerships with active community organizations including African Youth & Community Organization (AYCO) and Florida Africa Foundation, this research aims to establish a practical foundation for accessible, localized, and sustainable AI-driven education in resource-constrained environments. Keeping focus on long-term viability and cultural appropriateness, it contributes to United Nations SDGs 4, 9, and 10. Index Terms - Multi-Agent Systems, Edge AI Computing, Educational Technology, African Languages, Rural Education, Sustainable Development, UN SDG.

AI.tldr: A multi-agent edge-AI framework (InkubaLM) for culturally adaptive, decentralized educational content generation in Sub-Saharan Africa, achieving low TTFT and competitive throughput with strong multilingual and cultural quality on edge devices (Jetson Nano and Raspberry Pi 4B).
AI.motivation: Address educational inequity in Sub-Saharan Africa by delivering localized, language-appropriate educational content on resource-constrained devices, enabling offline or low-connectivity operation and culturally respectful pedagogy, contributing to UN SDGs 4, 9, and 10.
AI.method: An autonomous, four-agent orchestration framework that generates contextually appropriate educational content on edge devices. Evaluation on Jetson Nano and Raspberry Pi 4B measuring Time-To-First-Token (TTFT), inter-token latency, throughput, power, as well as multilingual quality (BLEU), cultural relevance, and fluency across African languages.
AI.result: On Jetson Nano (InkubaLM): TTFT 129 ms, inter-token latency 33 ms, throughput 45.2 tokens/s, power 8.4 W. On Raspberry Pi 4B: TTFT 326 ms, throughput 15.9 tokens/s, power 5.8 W. Quality metrics: BLEU 0.688, cultural relevance 4.4/5, fluency 4.2/5 across tested African languages.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates a viable, culturally attuned edge-AI approach to localized education in resource-limited settings, with potential partnerships (AYCO, Florida Africa Foundation) and alignment with UN SDGs 4, 9, 10; suggests pathways for sustainability, scalability, and community adoption.

title: Two Datasets Are Better Than One: Method of Double Moments for 3-D Reconstruction in Cryo-EM
summary: Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) is a powerful imaging technique for reconstructing three-dimensional molecular structures from noisy tomographic projection images of randomly oriented particles. We introduce a new data fusion framework, termed the method of double moments (MoDM), which reconstructs molecular structures from two instances of the second-order moment of projection images obtained under distinct orientation distributions--one uniform, the other non-uniform and unknown. We prove that these moments generically uniquely determine the underlying structure, up to a global rotation and reflection, and we develop a convex-relaxation-based algorithm that achieves accurate recovery using only second-order statistics. Our results demonstrate the advantage of collecting and modeling multiple datasets under different experimental conditions, illustrating that leveraging dataset diversity can substantially enhance reconstruction quality in computational imaging tasks.

AI.tldr: MoDM uses two second-order moment datasets from distinct orientation distributions to uniquely recover a 3D structure in cryo-EM, up to rotation/reflection, via a convex-relaxation algorithm; highlights the value of dataset diversity for improved reconstruction.
AI.motivation: In cryo-EM, reconstructing 3D structures from noisy projections is challenging; leveraging multiple datasets with different orientation statistics can provide richer information and enable identifiability with lower-order statistics.
AI.method: Introduce the method of double moments (MoDM) that uses two instances of the second-order moment of projection images under one uniform and one unknown non-uniform orientation distribution; prove generic identifiability up to global rotation/reflection; develop a convex-relaxation-based algorithm to recover the structure from second-order statistics.
AI.result: The moments generically determine the underlying structure up to rotation/reflection; the proposed convex-relaxation algorithm achieves accurate recovery using only second-order statistics; results illustrate that dataset diversity improves reconstruction quality.
AI.conclusion: Collecting and modeling multiple datasets under different experimental conditions can substantially enhance reconstruction quality in computational imaging tasks; MoDM demonstrates that second-order statistics, when paired with diverse datasets, suffice for accurate 3D reconstruction in cryo-EM.

title: Clean up your Mesh! Part 1: Plane and simplex
summary: We revisit the geometric foundations of mesh representation through the lens of Plane-based Geometric Algebra (PGA), questioning its efficiency and expressiveness for discrete geometry. We find how $k$-simplices (vertices, edges, faces, ...) and $k$-complexes (point clouds, line complexes, meshes, ...) can be written compactly as joins of vertices and their sums, respectively. We show how a single formula for their $k$-magnitudes (amount, length, area, ...) follows naturally from PGA's Euclidean and Ideal norms. This idea is then extended to produce unified coordinate-free formulas for classical results such as volume, centre of mass, and moments of inertia for simplices and complexes of arbitrary dimensionality. Finally we demonstrate the practical use of these ideas on some real-world examples.

AI.tldr: PGA provides a compact, coordinate-free framework for discrete geometry: k-simplices and k-complexes are expressed as joins and sums; a single formula for k-magnitudes follows from Euclidean/Ideal norms; unified, coordinate-free formulas for volume, centroid, and moments of inertia across arbitrary dimensions; demonstrated on real-world examples.
AI.motivation: Question the efficiency and expressiveness of Plane-based Geometric Algebra (PGA) for discrete geometry, and to unify classic geometric quantities (volume, centroid, inertia) in a coordinate-free framework that scales to arbitrary dimensionality; demonstrate practical applicability.
AI.method: Represent k-simplices as joins of their vertices and k-complexes as sums of their points within PGA. Derive a universal formula for k-magnitudes (length, area, volume, etc.) using PGA’s Euclidean and Ideal norms. From these, obtain coordinate-free formulas for volume, center of mass, and moments of inertia for simplices and complexes of arbitrary dimensionality. Apply these formulas to real-world examples to illustrate practicality.
AI.result: A unified, coordinate-free approach yielding a single k-magnitude formula from PGA norms and extended formulas for volume, center of mass, and moments of inertia across arbitrary dimensions; demonstrated on real-world datasets or scenarios.
AI.conclusion: PGA provides an elegant and practical framework for discrete geometry that unifies and simplifies computations of fundamental geometric quantities, with demonstrated applicability to real-world problems and potential for broader adoption in discrete geometry pipelines.

title: Comparing Reconstruction Attacks on Pretrained Versus Full Fine-tuned Large Language Model Embeddings on Homo Sapiens Splice Sites Genomic Data
summary: This study investigates embedding reconstruction attacks in large language models (LLMs) applied to genomic sequences, with a specific focus on how fine-tuning affects vulnerability to these attacks. Building upon Pan et al.'s seminal work demonstrating that embeddings from pretrained language models can leak sensitive information, we conduct a comprehensive analysis using the HS3D genomic dataset to determine whether task-specific optimization strengthens or weakens privacy protections. Our research extends Pan et al.'s work in three significant dimensions. First, we apply their reconstruction attack pipeline to pretrained and fine-tuned model embeddings, addressing a critical gap in their methodology that did not specify embedding types. Second, we implement specialized tokenization mechanisms tailored specifically for DNA sequences, enhancing the model's ability to process genomic data, as these models are pretrained on natural language and not DNA. Third, we perform a detailed comparative analysis examining position-specific, nucleotide-type, and privacy changes between pretrained and fine-tuned embeddings. We assess embeddings vulnerabilities across different types and dimensions, providing deeper insights into how task adaptation shifts privacy risks throughout genomic sequences. Our findings show a clear distinction in reconstruction vulnerability between pretrained and fine-tuned embeddings. Notably, fine-tuning strengthens resistance to reconstruction attacks in multiple architectures -- XLNet (+19.8\%), GPT-2 (+9.8\%), and BERT (+7.8\%) -- pointing to task-specific optimization as a potential privacy enhancement mechanism. These results highlight the need for advanced protective mechanisms for language models processing sensitive genomic data, while highlighting fine-tuning as a potential privacy-enhancing technique worth further exploration.

AI.tldr: Fine-tuning LLM embeddings on genomic data reduces vulnerability to embedding reconstruction attacks; resistance improves across XLNet, GPT-2, and BERT by 19.8%, 9.8%, and 7.8% respectively.
AI.motivation: Extend Pan et al.'s work by evaluating how task-specific optimization and DNA-aware tokenization affect privacy of embeddings in genomic-context LLMs; address gaps in embedding-type specification and privacy analysis.
AI.method: Apply a reconstruction attack pipeline to both pretrained and fine-tuned embeddings; implement DNA-specific tokenization; compare position-specific, nucleotide-type, and privacy changes across embedding types and dimensions.
AI.result: Fine-tuning strengthens resistance to reconstruction attacks compared with pretraining alone; notable improvements across XLNet, GPT-2, and BERT; highlights that task adaptation shifts privacy risk across genomic sequences.
AI.conclusion: Task-specific optimization, via fine-tuning, may serve as a privacy-enhancing mechanism for LLMs processing genomic data; warrants further exploration of protective strategies and broader model/dataset evaluation.

title: Testing and Evaluation of Underwater Vehicle Using Hardware-In-The-Loop Simulation with HoloOcean
comment: Published in IEEE/MTS OCEANS Conference proceedings 2025 Great Lakes
summary: Testing marine robotics systems in controlled environments before field tests is challenging, especially when acoustic-based sensors and control surfaces only function properly underwater. Deploying robots in indoor tanks and pools often faces space constraints that complicate testing of control, navigation, and perception algorithms at scale. Recent developments of high-fidelity underwater simulation tools have the potential to address these problems. We demonstrate the utility of the recently released HoloOcean 2.0 simulator with improved dynamics for torpedo AUV vehicles and a new ROS 2 interface. We have successfully demonstrated a Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) and Software-in-the-Loop (SIL) setup for testing and evaluating a CougUV torpedo autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) that was built and developed in our lab. With this HIL and SIL setup, simulations are run in HoloOcean using a ROS 2 bridge such that simulated sensor data is sent to the CougUV (mimicking sensor drivers) and control surface commands are sent back to the simulation, where vehicle dynamics and sensor data are calculated. We compare our simulated results to real-world field trial results.

AI.tldr: High-fidelity underwater simulation (HoloOcean 2.0) with a ROS 2 interface enables HIL/SIL testing of a torpedo AUV (CougUV), aligning simulated results with field trials.
AI.motivation: Testing marine robotics in indoor facilities is constrained by space and the need for underwater functioning acoustic sensors and control surfaces. A high-fidelity simulator can accelerate development, validation, and iteration by bridging virtual and real hardware.
AI.method: Utilize HoloOcean 2.0 with enhanced torpedo AUV dynamics and a new ROS 2 interface. Establish Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) and Software-in-the-Loop (SIL) workflows where simulated sensor data is fed to the CougUV as sensor drivers and control commands are applied in the simulator. Run simulations in HoloOcean with a ROS 2 bridge and compare outcomes to real-field trial data.
AI.result: The study demonstrates successful HIL and SIL setups. Simulated sensor streams and control commands were exchanged with the CougUV via ROS 2, and dynamics were computed within the simulator. Results from simulations were compared with field trial data, indicating good correspondence and validating the approach.
AI.conclusion: HoloOcean 2.0, with its enhanced dynamics and ROS 2 interface, provides a credible, scalable platform for indoors/narrow-water testing of AUVs, reducing reliance on field trials and enabling rigorous offline and hardware-in-the-loop validation of perception, navigation, and control algorithms.

title: Beyond Correctness: Confidence-Aware Reward Modeling for Enhancing Large Language Model Reasoning
summary: Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs) have shifted the post-training paradigm from traditional instruction tuning and human preference alignment toward reinforcement learning (RL) focused on reasoning capabilities. However, numerous technical reports indicate that purely rule-based reward RL frequently results in poor-quality reasoning chains or inconsistencies between reasoning processes and final answers, particularly when the base model is of smaller scale. During the RL exploration process, models might employ low-quality reasoning chains due to the lack of knowledge, occasionally producing correct answers randomly and receiving rewards based on established rule-based judges. This constrains the potential for resource-limited organizations to conduct direct reinforcement learning training on smaller-scale models. We propose a novel confidence-based reward model tailored for enhancing STEM reasoning capabilities. Unlike conventional approaches, our model penalizes not only incorrect answers but also low-confidence correct responses, thereby promoting more robust and logically consistent reasoning. We validate the effectiveness of our approach through static evaluations, Best-of-N inference tests, and PPO-based RL training. Our method outperforms several state-of-the-art open-source reward models across diverse STEM benchmarks. We release our codes and model in https://github.com/qianxiHe147/C2RM.

AI.tldr: Introduces a confidence-based reward model for RL-based STEM reasoning in LLMs that penalizes low-confidence correct answers to promote robust, consistent reasoning; outperforms several open-source reward models on STEM benchmarks and is released with code.
AI.motivation: Pure rule-based reward RL often yields low-quality or inconsistent reasoning, especially for smaller models; there is a need for a reward signal that encourages robust logical chain-of-thought and reduces spurious correct answers, enabling resource-limited organizations to train smaller LLMs.
AI.method: Develop a confidence-aware reward model that penalizes both incorrect answers and low-confidence correct responses. Evaluate via static evaluations, Best-of-N (BoN) inference, and PPO-based RL training; compare against state-of-the-art open-source reward models on STEM benchmarks; release code.
AI.result: The proposed reward model achieves superior performance relative to several state-of-the-art open-source reward models across diverse STEM benchmarks, demonstrating improved robustness and logical consistency in reasoning during RL.
AI.conclusion: Confidence-based reward modeling is effective for enhancing STEM reasoning in LLMs, particularly for smaller models and resource-limited settings; the work provides a practical, transferable approach and code release.

title: Modulo Video Recovery via Selective Spatiotemporal Vision Transformer
summary: Conventional image sensors have limited dynamic range, causing saturation in high-dynamic-range (HDR) scenes. Modulo cameras address this by folding incident irradiance into a bounded range, yet require specialized unwrapping algorithms to reconstruct the underlying signal. Unlike HDR recovery, which extends dynamic range from conventional sampling, modulo recovery restores actual values from folded samples. Despite being introduced over a decade ago, progress in modulo image recovery has been slow, especially in the use of modern deep learning techniques. In this work, we demonstrate that standard HDR methods are unsuitable for modulo recovery. Transformers, however, can capture global dependencies and spatial-temporal relationships crucial for resolving folded video frames. Still, adapting existing Transformer architectures for modulo recovery demands novel techniques. To this end, we present Selective Spatiotemporal Vision Transformer (SSViT), the first deep learning framework for modulo video reconstruction. SSViT employs a token selection strategy to improve efficiency and concentrate on the most critical regions. Experiments confirm that SSViT produces high-quality reconstructions from 8-bit folded videos and achieves state-of-the-art performance in modulo video recovery.

AI.tldr: Introduces SSViT, a selective spatiotemporal Vision Transformer for modulo video recovery, achieving state-of-the-art results on 8-bit folded videos by focusing on critical regions.
AI.motivation: Modulo cameras fold high dynamic range scenes to fit within a bounded range; conventional HDR methods fail to recover unfolded values; deep learning must capture global spatiotemporal dependencies to solve modulo unwrapping in video.
AI.method: Proposes Selective Spatiotemporal Vision Transformer (SSViT) with a token selection strategy to identify informative regions and adapt transformer-based processing for modulo signal reconstruction in video frames.
AI.result: SSViT achieves state-of-the-art performance in modulo video recovery, delivering high-quality reconstructions from 8-bit folded videos and outperforming existing approaches.
AI.conclusion: Selective spatiotemporal attention enables effective modulo video reconstruction; SSViT establishes a new deep-learning baseline for modulo imaging and highlights the potential of transformer-based models for folding/unfolding problems.

title: Topology-Preserving Line Densification for Creating Contiguous Cartograms
comment: 27 pages. 9 figures and 5 tables in the main text. 1 supplementary figure and 6 supplementary tables. Version accepted for publication in "Cartography and Geographic Information Science."
summary: Cartograms depict geographic regions with areas proportional to quantitative data. However, when created using density-equalizing map projections, cartograms may exhibit invalid topologies if boundary polygons are drawn using only a finite set of vertices connected by straight lines. Here we introduce a method for topology-preserving line densification that guarantees that cartogram regions remain connected and non-overlapping when using density-equalizing map projections. By combining our densification technique with a flow-based cartogram generator, we present a robust framework for strictly topology-preserving cartogram construction. Quantitative evaluations demonstrate that the proposed algorithm produces cartograms with greater accuracy and speed than alternative methods while maintaining comparable shape fidelity.

AI.tldr: Topology-preserving line densification for density-equalizing cartograms coupled with a flow-based generator yields accurate, fast, topology-safe cartograms.
AI.motivation: Density-equalizing projections can create invalid/topology-violating cartograms when polygons are simplified to finite vertex sets; a method to guarantee connectivity and non-overlap is needed.
AI.method: Develop a line densification technique that increases boundary detail to enforce topology during density-based distortion; integrate with a flow-based cartogram generator to produce topology-preserving maps. Evaluate quantitatively against alternatives.
AI.result: The proposed algorithm achieves greater accuracy and speed than competing methods while maintaining comparable shape fidelity.
AI.conclusion: The densification-enabled, flow-based approach provides a robust framework for strictly topology-preserving cartograms, improving validity and efficiency without sacrificing shape quality.

title: Alignment-Constrained Dynamic Pruning for LLMs: Identifying and Preserving Alignment-Critical Circuits
summary: Large Language Models require substantial computational resources for inference, posing deployment challenges. While dynamic pruning offers superior efficiency over static methods through adaptive circuit selection, it exacerbates alignment degradation by retaining only input-dependent safety-critical circuit preservation across diverse inputs. As a result, addressing these heightened alignment vulnerabilities remains critical. We introduce Alignment-Aware Probe Pruning (AAPP), a dynamic structured pruning method that adaptively preserves alignment-relevant circuits during inference, building upon Probe Pruning. Experiments on LLaMA 2-7B, Qwen2.5-14B-Instruct, and Gemma-3-12B-IT show AAPP improves refusal rates by 50\% at matched compute, enabling efficient yet safety-preserving LLM deployment.

AI.tldr: Alignment-Aware Probe Pruning (AAPP) is a dynamic structured pruning method that preserves alignment-relevant circuits during inference, improving refusal rates by 50% at matched compute across multiple LLMs.
AI.motivation: Dynamic pruning boosts efficiency but risks alignment by keeping only input-dependent safety-critical circuits; mitigating these alignment vulnerabilities is essential for safe deployment of LLMs.
AI.method: AAPP extends Probe Pruning by adaptively identifying and preserving alignment-relevant circuits during inference, ensuring safety-critical components are retained while pruning the rest.
AI.result: Experiments on LLaMA 2-7B, Qwen2.5-14B-Instruct, and Gemma-3-12B-IT show AAPP achieves ~50% higher refusal rates at matched compute, enabling more efficient yet safety-preserving deployment.
AI.conclusion: Alignment-aware dynamic pruning is effective for balancing efficiency and safety in LLM deployment; AAPP demonstrates practical gains and highlights the value of preserving alignment-critical circuits during adaptive pruning.

title: RoboTAG: End-to-end Robot Configuration Estimation via Topological Alignment Graph
summary: Estimating robot pose from a monocular RGB image is a challenge in robotics and computer vision. Existing methods typically build networks on top of 2D visual backbones and depend heavily on labeled data for training, which is often scarce in real-world scenarios, causing a sim-to-real gap. Moreover, these approaches reduce the 3D-based problem to 2D domain, neglecting the 3D priors. To address these, we propose Robot Topological Alignment Graph (RoboTAG), which incorporates a 3D branch to inject 3D priors while enabling co-evolution of the 2D and 3D representations, alleviating the reliance on labels. Specifically, the RoboTAG consists of a 3D branch and a 2D branch, where nodes represent the states of the camera and robot system, and edges capture the dependencies between these variables or denote alignments between them. Closed loops are then defined in the graph, on which a consistency supervision across branches can be applied. This design allows us to utilize in-the-wild images as training data without annotations. Experimental results demonstrate that our method is effective across robot types, highlighting its potential to alleviate the data bottleneck in robotics.

AI.tldr: RoboTAG proposes a topological alignment graph with a 3D branch to inject 3D priors into monocular pose estimation, enabling co-evolution of 2D/3D representations and training on unlabeled in-the-wild images.
AI.motivation: Monocular pose estimation with RGB input is hampered by scarce labeled data, a sim-to-real gap, and the neglect of 3D priors when using 2D backbones. A method that leverages unlabeled real-world data while incorporating 3D information could improve generalization.
AI.method: A dual-branch graph (3D and 2D) where nodes denote camera/robot states and edges encode variable dependencies or cross-branch alignments. Closed loops enable cross-branch consistency supervision. Training uses in-the-wild images with no annotations.
AI.result: Experiments show effectiveness across robot types and indicate a reduced data bottleneck and potential for better sim-to-real transfer by exploiting 3D priors and unlabeled data.
AI.conclusion: A graph-based, loop-consistent framework that couples 2D representations with a 3D priors branch can leverage unlabeled imagery to improve monocular robot pose estimation and generalize across robotic systems.

title: Procedural Knowledge Improves Agentic LLM Workflows
summary: Large language models (LLMs) often struggle when performing agentic tasks without substantial tool support, prom-pt engineering, or fine tuning. Despite research showing that domain-dependent, procedural knowledge can dramatically increase planning efficiency, little work evaluates its potential for improving LLM performance on agentic tasks that may require implicit planning. We formalize, implement, and evaluate an agentic LLM workflow that leverages procedural knowledge in the form of a hierarchical task network (HTN). Empirical results of our implementation show that hand-coded HTNs can dramatically improve LLM performance on agentic tasks, and using HTNs can boost a 20b or 70b parameter LLM to outperform a much larger 120b parameter LLM baseline. Furthermore, LLM-created HTNs improve overall performance, though less so. The results suggest that leveraging expertise--from humans, documents, or LLMs--to curate procedural knowledge will become another important tool for improving LLM workflows.

AI.tldr: Hand-coded hierarchical task networks (HTNs) dramatically boost LLM performance on agentic tasks; even smaller LLMs can surpass larger baselines when aided by HTNs, and LLM-generated HTNs are beneficial though less impactful.
AI.motivation: LLMs often struggle with agentic, planning-heavy tasks without substantial tool support or fine-tuning. Procedural knowledge, if properly organized, can dramatically improve planning efficiency and enable implicit planning.
AI.method: Formalize an agentic LLM workflow around hierarchical task networks (HTNs). Implement hand-coded HTNs and evaluate their impact on agentic tasks across LLMs of different sizes; also assess HTNs generated by LLMs.
AI.result: Hand-coded HTNs significantly improve performance; 20B or 70B LLMs with HTNs can outperform a 120B baseline; LLM-created HTNs improve performance too, but to a lesser extent.
AI.conclusion: Curating procedural knowledge from humans, documents, or LLMs is a promising, increasingly important tool for enhancing LLM workflows and agentic task performance.

title: Laplacian Score Sharpening for Mitigating Hallucination in Diffusion Models
summary: Diffusion models, though successful, are known to suffer from hallucinations that create incoherent or unrealistic samples. Recent works have attributed this to the phenomenon of mode interpolation and score smoothening, but they lack a method to prevent their generation during sampling. In this paper, we propose a post-hoc adjustment to the score function during inference that leverages the Laplacian (or sharpness) of the score to reduce mode interpolation hallucination in unconditional diffusion models across 1D, 2D, and high-dimensional image data. We derive an efficient Laplacian approximation for higher dimensions using a finite-difference variant of the Hutchinson trace estimator. We show that this correction significantly reduces the rate of hallucinated samples across toy 1D/2D distributions and a high- dimensional image dataset. Furthermore, our analysis explores the relationship between the Laplacian and uncertainty in the score.

AI.tldr: Post-hoc Laplacian-based correction to the score function during diffusion sampling reduces hallucinations from mode interpolation and score smoothing, using a finite-difference Hutchinson estimator for scalable high-dimensional data; shown to improve 1D/2D toy distributions and a high-dimensional image dataset; links Laplacian to score uncertainty.
AI.motivation: Diffusion models can produce hallucinations due to mode interpolation and score smoothening; there is a need for a post-hoc method that suppresses such artifacts during sampling without retraining the model.
AI.method: Introduce a post-hoc adjustment to the score function by incorporating the Laplacian (measure of sharpness) of the score. Develop an efficient high-dimensional Laplacian approximation using a finite-difference variant of the Hutchinson trace estimator and apply this correction during inference in unconditional diffusion models across 1D, 2D, and high-dimensional image data.
AI.result: The Laplacian-based correction significantly reduces the rate of hallucinated samples on toy 1D/2D distributions and on a high-dimensional image dataset, demonstrating practical effectiveness for mitigating mode-interpolation artifacts. Further analysis elucidates a relationship between the Laplacian and uncertainty in the score.
AI.conclusion: Laplacian-based post-hoc correction is a viable and efficient approach to suppress diffusion-model hallucinations related to mode interpolation, linking a measure of score sharpness to uncertainty and offering a scalable method for high-dimensional data.

title: Counterfactual Forecasting of Human Behavior using Generative AI and Causal Graphs
summary: This study presents a novel framework for counterfactual user behavior forecasting that combines structural causal models with transformer-based generative artificial intelligence. To model fictitious situations, the method creates causal graphs that map the connections between user interactions, adoption metrics, and product features. The framework generates realistic behavioral trajectories under counterfactual conditions by using generative models that are conditioned on causal variables. Tested on datasets from web interactions, mobile applications, and e-commerce, the methodology outperforms conventional forecasting and uplift modeling techniques. Product teams can effectively simulate and assess possible interventions prior to deployment thanks to the framework improved interpretability through causal path visualization.

AI.tldr: A framework that unites structural causal models with transformer-based generators for counterfactual user behavior forecasting, using causal graphs and conditioned generation to produce realistic trajectories; it outperforms baselines and enhances interpretability via causal-path visualizations.
AI.motivation: Forecasting user behavior under counterfactual interventions is valuable for decision-making. Existing methods struggle to provide both accurate predictions and interpretable causal insights. Integrating structural causal models with transformer-based generative AI aims to improve realism, counterfactual reasoning, and interpretability.
AI.method: Construct causal graphs linking user interactions, adoption metrics, and product features. Use transformer-based generative models conditioned on these causal variables to generate realistic counterfactual behavioral trajectories. Validate on datasets from web interactions, mobile apps, and e-commerce; provide visualization of causal paths to improve interpretability.
AI.result: The approach outperforms conventional forecasting and uplift modeling baselines. It offers improved interpretability through causal-path visualizations and enables product teams to simulate and evaluate interventions before deployment.
AI.conclusion: The framework demonstrates a cohesive, scalable approach that blends structural causal modeling with generative AI for counterfactual forecasting. It shows strong performance gains across domains and enhances decision-making through interpretable causal insights.

title: A QP Framework for Improving Data Collection: Quantifying Device-Controller Performance in Robot Teleoperation
summary: Robot learning empowers the robot system with human brain-like intelligence to autonomously acquire and adapt skills through experience, enhancing flexibility and adaptability in various environments. Aimed at achieving a similar level of capability in large language models (LLMs) for embodied intelligence, data quality plays a crucial role in training a foundational model with diverse robot skills. In this study, we investigate the collection of data for manipulation tasks using teleoperation devices. Different devices yield varying effects when paired with corresponding controller strategies, including position-based inverse kinematics (IK) control, torque-based inverse dynamics (ID) control, and optimization-based compliance control. In this paper, we develop a teleoperation pipeline that is compatible with different teleoperation devices and manipulator controllers. Within the pipeline, we construct the optimal QP formulation with the dynamic nullspace and the impedance tracking as the novel optimal controller to achieve compliant pose tracking and singularity avoidance. Regarding the optimal controller, it adaptively adjusts the weights assignment depending on the robot joint manipulability that reflects the state of joint configuration for the pose tracking in the form of impedance control and singularity avoidance with nullspace tracking. Analysis of quantitative experimental results suggests the quality of the teleoperated trajectory data, including tracking error, occurrence of singularity, and the smoothness of the joints' trajectory, with different combinations of teleoperation interface and the motion controller.

AI.tldr: A teleoperation pipeline compatible with multiple devices and controllers uses a novel QP-based optimal controller with dynamic nullspace and impedance tracking to collect high-quality manipulation data; the controller adaptively weights components based on joint manipulability to enable compliant pose tracking and avoid singularities, with results showing improved data quality via metrics like tracking error, singularity incidence, and trajectory smoothness.
AI.motivation: Data quality is critical for training embodied intelligence in robotics and LLM-based robotic systems. Different teleoperation devices and controllers yield varying data quality; a unified pipeline that delivers compliant tracking and singularity avoidance can produce more reliable, diverse manipulation data for downstream learning.
AI.method: Develop a device-agnostic teleoperation pipeline and formulate an optimal controller as a quadratic program (QP) that includes a dynamic nullspace projection and impedance-based tracking. The controller adaptively assigns weights based on current joint manipulability to enhance pose tracking and avoid singularities, along with nullspace tracking. The pipeline integrates position-based IK, torque-based ID control, or optimization-based compliance control as compatible controllers across devices.
AI.result: Quantitative experiments demonstrate that data quality varies with teleoperation interface and controller; metrics include tracking error, occurrence of singularities, and joint trajectory smoothness, highlighting the impact of device-controller combinations on the collected data.
AI.conclusion: The proposed teleoperation framework and adaptive, nullspace-aware QP controller improve the quality of teleoperated manipulation data across devices, supporting better learning for embodied intelligence and robotic control; adaptive weighting based on manipulability helps mitigate singularities during pose tracking.

title: Think Before You Retrieve: Learning Test-Time Adaptive Search with Small Language Models
summary: Effective information retrieval requires reasoning over partial evidence and refining strategies as information emerges. Yet current approaches fall short: neural retrievers lack reasoning capabilities, large language models (LLMs) provide semantic depth but at prohibitive cost, and query rewriting or decomposition limits improvement to static transformations. As a result, existing methods fail to capture the iterative dynamics of exploration, feedback, and revision that complex user queries demand. We introduce Orion, a training framework that enables compact models (350M-1.2B parameters) to perform iterative retrieval through learned search strategies. Orion combines: (1) synthetic trajectory generation and supervised fine-tuning to encourage diverse exploration patterns in models, (2) reinforcement learning (RL) that rewards effective query refinement and backtracking behaviors, and (3) inference-time beam search algorithms that exploit the self-reflection capabilities learned during RL. Despite using only 3% of the training data available, our 1.2B model achieves 77.6% success on SciFact (vs. 72.6% for prior retrievers), 25.2% on BRIGHT (vs. 22.1%), 63.2% on NFCorpus (vs. 57.8%), and remains competitive on FEVER, HotpotQA, and MSMarco. It outperforms retrievers up to 200-400x larger on five of six benchmarks. These findings suggest that retrieval performance can emerge from learned strategies, not just model scale, when models are trained to search, reflect, and revise.

AI.tldr: Orion enables compact models to perform iterative retrieval via synthetic trajectories, RL, and beam search; with only 3% training data, 1.2B model achieves strong results across multiple benchmarks, outperforming much larger retrievers.
AI.motivation: Current neural retrievers struggle with reasoning over partial evidence and iterative exploration, while large language models are costly; there is a need for efficient, iterative retrieval that learns search strategies.
AI.method: (1) generate synthetic trajectories and supervise fine-tuning to foster diverse exploration; (2) apply reinforcement learning that rewards effective query refinement and backtracking; (3) use inference-time beam search to exploit learned self-reflection during RL.
AI.result: 1.2B model with 3% of training data achieves 77.6% on SciFact (vs. 72.6%), 25.2% on BRIGHT (vs. 22.1%), 63.2% on NFCorpus (vs. 57.8%), competitive on FEVER, HotpotQA, MSMarco; outperforms retrievers up to 200-400x larger on five of six benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Retrieval performance can emerge from learned search strategies, not just model scale, when models are trained to search, reflect, and revise.

title: Toward the Frontiers of Reliable Diffusion Sampling via Adversarial Sinkhorn Attention Guidance
summary: Diffusion models have demonstrated strong generative performance when using guidance methods such as classifier-free guidance (CFG), which enhance output quality by modifying the sampling trajectory. These methods typically improve a target output by intentionally degrading another, often the unconditional output, using heuristic perturbation functions such as identity mixing or blurred conditions. However, these approaches lack a principled foundation and rely on manually designed distortions. In this work, we propose Adversarial Sinkhorn Attention Guidance (ASAG), a novel method that reinterprets attention scores in diffusion models through the lens of optimal transport and intentionally disrupt the transport cost via Sinkhorn algorithm. Instead of naively corrupting the attention mechanism, ASAG injects an adversarial cost within self-attention layers to reduce pixel-wise similarity between queries and keys. This deliberate degradation weakens misleading attention alignments and leads to improved conditional and unconditional sample quality. ASAG shows consistent improvements in text-to-image diffusion, and enhances controllability and fidelity in downstream applications such as IP-Adapter and ControlNet. The method is lightweight, plug-and-play, and improves reliability without requiring any model retraining.

AI.tldr: ASAG (Adversarial Sinkhorn Attention Guidance) reinterprets diffusion attention as an optimal-transport problem and injects an adversarial Sinkhorn cost into self-attention to degrade query-key similarity, improving conditional/unconditional diffusion outputs without retraining; it’s plug-and-play and enhances downstream controllability (IP-Adapter, ControlNet).
AI.motivation: Current guidance methods (e.g., classifier-free guidance) rely on heuristic distortions and lack a principled foundation for modifying attention; there is a need for a theoretically grounded, lightweight technique to improve diffusion outputs and reliability without retraining.
AI.method: Treat attention scores as transport costs in an optimal-transport framework. Inject an adversarial cost into self-attention by perturbing the Sinkhorn-regularized transport plan, effectively reducing pixel-wise query-key similarity. This degrades misleading attention alignments to improve both conditional and unconditional sampling. The approach is lightweight, plug-and-play, and does not require model training or retraining.
AI.result: ASAG yields consistent quality gains in text-to-image diffusion and improves controllability and fidelity in downstream tools such as IP-Adapter and ControlNet.
AI.conclusion: ASAG provides a principled, lightweight, non-retraining mechanism to guide diffusion via attention perturbations, improving reliability and sample quality while remaining plug-and-play for existing diffusion pipelines.

title: When Are Learning Biases Equivalent? A Unifying Framework for Fairness, Robustness, and Distribution Shift
summary: Machine learning systems exhibit diverse failure modes: unfairness toward protected groups, brittleness to spurious correlations, poor performance on minority sub-populations, which are typically studied in isolation by distinct research communities. We propose a unifying theoretical framework that characterizes when different bias mechanisms produce quantitatively equivalent effects on model performance. By formalizing biases as violations of conditional independence through information-theoretic measures, we prove formal equivalence conditions relating spurious correlations, subpopulation shift, class imbalance, and fairness violations. Our theory predicts that a spurious correlation of strength $α$ produces equivalent worst-group accuracy degradation as a sub-population imbalance ratio $r \approx (1+α)/(1-α)$ under feature overlap assumptions. Empirical validation in six datasets and three architectures confirms that predicted equivalences hold within the accuracy of the worst group 3\%, enabling the principled transfer of debiasing methods across problem domains. This work bridges the literature on fairness, robustness, and distribution shifts under a common perspective.

AI.tldr: A unifying information-theoretic framework shows that biases from spurious correlations, subpopulation shifts, class imbalance, and fairness violations have equivalent effects on worst-group accuracy under conditional independence violations; a spurious correlation of strength α is equivalent to a subpopulation imbalance ratio r ≈ (1+α)/(1-α) given feature overlap; validated across six datasets and three architectures, enabling transferring debiasing methods across domains.
AI.motivation: Bias in ML manifests as unfairness, brittleness to spurious correlations, and poor minority subpopulation performance, typically studied separately. A unifying theory can explain equivalences between these biases and enable cross-domain debiasing.
AI.method: Formalize biases as violations of conditional independence using information-theoretic measures. Prove equivalence conditions linking spurious correlations, subpopulation shift, class imbalance, and fairness violations. Derive the relation between spurious correlation strength α and imbalance ratio r under feature overlap. Validate predictions empirically on six datasets across three architectures.
AI.result: Derived formal equivalence conditions among bias mechanisms and a quantitative mapping (α to r) for worst-group accuracy degradation. Empirical results confirm the predicted equivalences within 3% worst-group accuracy degradation across datasets and models.
AI.conclusion: Bridges fairness, robustness, and distribution-shift literatures under a single perspective, enabling principled transfer of debiasing methods across problem domains.

title: LLM-GROP: Visually Grounded Robot Task and Motion Planning with Large Language Models
summary:
Task planning and motion planning are two of the most important problems in robotics, where task planning methods help robots achieve high-level goals and motion planning methods maintain low-level feasibility. Task and motion planning (TAMP) methods interleave the two processes of task planning and motion planning to ensure goal achievement and motion feasibility. Within the TAMP context, we are concerned with the mobile manipulation (MoMa) of multiple objects, where it is necessary to interleave actions for navigation and manipulation.
  In particular, we aim to compute where and how each object should be placed given underspecified goals, such as ``set up dinner table with a fork, knife and plate.'' We leverage the rich common sense knowledge from large language models (LLMs), e.g., about how tableware is organized, to facilitate both task-level and motion-level planning. In addition, we use computer vision methods to learn a strategy for selecting base positions to facilitate MoMa behaviors, where the base position corresponds to the robot's ``footprint'' and orientation in its operating space. Altogether, this article provides a principled TAMP framework for MoMa tasks that accounts for common sense about object rearrangement and is adaptive to novel situations that include many objects that need to be moved. We performed quantitative experiments in both real-world settings and simulated environments. We evaluated the success rate and efficiency in completing long-horizon object rearrangement tasks. While the robot completed 84.4\% real-world object rearrangement trials, subjective human evaluations indicated that the robot's performance is still lower than experienced human waiters.

AI.tldr: A principled task-and-motion planning (TAMP) framework for mobile manipulation of multiple objects under underspecified goals. It leverages large-language models (LLMs) for common-sense knowledge about rearrangement and computer vision to learn base-position strategies, enabling interleaved navigation and manipulation. Real-world experiments show an 84.4% success rate, but performance remains below experienced human waiters, indicating room for improvement.
AI.motivation: To enable robust mobile manipulation of multiple objects under underspecified goals by tightly integrating task planning, motion planning, LLM-based common-sense knowledge, and perception-driven base-position selection. The work aims to bridge the gap between high-level goal specification and low-level feasibility in dynamic, multi-object rearrangement tasks.
AI.method: Integrates LLM-derived common-sense planning for object rearrangement with a TAMP framework that interleaves navigation and manipulation actions. Uses computer-vision-based learning to predict robot base positions (footprint and orientation) to facilitate MoMa. Evaluates long-horizon object rearrangement tasks in both real and simulated settings, measuring success rate and efficiency.
AI.result: Real-world experiments achieved 84.4% success in object rearrangement trials; simulations corroborate the approach. Human evaluators rated the robot as performing below experienced human waiters, indicating a gap to human-level performance but demonstrating a notable capability in adaptive MoMa tasks.
AI.conclusion: The paper offers a principled TAMP framework that blends LLM-based common sense and vision-driven base-position strategies to handle underspecified, multi-object rearrangement. It demonstrates feasibility and adaptability in real-world MoMa tasks, while highlighting the need for further improvements to reach human-level performance.

title: Beyond Fact Retrieval: Episodic Memory for RAG with Generative Semantic Workspaces
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) face fundamental challenges in long-context reasoning: many documents exceed their finite context windows, while performance on texts that do fit degrades with sequence length, necessitating their augmentation with external memory frameworks. Current solutions, which have evolved from retrieval using semantic embeddings to more sophisticated structured knowledge graphs representations for improved sense-making and associativity, are tailored for fact-based retrieval and fail to build the space-time-anchored narrative representations required for tracking entities through episodic events. To bridge this gap, we propose the \textbf{Generative Semantic Workspace} (GSW), a neuro-inspired generative memory framework that builds structured, interpretable representations of evolving situations, enabling LLMs to reason over evolving roles, actions, and spatiotemporal contexts. Our framework comprises an \textit{Operator}, which maps incoming observations to intermediate semantic structures, and a \textit{Reconciler}, which integrates these into a persistent workspace that enforces temporal, spatial, and logical coherence. On the Episodic Memory Benchmark (EpBench) \cite{huet_episodic_2025} comprising corpora ranging from 100k to 1M tokens in length, GSW outperforms existing RAG based baselines by up to \textbf{20\%}. Furthermore, GSW is highly efficient, reducing query-time context tokens by \textbf{51\%} compared to the next most token-efficient baseline, reducing inference time costs considerably. More broadly, GSW offers a concrete blueprint for endowing LLMs with human-like episodic memory, paving the way for more capable agents that can reason over long horizons.

AI.tldr: GSW is a neuro-inspired generative memory framework that builds structured episodic, spatiotemporal representations for LLMs, enabling long-horizon reasoning; uses Operator and Reconciler; outperforms RAG baselines on EpBench by up to 20% and reduces query tokens by 51%; provides a blueprint for human-like episodic memory in LLM agents.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle with long contexts and degrade with sequence length; existing retrieval methods (embedding-based or knowledge graphs) are not tailored to track evolving entities through episodic events; need space-time anchored narratives.
AI.method: Introduce Generative Semantic Workspace (GSW) with two components: Operator to map observations into intermediate semantic structures; Reconciler to integrate into a persistent workspace enforcing temporal, spatial, and logical coherence; evaluation on EpBench 100k-1M tokens.
AI.result: GSW outperforms existing RAG baselines by up to 20% on EpBench and reduces query-time context tokens by 51% relative to the next most token-efficient baseline, lowering inference costs.
AI.conclusion: GSW offers a concrete blueprint for endowing LLMs with human-like episodic memory, enabling reasoning over long horizons and advancing agent capabilities.

title: LiveNeRF: Efficient Face Replacement Through Neural Radiance Fields Integration
