summary: Face replacement technology enables significant advancements in entertainment, education, and communication applications, including dubbing, virtual avatars, and cross-cultural content adaptation. Our LiveNeRF framework addresses critical limitations of existing methods by achieving real-time performance (33 FPS) with superior visual quality, enabling practical deployment in live streaming, video conferencing, and interactive media. The technology particularly benefits content creators, educators, and individuals with speech impairments through accessible avatar communication. While acknowledging potential misuse in unauthorized deepfake creation, we advocate for responsible deployment with user consent verification and integration with detection systems to ensure positive societal impact while minimizing risks.

AI.tldr: Real-time face replacement framework LiveNeRF enables 33 FPS face substitution with high visual quality for live media, while noting ethical safeguards.
AI.motivation: There is strong demand for high-quality, low-latency avatar-based communication in entertainment, education, and accessibility. Current methods struggle with real-time performance and robustness, and there are risks of misuse in deepfakes.
AI.method: Proposes LiveNeRF, a real-time NeRF-based face replacement approach optimized for live streaming and video conferencing to deliver 33 FPS with improved visual fidelity.
AI.result: Demonstrates real-time performance at 33 FPS with superior visual quality, enabling practical deployment in live streaming, video conferencing, and interactive media.
AI.conclusion: Acknowledges potential misuse for unauthorized deepfakes; advocates for responsible deployment with user consent verification and integration with detection systems to maximize positive societal impact while mitigating risks.

title: Provably Efficient Sample Complexity for Robust CMDP
summary: We study the problem of learning policies that maximize cumulative reward while satisfying safety constraints, even when the real environment differs from a simulator or nominal model. We focus on robust constrained Markov decision processes (RCMDPs), where the agent must maximize reward while ensuring cumulative utility exceeds a threshold under the worst-case dynamics within an uncertainty set. While recent works have established finite-time iteration complexity guarantees for RCMDPs using policy optimization, their sample complexity guarantees remain largely unexplored. In this paper, we first show that Markovian policies may fail to be optimal even under rectangular uncertainty sets unlike the {\em unconstrained} robust MDP. To address this, we introduce an augmented state space that incorporates the remaining utility budget into the state representation. Building on this formulation, we propose a novel Robust constrained Value iteration (RCVI) algorithm with a sample complexity of $\mathcal{\tilde{O}}(|S||A|H^5/ε^2)$ achieving at most $ε$ violation using a generative model where $|S|$ and $|A|$ denote the sizes of the state and action spaces, respectively, and $H$ is the episode length. To the best of our knowledge, this is the {\em first sample complexity guarantee} for RCMDP. Empirical results further validate the effectiveness of our approach.

AI.tldr: Introduces Robust Constrained Value Iteration (RCVI) for RCMDPs, augmenting the state to track remaining utility budget, and proves the first sample complexity guarantee of tilde O(|S||A|H^5/ε^2) with ε-violation under a generative model.
AI.motivation: Safe reinforcement learning under model misspecification: existing RCMDP results show finite-time guarantees but lack sample complexity guarantees; Markovian policies can be suboptimal under uncertainty; need an augmented state to maintain feasibility with respect to a safety budget.
AI.method: Augment the MDP state with the remaining utility budget; develop Robust Constrained Value Iteration (RCVI) that optimizes under worst-case dynamics within an uncertainty set; analyze sample complexity under a generative (sampling) model; derive an upper bound of Õ(|S||A|H^5/ε^2) ensuring at most ε violation.
AI.result: First known sample complexity guarantee for RCMDPs; RCVI achieves near-optimal reward while satisfying safety constraint with high probability up to ε violation; empirical results corroborate theoretical findings.
AI.conclusion: This work delivers the inaugural sample complexity bound for RCMDPs, enabling principled, data-efficient safe planning under model uncertainty and paving the way for more practical robust, constrained RL algorithms.

title: ViPRA: Video Prediction for Robot Actions
summary: Can we turn a video prediction model into a robot policy? Videos, including those of humans or teleoperated robots, capture rich physical interactions. However, most of them lack labeled actions, which limits their use in robot learning. We present Video Prediction for Robot Actions (ViPRA), a simple pretraining-finetuning framework that learns continuous robot control from these actionless videos. Instead of directly predicting actions, we train a video-language model to predict both future visual observations and motion-centric latent actions, which serve as intermediate representations of scene dynamics. We train these latent actions using perceptual losses and optical flow consistency to ensure they reflect physically grounded behavior. For downstream control, we introduce a chunked flow matching decoder that maps latent actions to robot-specific continuous action sequences, using only 100 to 200 teleoperated demonstrations. This approach avoids expensive action annotation, supports generalization across embodiments, and enables smooth, high-frequency continuous control upto 22 Hz via chunked action decoding. Unlike prior latent action works that treat pretraining as autoregressive policy learning, explicitly models both what changes and how. Our method outperforms strong baselines, with a 16% gain on the SIMPLER benchmark and a 13% improvement across real world manipulation tasks. We will release models and code at https://vipra-project.github.io

AI.tldr: ViPRA converts actionless videos into robot policies by learning latent motion actions through a video-language pretraining stage and then decoding them into continuous control using a lightweight, chunked flow decoder, enabling high-frequency control with few demonstrations and outperforming baselines.
AI.motivation: Labeled action data in real videos are scarce; leveraging actionless videos (including human and teleoperated footage) to learn controllable representations can generalize across embodiments and reduce annotation costs.
AI.method: Train a video-language model to predict future observations and latent motion-centric actions, guided by perceptual losses and optical-flow consistency to ensure physically grounded dynamics. A chunked flow matching decoder maps these latent actions to robot-specific continuous action sequences, trained with only 100–200 teleoperated demonstrations, achieving up to 22 Hz control.
AI.result: Significant gains over strong baselines: ~16% improvement on the SIMPLER benchmark and ~13% improvement on real-world manipulation tasks; enables smooth high-frequency control and generalizes across embodiments; code and models to be released.
AI.conclusion: Actionless videos can be harnessed to produce practical robot policies by explicitly modeling both what changes and how, via latent motion actions and a lightweight decoder; ViPRA provides a scalable pretraining-finetuning pathway to learn robust robot control from unlabeled video data.

title: AI-Driven Contribution Evaluation and Conflict Resolution: A Framework & Design for Group Workload Investigation
summary: The equitable assessment of individual contribution in teams remains a persistent challenge, where conflict and disparity in workload can result in unfair performance evaluation, often requiring manual intervention - a costly and challenging process. We survey existing tool features and identify a gap in conflict resolution methods and AI integration. To address this, we propose a framework and implementation design for a novel AI-enhanced tool that assists in dispute investigation. The framework organises heterogeneous artefacts - submissions (code, text, media), communications (chat, email), coordination records (meeting logs, tasks), peer assessments, and contextual information - into three dimensions with nine benchmarks: Contribution, Interaction, and Role. Objective measures are normalised, aggregated per dimension, and paired with inequality measures (Gini index) to surface conflict markers. A Large Language Model (LLM) architecture performs validated and contextual analysis over these measures to generate interpretable and transparent advisory judgments. We argue for feasibility under current statutory and institutional policy, and outline practical analytics (sentimental, task fidelity, word/line count, etc.), bias safeguards, limitations, and practical challenges.

AI.tldr: A conceptual framework for an AI-enhanced tool to equitably assess individual contribution in teams by integrating heterogeneous artefacts into a three-dimensional, nine-benchmark framework, using normalized metrics and Gini-based inequality measures, with an LLM to generate transparent advisory judgments; discusses feasibility, analytics, safeguards, and challenges.
AI.motivation: Fair, transparent, scalable evaluation of team contributions to prevent dispute and bias and reduce manual intervention; current tools lack conflict resolution and AI-enabled analysis.
AI.method: Organize artefacts (code, text, media, communications, coordination records, peer assessments, contextual info) into three dimensions (Contribution, Interaction, Role) across nine benchmarks; normalize measures; compute inequality (Gini); use LLM architecture to perform contextual analysis and produce advisory judgments; discuss analytics (sentiment, task fidelity, word/line counts), bias safeguards, limitations, and practical challenges.
AI.result: Conceptual framework and implementation design; feasibility arguments under current policy; no empirical results reported in abstract; outlines analytics, safeguards, and potential challenges.
AI.conclusion: Feasible, policies permitting; offers a blueprint for AI-assisted dispute investigation in teams and calls for further development and evaluation.

title: TrackStudio: An Integrated Toolkit for Markerless Tracking
comment: 26 pages, 5 main text figures, 5 supplementary figures
summary:
Markerless motion tracking has advanced rapidly in the past 10 years and currently offers powerful opportunities for behavioural, clinical, and biomechanical research. While several specialised toolkits provide high performance for specific tasks, using existing tools still requires substantial technical expertise. There remains a gap in accessible, integrated solutions that deliver sufficient tracking for non-experts across diverse settings.
  TrackStudio was developed to address this gap by combining established open-source tools into a single, modular, GUI-based pipeline that works out of the box. It provides automatic 2D and 3D tracking, calibration, preprocessing, feature extraction, and visualisation without requiring any programming skills. We supply a user guide with practical advice for video acquisition, synchronisation, and setup, alongside documentation of common pitfalls and how to avoid them.
  To validate the toolkit, we tested its performance across three environments using either low-cost webcams or high-resolution cameras, including challenging conditions for body position, lightning, and space and obstructions. Across 76 participants, average inter-frame correlations exceeded 0.98 and average triangulation errors remained low (<13.6mm for hand tracking), demonstrating stable and consistent tracking. We further show that the same pipeline can be extended beyond hand tracking to other body and face regions. TrackStudio provides a practical, accessible route into markerless tracking for researchers or laypeople who need reliable performance without specialist expertise.

AI.tldr: TrackStudio is a GUI-based, out-of-the-box markerless tracking suite that merges open-source tools for automatic 2D/3D tracking, calibration, preprocessing, feature extraction, and visualization, designed for non-experts and diverse settings.
AI.motivation: Address the gap between powerful markerless tracking tools and accessibility; existing options require substantial technical expertise, hindering non-experts from using markerless tracking across varied contexts.
AI.method: Integrates established open-source components into a modular GUI pipeline that works out of the box, offering automatic 2D/3D tracking, calibration, preprocessing, feature extraction, and visualisation; includes a user guide for video acquisition, synchronization, and setup, plus guidance on common pitfalls.
AI.result: Validated across three environments with low-cost webcams and high-resolution cameras; 76 participants; average inter-frame correlations >0.98; triangulation errors for hand tracking <13.6 mm; same pipeline extends to other body/face regions; demonstrates stable, reliable tracking without programming.
AI.conclusion: TrackStudio provides a practical, accessible route into markerless tracking for researchers or laypeople, enabling reliable performance without specialist expertise and adaptable to broader body regions.

title: Methodological Precedence in Health Tech: Why ML/Big Data Analysis Must Follow Basic Epidemiological Consistency. A Case Study
comment: 2 Tables; ML/Big data paper on medical data
summary: The integration of advanced analytical tools, including Machine Learning (ML) and massive data processing, has revolutionized health research, promising unprecedented accuracy in diagnosis and risk prediction. However, the rigor of these complex methods is fundamentally dependent on the quality and integrity of the underlying datasets and the validity of their statistical design. We propose an emblematic case where advanced analysis (ML/Big Data) must necessarily be subsequent to the verification of basic methodological coherence. This study highlights a crucial cautionary principle: sophisticated analyses amplify, rather than correct, severe methodological flaws rooted in basic design choices, leading to misleading or contradictory findings. By applying simple, standard descriptive statistical methods and established national epidemiological benchmarks to a recently published cohort study on vaccine outcomes and psychiatric events, we expose multiple, statistically irreconcilable paradoxes. These paradoxes, including an implausible risk reduction for a chronic disorder in a high-risk group and contradictory incidence rate comparisons, definitively invalidate the reported hazard ratios (HRs). We demonstrate that the observed effects are mathematical artifacts stemming from an uncorrected selection bias in the cohort construction. This analysis serves as a robust reminder that even the most complex health studies must first pass the test of basic epidemiological consistency before any conclusion drawn from subsequent advanced ML or statistical modeling can be considered valid or publishable. We conclude that robust methods, such as Propensity Score Matching, are essential for achieving valid causal inference from administrative data in the absence of randomization

AI.tldr: Advanced ML/big-data analyses can amplify fundamental design flaws in epidemiologic studies. The authors demonstrate paradoxes in a vaccine-outcome cohort by applying basic descriptive methods and benchmarks, showing that reported hazard ratios are artifacts of uncorrected selection bias. They argue for rigorous basic design checks and causal methods (e.g., Propensity Score Matching) before complex analyses.
AI.motivation: To warn researchers that sophisticated analytics do not compensate for fundamental methodological issues in study design and data quality, and that ensuring basic epidemiological coherence is essential for valid conclusions.
AI.method: Apply simple descriptive statistics and national epidemiological benchmarks to a recently published cohort study on vaccine outcomes and psychiatric events, revealing irreconcilable paradoxes and demonstrating that observed effects arise from selection bias in cohort construction.
AI.result: Identification of multiple paradoxes (e.g., implausible risk reductions, contradictory incidence-rate comparisons) that invalidate the reported HRs; demonstration that effects are mathematical artifacts due to uncorrected selection bias.
AI.conclusion: Robust causal inference requires strong design and bias-control; methods like Propensity Score Matching are essential when using administrative data without randomization to obtain valid conclusions.

title: Navigating the Wild: Pareto-Optimal Visual Decision-Making in Image Space
summary: Navigating complex real-world environments requires semantic understanding and adaptive decision-making. Traditional reactive methods without maps often fail in cluttered settings, map-based approaches demand heavy mapping effort, and learning-based solutions rely on large datasets with limited generalization. To address these challenges, we present Pareto-Optimal Visual Navigation, a lightweight image-space framework that combines data-driven semantics, Pareto-optimal decision-making, and visual servoing for real-time navigation.

AI.tldr: A lightweight image-space navigation framework that fuses data-driven semantics, Pareto-optimal decision-making, and visual servoing to navigate real-world clutter without heavy maps or large datasets.
AI.motivation: Current navigation approaches face three core issues: reactive ways without maps fail in cluttered environments; map-based methods require heavy mapping; learning-based methods demand large datasets and often struggle to generalize. The abstract argues for a more efficient, adaptable alternative.
AI.method: Proposes Pareto-Optimal Visual Navigation (POVN): an image-space framework that combines data-driven semantic understanding, Pareto-optimal multi-objective decision-making, and visual servoing to enable real-time navigation.
AI.result: Not specified in the abstract; there are no empirical results or quantitative findings described.
AI.conclusion: The abstract presents a conceptual, lightweight framework and suggests potential improvements in real-time navigation without heavy mapping or large datasets; no conclusions or validation are provided in the abstract.

title: Making LLMs Reliable When It Matters Most: A Five-Layer Architecture for High-Stakes Decisions
summary:
Current large language models (LLMs) excel in verifiable domains where outputs can be checked before action but prove less reliable for high-stakes strategic decisions with uncertain outcomes. This gap, driven by mutually reinforcing cognitive biases in both humans and artificial intelligence (AI) systems, threatens the defensibility of valuations and sustainability of investments in the sector.
  This report describes a framework emerging from systematic qualitative assessment across 7 frontier-grade LLMs and 3 market-facing venture vignettes under time pressure. Detailed prompting specifying decision partnership and explicitly instructing avoidance of sycophancy, confabulation, solution drift, and nihilism achieved initial partnership state but failed to maintain it under operational pressure. Sustaining protective partnership state required an emergent 7-stage calibration sequence, built upon a 4-stage initialization process, within a 5-layer protection architecture enabling bias self-monitoring, human-AI adversarial challenge, partnership state verification, performance degradation detection, and stakeholder protection.
  Three discoveries resulted: partnership state is achievable through ordered calibration but requires emergent maintenance protocols; reliability degrades when architectural drift and context exhaustion align; and dissolution discipline prevents costly pursuit of fundamentally wrong directions. Cross-model validation revealed systematic performance differences across LLM architectures.
  This approach demonstrates that human-AI teams can achieve cognitive partnership capable of preventing avoidable regret in high-stakes decisions, addressing return-on-investment expectations that depend on AI systems supporting consequential decision-making without introducing preventable cognitive traps when verification arrives too late.

AI.tldr: A 7-stage calibration and 5-layer protection framework enabling sustained cognitive partnership in high-stakes AI decisions; initial partnership can be formed but requires emergent maintenance; performance varies across architectures.
AI.motivation: To address cognitive biases and uncertainty that threaten defensible valuations and sustainable investments in AI, ensuring reliable, verifiable decision-making in high-stakes contexts.
AI.method: Qualitative assessment across 7 frontier-grade LLMs and 3 market-facing venture vignettes under time pressure; prompting to specify decision partnership and explicitly avoid sycophancy, confabulation, solution drift, and nihilism; a 4-stage initialization leading to a 7-stage calibration within a 5-layer protection architecture enabling bias self-monitoring, adversarial human-AI challenge, partnership state verification, performance degradation detection, and stakeholder protection.
AI.result: Initial partnership state was achieved but not maintained under operational pressure; sustained partnership requires the emergent 7-stage calibration sequence; reliability degrades when architectural drift and context exhaustion align; dissolution discipline helps avoid pursuing fundamentally wrong directions; cross-model validation reveals systematic performance differences across LLM architectures.
AI.conclusion: Human-AI teams can achieve cognitive partnership capable of preventing avoidable regret in high-stakes decisions and addressing ROI expectations, but require ongoing maintenance protocols and guardrails to prevent cognitive traps when verification arrives too late.

title: Predicting Coronary Artery Calcium Severity based on Non-Contrast Cardiac CT images using Deep Learning
summary: Cardiovascular disease causes high rates of mortality worldwide. Coronary artery calcium (CAC) scoring is a powerful tool to stratify the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Current scoring practices require time-intensive semiautomatic analysis of cardiac computed tomography by radiologists and trained radiographers. The purpose of this study is to develop a deep learning convolutional neural networks (CNN) model to classify the calcium score in cardiac, non-contrast computed tomography images into one of six clinical categories. A total of 68 patient scans were retrospectively obtained together with their respective reported semiautomatic calcium score using an ECG-gated GE Discovery 570 Cardiac SPECT/CT camera. The dataset was divided into training, validation and test sets. Using the semiautomatic CAC score as the reference label, the model demonstrated high performance on a six-class CAC scoring categorisation task. Of the scans analysed, the model misclassified 32 cases, tending towards overestimating the CAC in 26 out of 32 misclassifications. Overall, the model showed high agreement (Cohen's kappa of 0.962), an overall accuracy of 96.5% and high generalisability. The results suggest that the model outputs were accurate and consistent with current semiautomatic practice, with good generalisability to test data. The model demonstrates the viability of a CNN model to stratify the calcium score into an expanded set of six clinical categories.

AI.tldr: A CNN-based approach classifies coronary artery calcium (CAC) scores into six categories on non-contrast cardiac CT, achieving high agreement with semiautomatic scoring (Cohen's kappa 0.962; accuracy 96.5) in a small 68-patient dataset; results suggest viability but require external validation.
AI.motivation: To reduce time and variability in CAC scoring by radiologists, by automating multi-category CAC classification using deep learning.
AI.method: Train a CNN on 68 retrospectively collected ECG-gated non-contrast CT scans with semiautomatic CAC scores as ground truth; dataset split into training/validation/test; multi-class six-category classification; evaluated using Cohen's kappa and accuracy; reported misclassification pattern (overestimation).
AI.result: High performance on six-class CAC scoring; 32 misclassified cases (26 overestimated); overall Cohen's kappa 0.962; accuracy 96.5%; claimed good generalisability to test data.
AI.conclusion: CNN-based CAC classifier can replicate semiautomatic scoring across six clinical categories with high agreement; promising for clinical workflow, but validation on larger, multi-center datasets is needed to confirm generalisability and assess boundary-case misclassifications.

title: N-ReLU: Zero-Mean Stochastic Extension of ReLU
summary: Activation functions are fundamental for enabling nonlinear representations in deep neural networks. However, the standard rectified linear unit (ReLU) often suffers from inactive or "dead" neurons caused by its hard zero cutoff. To address this issue, we introduce N-ReLU (Noise-ReLU), a zero-mean stochastic extension of ReLU that replaces negative activations with Gaussian noise while preserving the same expected output. This expectation-aligned formulation maintains gradient flow in inactive regions and acts as an annealing-style regularizer during training. Experiments on the MNIST dataset using both multilayer perceptron (MLP) and convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures show that N-ReLU achieves accuracy comparable to or slightly exceeding that of ReLU, LeakyReLU, PReLU, GELU, and RReLU at moderate noise levels (sigma = 0.05-0.10), with stable convergence and no dead neurons observed. These results demonstrate that lightweight Gaussian noise injection offers a simple yet effective mechanism to enhance optimization robustness without modifying network structures or introducing additional parameters.

AI.tldr: N-ReLU (Noise-ReLU) is a zero-mean Gaussian-noise extension of ReLU that replaces negative activations with noise while preserving the same expected output. It maintains gradient flow in inactive regions, acts as an annealing-style regularizer, and yields competitive MNIST performance without extra parameters.
AI.motivation: ReLU can produce dead neurons due to its zero cutoff, hindering gradient flow. A small, zero-mean noise injection in the negative region can preserve expected outputs and improve optimization without adding parameters.
AI.method: Modify ReLU so that negative activations are replaced with Gaussian noise drawn from a zero-mean distribution, ensuring the overall expected output matches ReLU. This acts as an annealing-type regularizer. Evaluated on MNIST with MLP and CNN architectures using moderate noise levels (sigma = 0.05–0.10).
AI.result: On MNIST, N-ReLU achieves accuracy comparable to or slightly higher than ReLU, LeakyReLU, PReLU, GELU, and RReLU at moderate noise levels. It shows stable convergence and no dead neurons observed.
AI.conclusion: Lightweight Gaussian noise injection is an effective, parameter-free regularizer that improves optimization robustness without changing network architectures.

title: High-Altitude Balloon Station-Keeping with First Order Model Predictive Control
summary: High-altitude balloons (HABs) are common in scientific research due to their wide range of applications and low cost. Because of their nonlinear, underactuated dynamics and the partial observability of wind fields, prior work has largely relied on model-free reinforcement learning (RL) methods to design near-optimal control schemes for station-keeping. These methods often compare only against hand-crafted heuristics, dismissing model-based approaches as impractical given the system complexity and uncertain wind forecasts. We revisit this assumption about the efficacy of model-based control for station-keeping by developing First-Order Model Predictive Control (FOMPC). By implementing the wind and balloon dynamics as differentiable functions in JAX, we enable gradient-based trajectory optimization for online planning. FOMPC outperforms a state-of-the-art RL policy, achieving a 24% improvement in time-within-radius (TWR) without requiring offline training, though at the cost of greater online computation per control step. Through systematic ablations of modeling assumptions and control factors, we show that online planning is effective across many configurations, including under simplified wind and dynamics models.

AI.tldr: Proposes First-Order Model Predictive Control (FOMPC) for high-altitude balloon station-keeping using differentiable wind and balloon dynamics in JAX; online gradient-based planning outperforms a state-of-the-art RL policy by 24% in time-within-radius, with higher per-step computation but no offline training.
AI.motivation: To challenge the belief that model-based control is impractical for HABs with nonlinear, underactuated dynamics and uncertain winds, and to evaluate gradient-based online planning for station-keeping.
AI.method: Model wind and balloon dynamics as differentiable functions in JAX and perform gradient-based trajectory optimization within a first-order MPC framework for online planning; conduct systematic ablations on modeling assumptions and control factors.
AI.result: FOMPC achieves a 24% improvement in time-within-radius (TWR) over a state-of-the-art RL policy without offline training, though it incurs higher online computation per control step; online planning remains effective across various configurations, including simplified models.
AI.conclusion: Model-based online planning via FOMPC is a viable and effective approach for HAB station-keeping, capable of outperforming RL policies; computational trade-offs are the primary consideration for deployment.

title: AIA Forecaster: Technical Report
summary: This technical report describes the AIA Forecaster, a Large Language Model (LLM)-based system for judgmental forecasting using unstructured data. The AIA Forecaster approach combines three core elements: agentic search over high-quality news sources, a supervisor agent that reconciles disparate forecasts for the same event, and a set of statistical calibration techniques to counter behavioral biases in large language models. On the ForecastBench benchmark (Karger et al., 2024), the AIA Forecaster achieves performance equal to human superforecasters, surpassing prior LLM baselines. In addition to reporting on ForecastBench, we also introduce a more challenging forecasting benchmark sourced from liquid prediction markets. While the AIA Forecaster underperforms market consensus on this benchmark, an ensemble combining AIA Forecaster with market consensus outperforms consensus alone, demonstrating that our forecaster provides additive information. Our work establishes a new state of the art in AI forecasting and provides practical, transferable recommendations for future research. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that verifiably achieves expert-level forecasting at scale.

AI.tldr: AIA Forecaster is an LLM-based forecasting system that uses agentic search, a supervisor to reconcile forecasts, and calibration techniques to achieve human-expert performance on ForecastBench and shows additive value when combined with market consensus, setting new state-of-the-art in AI forecasting.
AI.motivation: Improve judgmental forecasting from unstructured data, mitigate LLM biases, enable expert-level forecasting at scale.
AI.method: Three components: agentic search over high-quality news sources; supervisor agent reconciling divergent forecasts; statistical calibration to counter behavioral biases in LLMs; evaluation on ForecastBench and liquid prediction markets; ensemble with market consensus.
AI.result: On ForecastBench, matches human superforecasters; beats prior LLM baselines; on liquid markets benchmark, ensemble with market consensus outperforms consensus; indicates additive information; claims state-of-the-art, first verifiably expert-level forecasting at scale.
AI.conclusion: Establishes a new state-of-the-art in AI forecasting with practical recommendations for future research.

title: FlowFeat: Pixel-Dense Embedding of Motion Profiles
summary: Dense and versatile image representations underpin the success of virtually all computer vision applications. However, state-of-the-art networks, such as transformers, produce low-resolution feature grids, which are suboptimal for dense prediction tasks. To address this limitation, we present FlowFeat, a high-resolution and multi-task feature representation. The key ingredient behind FlowFeat is a novel distillation technique that embeds a distribution of plausible apparent motions, or motion profiles. By leveraging optical flow networks and diverse video data, we develop an effective self-supervised training framework that statistically approximates the apparent motion. With its remarkable level of spatial detail, FlowFeat encodes a compelling degree of geometric and semantic cues while exhibiting high temporal consistency. Empirically, FlowFeat significantly enhances the representational power of five state-of-the-art encoders and alternative upsampling strategies across three dense tasks: video object segmentation, monocular depth estimation and semantic segmentation. Training FlowFeat is computationally inexpensive and robust to inaccurate flow estimation, remaining highly effective even when using unsupervised flow networks. Our work takes a step forward towards reliable and versatile dense image representations.

AI.tldr: FlowFeat proposes high-resolution, multi-task dense feature representations learned via self-supervised distillation of plausible apparent motions (motion profiles). It improves dense prediction tasks (video object segmentation, monocular depth estimation, semantic segmentation) across multiple encoders and upsampling methods, is computationally inexpensive, and robust to imperfect flow estimates.
AI.motivation: State-of-the-art networks (e.g., transformers) produce low-resolution feature grids that hinder dense prediction tasks. There is a need for dense, high-resolution representations that retain geometric and semantic cues while maintaining temporal consistency.
AI.method: Introduce FlowFeat, a high-resolution feature representation learned through a novel distillation technique that embeds a distribution of plausible apparent motions (motion profiles). Uses optical flow networks and diverse video data to build a self-supervised framework that statistically approximates apparent motion, yielding detailed spatial features with temporal coherence. Compatible with various encoders and upsampling strategies, and robust to inaccurate/unlabeled flow.
AI.result: Empirically improves the representational power of five state-of-the-art encoders and multiple upsampling strategies across three dense tasks: video object segmentation, monocular depth estimation, and semantic segmentation. Training is computationally inexpensive and remains effective even with unsupervised/ imperfect flow networks, offering high spatial detail and strong temporal consistency.
AI.conclusion: FlowFeat advances reliable, versatile dense image representations, enabling improved performance on dense prediction tasks while remaining robust and efficient.

title: SCALAR: Benchmarking SAE Interaction Sparsity in Toy LLMs
summary: Mechanistic interpretability aims to decompose neural networks into interpretable features and map their connecting circuits. The standard approach trains sparse autoencoders (SAEs) on each layer's activations. However, SAEs trained in isolation don't encourage sparse cross-layer connections, inflating extracted circuits where upstream features needlessly affect multiple downstream features. Current evaluations focus on individual SAE performance, leaving interaction sparsity unexamined. We introduce SCALAR (Sparse Connectivity Assessment of Latent Activation Relationships), a benchmark measuring interaction sparsity between SAE features. We also propose "Staircase SAEs", using weight-sharing to limit upstream feature duplication across downstream features. Using SCALAR, we compare TopK SAEs, Jacobian SAEs (JSAEs), and Staircase SAEs. Staircase SAEs improve relative sparsity over TopK SAEs by $59.67\% \pm 1.83\%$ (feedforward) and $63.15\% \pm 1.35\%$ (transformer blocks). JSAEs provide $8.54\% \pm 0.38\%$ improvement over TopK for feedforward layers but cannot train effectively across transformer blocks, unlike Staircase and TopK SAEs which work anywhere in the residual stream. We validate on a $216$K-parameter toy model and GPT-$2$ Small ($124$M), where Staircase SAEs maintain interaction sparsity improvements while preserving feature interpretability. Our work highlights the importance of interaction sparsity in SAEs through benchmarking and comparing promising architectures.

AI.tldr: SCALAR introduces a benchmark to quantify interaction sparsity between sparse autoencoder (SAE) features, and proposes Staircase SAEs with weight-sharing to limit upstream feature duplication. Staircase SAEs achieve substantial gains in cross-layer sparsity over TopK SAEs (≈60% improvements) and can operate across residual streams, unlike JSAEs which only help in feedforward layers and struggle across transformer blocks. Validated on a 216k-parameter toy model and GPT-2 Small, maintaining interpretability while reducing interaction complexity.
AI.motivation: Layer-wise sparse autoencoders do not enforce sparsity of cross-layer connections, leading to inflated, entangled downstream feature influences and reduced interpretability. There is a lack of standardized evaluation for interaction sparsity across layers, hindering progress in mechanistic interpretability.
AI.method: Propose SCALAR, a benchmark to measure interaction sparsity between SAE features. Introduce Staircase SAEs that use weight-sharing to constrain upstream feature duplication across downstream features. Compare TopK SAEs, Jacobian SAEs (JSAEs), and Staircase SAEs across feedforward and transformer blocks, evaluating on a 216k-parameter toy model and GPT-2 Small (124M). Use interaction-sparsity metrics to quantify cross-layer connectivity.
AI.result: Staircase SAEs yield large gains in interaction sparsity relative to TopK SAEs: 59.67% ±1.83% in feedforward and 63.15% ±1.35% in transformer blocks. JSAEs improve feedforward sparsity by 8.54% ±0.38% over TopK but fail to train effectively across transformer blocks. Staircase SAEs and TopK SAEs work anywhere in the residual stream, preserving feature interpretability while reducing unwanted cross-layer dependencies. Validation on a 216k-parameter toy model and GPT-2 Small confirms robustness of the sparsity improvements and interpretability preservation.
AI.conclusion: Interaction sparsity across layers is crucial for robust interpretability of mechanistic models. SCALAR provides a practical benchmark to assess cross-layer sparsity, and Staircase SAEs emerge as a promising architecture to enforce sparse cross-layer connectivity. Further work is needed to understand training stability and generalization across broader architectures and tasks.

title: Benchmarking Resilience and Sensitivity of Polyurethane-Based Vision-Based Tactile Sensors
summary: Vision-based tactile sensors (VBTSs) are a promising technology for robots, providing them with dense signals that can be translated into an understanding of normal and shear load, contact region, texture classification, and more. However, existing VBTS tactile surfaces make use of silicone gels, which provide high sensitivity but easily deteriorate from loading and surface wear. We propose that polyurethane rubber, used for high-load applications like shoe soles, rubber wheels, and industrial gaskets, may provide improved physical gel resilience, potentially at the cost of sensitivity. To compare the resilience and sensitivity of silicone and polyurethane VBTS gels, we propose a series of standard evaluation benchmarking protocols. Our resilience tests assess sensor durability across normal loading, shear loading, and abrasion. For sensitivity, we introduce model-free assessments of force and spatial sensitivity to directly measure the physical capabilities of each gel without effects introduced from data and model quality. Finally, we include a bottle cap loosening and tightening demonstration as an example where polyurethane gels provide an advantage over their silicone counterparts.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a benchmarking framework to compare silicone and polyurethane vision-based tactile sensor gels, focusing on resilience (loading and wear) and sensitivity, and showcases a polyurethane advantage in a bottle-cap task.
AI.motivation: Silicone gels in VBTSs offer high sensitivity but wear/deteriorate under loading; polyurethane gels promise improved resilience for high-load tactile sensing, motivating direct, standardized comparisons.
AI.method: Develop standard evaluation protocols for resilience (normal loading, shear loading, abrasion) and model-free sensitivity assessments; include measurement of force and spatial sensitivity; demonstrate with a bottle-cap loosening/tightening task to illustrate polyurethane benefits.
AI.result: Outlines a benchmarking suite and presents a representative demonstration where polyurethane gels outperform silicone in a practical manipulation task; no full empirical results are provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: A standardized benchmarking framework is needed to fairly compare VBTS gels; polyurethane gels may offer improved resilience under load with potential sensitivity trade-offs, warranting further study.

title: ResearchRubrics: A Benchmark of Prompts and Rubrics For Evaluating Deep Research Agents
summary: Deep Research (DR) is an emerging agent application that leverages large language models (LLMs) to address open-ended queries. It requires the integration of several capabilities, including multi-step reasoning, cross-document synthesis, and the generation of evidence-backed, long-form answers. Evaluating DR remains challenging because responses are lengthy and diverse, admit many valid solutions, and often depend on dynamic information sources. We introduce ResearchRubrics, a standardized benchmark for DR built with over 2,800+ hours of human labor that pairs realistic, domain-diverse prompts with 2,500+ expert-written, fine-grained rubrics to assess factual grounding, reasoning soundness, and clarity. We also propose a new complexity framework for categorizing DR tasks along three axes: conceptual breadth, logical nesting, and exploration. In addition, we develop human and model-based evaluation protocols that measure rubric adherence for DR agents. We evaluate several state-of-the-art DR systems and find that even leading agents like Gemini's DR and OpenAI's DR achieve under 68% average compliance with our rubrics, primarily due to missed implicit context and inadequate reasoning about retrieved information. Our results highlight the need for robust, scalable assessment of deep research capabilities, to which end we release ResearchRubrics(including all prompts, rubrics, and evaluation code) to facilitate progress toward well-justified research assistants.

AI.tldr: Introduces ResearchRubrics, a large-scale benchmark and a three-axis complexity framework for evaluating Deep Research (DR) agents, plus evaluation protocols; finds current DR systems underperform (≤68% rubric compliance) due to missed implicit context and weak reasoning about retrieved information; releases resources to advance trustworthy DR assistants.
AI.motivation: Evaluate open-ended, long-form DR outputs reliably and scalably. DR tasks involve multi-step reasoning, cross-document synthesis, and dynamic sources, which are hard to assess with existing benchmarks or ad-hoc tests.
AI.method: Build ResearchRubrics with 2,500+ expert-written rubrics tied to 2,800+ hours of human labor, paired with diverse prompts. Propose a complexity framework across three axes (conceptual breadth, logical nesting, exploration). Develop human and model-based evaluation protocols to measure rubric adherence. Empirically evaluate state-of-the-art DR systems (e.g., Gemini DR, OpenAI DR).
AI.result: Leading DR systems show under 68% average rubric compliance, largely failing to capture implicit context and to reason about retrieved information. The evaluation reveals gaps in grounding, reasoning, and clarity.
AI.conclusion: Robust, scalable assessment is essential for trustworthy DR. The authors release ResearchRubrics (prompts, rubrics, and evaluation code) to accelerate progress toward well-justified DR agents.

title: Cross Modal Fine-grained Alignment via Granularity-aware and Region-uncertain Modeling
summary: Fine-grained image-text alignment is a pivotal challenge in multimodal learning, underpinning key applications such as visual question answering, image captioning, and vision-language navigation. Unlike global alignment, fine-grained alignment requires precise correspondence between localized visual regions and textual tokens, often hindered by noisy attention mechanisms and oversimplified modeling of cross-modal relationships. In this work, we identify two fundamental limitations of existing approaches: the lack of robust intra-modal mechanisms to assess the significance of visual and textual tokens, leading to poor generalization in complex scenes; and the absence of fine-grained uncertainty modeling, which fails to capture the one-to-many and many-to-one nature of region-word correspondences. To address these issues, we propose a unified approach that incorporates significance-aware and granularity-aware modeling and region-level uncertainty modeling. Our method leverages modality-specific biases to identify salient features without relying on brittle cross-modal attention, and represents region features as a mixture of Gaussian distributions to capture fine-grained uncertainty. Extensive experiments on Flickr30K and MS-COCO demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance across various backbone architectures, significantly enhancing the robustness and interpretability of fine-grained image-text alignment.

AI.tldr: A unified framework for fine-grained image-text alignment using significance-aware intra-modal cues and region-level Gaussian uncertainty to surpass previous cross-modal attention-based methods.
AI.motivation: Fine-grained alignment is hindered by noisy intra-modal signals for visual and textual tokens and by the lack of modeling uncertainty in region-word correspondences, leading to poor generalization and misalignment.
AI.method: Propose significance-aware and granularity-aware intra-modal modeling combined with region-level uncertainty modeling. Use modality-specific biases to identify salient features without relying on brittle cross-modal attention. Represent region features as a mixture of Gaussians to capture fine-grained uncertainty and one-to-many/many-to-one mappings, trained under a unified alignment objective across modalities.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on Flickr30K and MS-COCO across various backbone architectures, with improved robustness and interpretability of fine-grained alignments.
AI.conclusion: Significance- and granularity-aware intra-modal cues plus region-level uncertainty modeling yield robust, interpretable fine-grained image-text alignment that generalizes across backbones.

title: LLM Output Drift: Cross-Provider Validation & Mitigation for Financial Workflows
comment: 11 pages, 5 figures. To appear in AI4F @ ACM ICAIF '25, November 15-18, 2025, Singapore
summary:
Financial institutions deploy Large Language Models (LLMs) for reconciliations, regulatory reporting, and client communications, but nondeterministic outputs (output drift) undermine auditability and trust. We quantify drift across five model architectures (7B-120B parameters) on regulated financial tasks, revealing a stark inverse relationship: smaller models (Granite-3-8B, Qwen2.5-7B) achieve 100% output consistency at T=0.0, while GPT-OSS-120B exhibits only 12.5% consistency (95% CI: 3.5-36.0%) regardless of configuration (p<0.0001, Fisher's exact test). This finding challenges conventional assumptions that larger models are universally superior for production deployment.
  Our contributions include: (i) a finance-calibrated deterministic test harness combining greedy decoding (T=0.0), fixed seeds, and SEC 10-K structure-aware retrieval ordering; (ii) task-specific invariant checking for RAG, JSON, and SQL outputs using finance-calibrated materiality thresholds (plus or minus 5%) and SEC citation validation; (iii) a three-tier model classification system enabling risk-appropriate deployment decisions; and (iv) an audit-ready attestation system with dual-provider validation.
  We evaluated five models (Qwen2.5-7B via Ollama, Granite-3-8B via IBM watsonx.ai, Llama-3.3-70B, Mistral-Medium-2505, and GPT-OSS-120B) across three regulated financial tasks. Across 480 runs (n=16 per condition), structured tasks (SQL) remain stable even at T=0.2, while RAG tasks show drift (25-75%), revealing task-dependent sensitivity. Cross-provider validation confirms deterministic behavior transfers between local and cloud deployments. We map our framework to Financial Stability Board (FSB), Bank for International Settlements (BIS), and Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) requirements, demonstrating practical pathways for compliance-ready AI deployments.

AI.tldr: Smaller finance-calibrated LLMs exhibit deterministic outputs under a fully deterministic test harness, while a large 120B model shows low consistency; this challenges the belief that bigger models are always better for production in regulated finance.
AI.motivation: In regulated finance, auditability and trust are critical. Nondeterministic outputs (output drift) undermine auditability of reconciliations, regulatory reporting, and client communications. The paper seeks to quantify drift across architectures to enable governance and compliant deployment.
AI.method: Evaluated five models (Qwen2.5-7B via Ollama; Granite-3-8B via IBM watsonx.ai; Llama-3.3-70B; Mistral-Medium-2505; GPT-OSS-120B) across three regulated financial tasks with 480 runs (n=16 per condition). Built a finance-calibrated deterministic test harness using greedy decoding (T=0.0), fixed seeds, and SEC 10-K structure-aware retrieval ordering. Implemented task-specific invariant checks for RAG, JSON, and SQL outputs using finance-calibrated materiality thresholds (±5%) and SEC citation validation. Introduced a three-tier model classification system for risk-appropriate deployment and an audit-ready attestation system with dual-provider validation. Cross-provider validation tested deterministic behavior transfer between local and cloud deployments and mapped the framework to FSB, BIS, and CFTC requirements for compliance-ready AI deployments.
AI.result: An inverse relationship between model size and output consistency emerged. Smaller models Granite-3-8B and Qwen2.5-7B achieved 100% output consistency at T=0.0, while GPT-OSS-120B achieved only 12.5% consistency (95% CI: 3.5–36.0%), p<0.0001. Across 480 runs, structured SQL tasks remained stable even at T=0.2, while RAG tasks showed drift in the 25–75% range, indicating task-dependent sensitivity. Cross-provider validation confirmed that deterministic behavior transfers between local and cloud deployments. The study aligns the framework with FSB, BIS, and CFTC requirements to enable compliance-ready AI deployments.
AI.conclusion: The findings challenge the assumption that larger models are universally superior for production in regulated finance. The authors present a practical framework—deterministic test harness, invariant checks, risk-tier classification, and audit attestations—to support governance and compliant deployment of AI in financial settings.

title: Virtual Traffic Lights for Multi-Robot Navigation: Decentralized Planning with Centralized Conflict Resolution
summary: We present a hybrid multi-robot coordination framework that combines decentralized path planning with centralized conflict resolution. In our approach, each robot autonomously plans its path and shares this information with a centralized node. The centralized system detects potential conflicts and allows only one of the conflicting robots to proceed at a time, instructing others to stop outside the conflicting area to avoid deadlocks. Unlike traditional centralized planning methods, our system does not dictate robot paths but instead provides stop commands, functioning as a virtual traffic light. In simulation experiments with multiple robots, our approach increased the success rate of robots reaching their goals while reducing deadlocks. Furthermore, we successfully validated the system in real-world experiments with two quadruped robots and separately with wheeled Duckiebots.

AI.tldr: A decentralized path-planning with centralized stop-command coordination acts as a virtual traffic light to reduce deadlocks and improve success in multi-robot systems; validated in simulation and real robots (quadrupeds and Duckiebots).
AI.motivation: Need for scalable coordination that preserves autonomous planning while preventing conflicts and deadlocks in multi-robot teams.
AI.method: Each robot plans locally and shares plan with a central coordinator; the central detects potential conflicts and issues stop commands to one or more robots to avoid deadlocks, rather than dictating full paths; acts as virtual traffic light.
AI.result: Simulation: increased success rate at reaching goals and reduced deadlocks. Real-world: validated on two quadruped robots and on wheeled Duckiebots.
AI.conclusion: Hybrid approach effectively balances autonomy and coordination, reducing deadlocks without rigid path planning, and demonstrates feasibility across different platforms.

title: Towards AI-Assisted Generation of Military Training Scenarios
summary: Achieving expert-level performance in simulation-based training relies on the creation of complex, adaptable scenarios, a traditionally laborious and resource intensive process. Although prior research explored scenario generation for military training, pre-LLM AI tools struggled to generate sufficiently complex or adaptable scenarios. This paper introduces a multi-agent, multi-modal reasoning framework that leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate critical training artifacts, such as Operations Orders (OPORDs). We structure our framework by decomposing scenario generation into a hierarchy of subproblems, and for each one, defining the role of the AI tool: (1) generating options for a human author to select from, (2) producing a candidate product for human approval or modification, or (3) generating textual artifacts fully automatically. Our framework employs specialized LLM-based agents to address distinct subproblems. Each agent receives input from preceding subproblem agents, integrating both text-based scenario details and visual information (e.g., map features, unit positions and applies specialized reasoning to produce appropriate outputs. Subsequent agents process these outputs sequentially, preserving logical consistency and ensuring accurate document generation. This multi-agent strategy overcomes the limitations of basic prompting or single-agent approaches when tackling such highly complex tasks. We validate our framework through a proof-of-concept that generates the scheme of maneuver and movement section of an OPORD while estimating map positions and movements as a precursor demonstrating its feasibility and accuracy. Our results demonstrate the potential of LLM-driven multi-agent systems to generate coherent, nuanced documents and adapt dynamically to changing conditions, advancing automation in scenario generation for military training.

AI.tldr: Proposes a multi-agent LLM framework to automatically generate scenario content (OPORDs) for military training by decomposing tasks into subproblems with specialized AI roles, validated via a proof-of-concept for scheme of maneuver and movement with map estimation; shows potential for coherent, adaptive, automated scenario generation.
AI.motivation: To reduce the labor and resource intensity of creating complex, adaptable training scenarios and to surpass the limitations of prior pre-LLM tools that could not handle complexity.
AI.method: Decompose scenario generation into a hierarchy of subproblems. Assign AI roles per subproblem: (1) provide options for human author, (2) produce candidate product for human approval/modification, (3) generate artifacts automatically. Use specialized LLM-based agents that take input from previous agents and integrate text and visual data (maps, unit positions). Process outputs sequentially to preserve logical consistency and document accuracy. Validate with a proof-of-concept generating the scheme of maneuver and movement sections of an OPORD, including map position/movement estimation.
AI.result: Demonstrates the feasibility and potential of LLM-driven multi-agent systems to produce coherent, nuanced, adaptive scenario documents for military training, with maintained logical consistency across steps and the ability to incorporate visual data.
AI.conclusion: LLM-driven multi-agent frameworks can enhance automation and adaptability in scenario generation, addressing the limitations of single-agent prompting and enabling more complex, dynamic training scenarios.

title: UltraGS: Gaussian Splatting for Ultrasound Novel View Synthesis
summary: Ultrasound imaging is a cornerstone of non-invasive clinical diagnostics, yet its limited field of view complicates novel view synthesis. We propose \textbf{UltraGS}, a Gaussian Splatting framework optimized for ultrasound imaging. First, we introduce a depth-aware Gaussian splatting strategy, where each Gaussian is assigned a learnable field of view, enabling accurate depth prediction and precise structural representation. Second, we design SH-DARS, a lightweight rendering function combining low-order spherical harmonics with ultrasound-specific wave physics, including depth attenuation, reflection, and scattering, to model tissue intensity accurately. Third, we contribute the Clinical Ultrasound Examination Dataset, a benchmark capturing diverse anatomical scans under real-world clinical protocols. Extensive experiments on three datasets demonstrate UltraGS's superiority, achieving state-of-the-art results in PSNR (up to 29.55), SSIM (up to 0.89), and MSE (as low as 0.002) while enabling real-time synthesis at 64.69 fps. The code and dataset are open-sourced at: https://github.com/Bean-Young/UltraGS.

AI.tldr: UltraGS introduces a Gaussian splatting framework tailored for ultrasound, with depth-aware Gaussians, a light SH-based renderer (SH-DARS) that incorporates ultrasound physics, and a Clinical Ultrasound Examination Dataset. It achieves state-of-the-art PSNR/SSIM and real-time synthesis, and is open-sourced.
AI.motivation: Ultrasound's limited field of view and complex wave-tissue interactions hinder novel view synthesis and accurate rendering. A depth-aware, physics-informed representation and a dedicated dataset can enable high-fidelity, real-time ultrasound synthesis.
AI.method: 1) depth-aware Gaussian splatting where each Gaussian has a learnable field of view for accurate depth and structure; 2) SH-DARS rendering combining low-order spherical harmonics with ultrasound-specific depth attenuation, reflection, and scattering; 3) a Clinical Ultrasound Examination Dataset for benchmarking; training and evaluation on three datasets.
AI.result: State-of-the-art metrics on PSNR (up to 29.55), SSIM (up to 0.89), MSE as low as 0.002, and real-time synthesis at 64.69 fps; code and dataset released at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: UltraGS meaningfully advances ultrasound novel-view synthesis by integrating depth-aware Gaussian splatting and a physics-informed renderer, supported by a new clinical dataset and open-source release, enabling accurate, fast ultrasound rendering.

title: One Router to Route Them All: Homogeneous Expert Routing for Heterogeneous Graph Transformers
comment: 14 pages, 4 figures; 2 tables; work in progress, feedback welcome
summary: A common practice in heterogeneous graph neural networks (HGNNs) is to condition parameters on node/edge types, assuming types reflect semantic roles. However, this can cause overreliance on surface-level labels and impede cross-type knowledge transfer. We explore integrating Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) into HGNNs--a direction underexplored despite MoE's success in homogeneous settings. Crucially, we question the need for type-specific experts. We propose Homogeneous Expert Routing (HER), an MoE layer for Heterogeneous Graph Transformers (HGT) that stochastically masks type embeddings during routing to encourage type-agnostic specialization. Evaluated on IMDB, ACM, and DBLP for link prediction, HER consistently outperforms standard HGT and a type-separated MoE baseline. Analysis on IMDB shows HER experts specialize by semantic patterns (e.g., movie genres) rather than node types, confirming routing is driven by latent semantics. Our work demonstrates that regularizing type dependence in expert routing yields more generalizable, efficient, and interpretable representations--a new design principle for heterogeneous graph learning.

AI.tldr: Proposes Homogeneous Expert Routing (HER): an MoE layer for Heterogeneous Graph Transformers that masks type embeddings to foster type-agnostic routing. It improves link prediction across datasets and shows experts organize by latent semantics rather than explicit types.
AI.motivation: HGNNs often depend on surface-type labels, limiting cross-type knowledge transfer and generalization. MoE has excelled in homogeneous graphs, but its role in HGNNs is underexplored. Questioning the necessity of type-specific experts could unlock more generalizable representations.
AI.method: Integrate an MoE layer (HER) into Heterogeneous Graph Transformer (HGT). During routing, apply stochastic masking of type embeddings to reduce reliance on explicit types and encourage latent-semantics-based specialization. Compare against standard HGT and a type-separated MoE baseline on IMDB, ACM, and DBLP for link prediction.
AI.result: HER consistently outperforms both standard HGT and a type-separated MoE baseline across the three datasets for link prediction. Analysis on IMDB shows HER experts specialize by semantic patterns (e.g., movie genres) rather than node types, indicating routing is driven by latent semantics.
AI.conclusion: Regularizing dependence on node/edge types in MoE routing yields more generalizable, efficient, and interpretable representations. This supports a new design principle for heterogeneous graph learning: favor latent-semantics-driven routing over strict type-specific specialization.

title: SONIC: Supersizing Motion Tracking for Natural Humanoid Whole-Body Control
summary: Despite the rise of billion-parameter foundation models trained across thousands of GPUs, similar scaling gains have not been shown for humanoid control. Current neural controllers for humanoids remain modest in size, target a limited behavior set, and are trained on a handful of GPUs over several days. We show that scaling up model capacity, data, and compute yields a generalist humanoid controller capable of creating natural and robust whole-body movements. Specifically, we posit motion tracking as a natural and scalable task for humanoid control, leverageing dense supervision from diverse motion-capture data to acquire human motion priors without manual reward engineering. We build a foundation model for motion tracking by scaling along three axes: network size (from 1.2M to 42M parameters), dataset volume (over 100M frames, 700 hours of high-quality motion data), and compute (9k GPU hours). Beyond demonstrating the benefits of scale, we show the practical utility of our model through two mechanisms: (1) a real-time universal kinematic planner that bridges motion tracking to downstream task execution, enabling natural and interactive control, and (2) a unified token space that supports various motion input interfaces, such as VR teleoperation devices, human videos, and vision-language-action (VLA) models, all using the same policy. Scaling motion tracking exhibits favorable properties: performance improves steadily with increased compute and data diversity, and learned representations generalize to unseen motions, establishing motion tracking at scale as a practical foundation for humanoid control.

AI.tldr: A scalable foundation-model approach to humanoid motion tracking that uses large-scale data, model capacity, and compute to produce a generalist humanoid controller with a real-time planner and a unified motion-token interface.
AI.motivation: Current humanoid controllers are small, specialized, and trained with limited data and compute. The authors hypothesize that scaling data, model size, and compute for a motion-tracking objective can yield a generalist controller capable of natural, robust whole-body movements and broad input modalities without heavy reward engineering.
AI.method: Scale a motion-tracking model along three axes (size: 1.2M→42M parameters; data: 100M+ frames, 700 hours of high-quality motion data; compute: ~9k GPU-hours). Train with dense supervision from motion capture to learn human motion priors. Develop a real-time universal kinematic planner to map tracking to task execution and a unified token space to support diverse input interfaces (VR devices, human videos, and vision-language-action models) using the same policy.
AI.result: Performance scales with data diversity and compute; representations generalize to unseen motions; practical utilities include a real-time planner for natural control and a unified motion-token interface enabling multiple input modalities, establishing motion tracking at scale as a viable foundation for humanoid control.
AI.conclusion: Motion tracking at scale can serve as a practical foundation for humanoid control, with scalable data, model, and compute yielding a generalist controller and versatile input interfaces that enable natural, interactive whole-body motion.

title: Operational machine learning for remote spectroscopic detection of CH$_{4}$ point sources
summary: Mitigating anthropogenic methane sources is one the most cost-effective levers to slow down global warming. While satellite-based imaging spectrometers, such as EMIT, PRISMA, and EnMAP, can detect these point sources, current methane retrieval methods based on matched filters still produce a high number of false detections requiring laborious manual verification. This paper describes the operational deployment of a machine learning system for detecting methane emissions within the Methane Alert and Response System (MARS) of the United Nations Environment Programme's International Methane Emissions Observatory. We created the largest and most diverse global dataset of annotated methane plumes from three imaging spectrometer missions and quantitatively compared different deep learning model configurations. Focusing on the requirements for operational deployment, we extended prior evaluation methodologies from small tiled datasets to full granule evaluation. This revealed that deep learning models still produce a large number of false detections, a problem we address with model ensembling, which reduced false detections by over 74%. Deployed in the MARS pipeline, our system processes scenes and proposes plumes to analysts, accelerating the detection and analysis process. During seven months of operational deployment, it facilitated the verification of 1,351 distinct methane leaks, resulting in 479 stakeholder notifications. We further demonstrate the model's utility in verifying mitigation success through case studies in Libya, Argentina, Oman, and Azerbaijan. Our work represents a critical step towards a global AI-assisted methane leak detection system, which is required to process the dramatically higher data volumes expected from new and current imaging spectrometers.

AI.tldr: Operational deep-learning pipeline with ensembling substantially reduces false methane plume detections and accelerates verification, enabling widespread use in MARS with thousands of verified leaks and stakeholder notifications.
AI.motivation: Mitigate the high false-positive rate of current methane plume detections from imaging spectrometers and scale detection to the growing data volumes from satellite missions, supporting timely mitigation actions.
AI.method: Created a large, diverse, globally sourced annotated methane plume dataset from three imaging spectrometer missions; compared multiple deep learning model configurations; extended evaluation from tiled datasets to full granule evaluation; used model ensembling to reduce false positives; deployed within the MARS pipeline to propose plumes to analysts.
AI.result: False detections reduced by over 74% through model ensembling; seven months of deployment verified 1,351 leaks and generated 479 stakeholder notifications; demonstrated utility via mitigation-case studies in Libya, Argentina, Oman, and Azerbaijan.
AI.conclusion: A critical step toward a global AI-assisted methane leak detection system, showing operational viability and scalability to accommodate higher data volumes from current and future imaging spectrometers.

title: VectorSynth: Fine-Grained Satellite Image Synthesis with Structured Semantics
summary: We introduce VectorSynth, a diffusion-based framework for pixel-accurate satellite image synthesis conditioned on polygonal geographic annotations with semantic attributes. Unlike prior text- or layout-conditioned models, VectorSynth learns dense cross-modal correspondences that align imagery and semantic vector geometry, enabling fine-grained, spatially grounded edits. A vision language alignment module produces pixel-level embeddings from polygon semantics; these embeddings guide a conditional image generation framework to respect both spatial extents and semantic cues. VectorSynth supports interactive workflows that mix language prompts with geometry-aware conditioning, allowing rapid what-if simulations, spatial edits, and map-informed content generation. For training and evaluation, we assemble a collection of satellite scenes paired with pixel-registered polygon annotations spanning diverse urban scenes with both built and natural features. We observe strong improvements over prior methods in semantic fidelity and structural realism, and show that our trained vision language model demonstrates fine-grained spatial grounding. The code and data are available at https://github.com/mvrl/VectorSynth.

AI.tldr: VectorSynth is a diffusion-based satellite image synthesis framework conditioned on polygonal geographic annotations, enabling pixel-accurate generation and geometry-aware edits for interactive, map-informed workflows.
AI.motivation: Existing text- or layout-conditioned generative models lack dense cross-modal alignment with vector geographic geometry, limiting pixel-level fidelity and precise spatial edits in satellite imagery.
AI.method: A diffusion-based generator with a vision-language alignment module that converts polygon semantics into pixel-level embeddings, which guide conditional image synthesis to respect spatial extents and semantic cues. Supports interactive workflows mixing language prompts with geometry conditioning for what-if simulations. Trains on satellite scenes paired with pixel-registered polygon annotations.
AI.result: Outperforms prior methods in semantic fidelity and structural realism; demonstrates fine-grained spatial grounding of the vision-language model; code and data released for reproduction.
AI.conclusion: Shows the viability of dense cross-modal alignment between vector geometry and satellite imagery, enabling rapid what-if simulations, spatial edits, and map-informed content generation.

title: Partial Action Replacement: Tackling Distribution Shift in Offline MARL
summary: Offline multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is severely hampered by the challenge of evaluating out-of-distribution (OOD) joint actions. Our core finding is that when the behavior policy is factorized - a common scenario where agents act fully or partially independently during data collection - a strategy of partial action replacement (PAR) can significantly mitigate this challenge. PAR updates a single or part of agents' actions while the others remain fixed to the behavioral data, reducing distribution shift compared to full joint-action updates. Based on this insight, we develop Soft-Partial Conservative Q-Learning (SPaCQL), using PAR to mitigate OOD issue and dynamically weighting different PAR strategies based on the uncertainty of value estimation. We provide a rigorous theoretical foundation for this approach, proving that under factorized behavior policies, the induced distribution shift scales linearly with the number of deviating agents rather than exponentially with the joint-action space. This yields a provably tighter value error bound for this important class of offline MARL problems. Our theoretical results also indicate that SPaCQL adaptively addresses distribution shift using uncertainty-informed weights. Our empirical results demonstrate SPaCQL enables more effective policy learning, and manifest its remarkable superiority over baseline algorithms when the offline dataset exhibits the independence structure.

AI.tldr: PAR-based SPaCQL reduces OOD issues in offline MARL with factorized policies by updating partial action subsets; theoretical analysis shows distribution shift scales linearly with the number of deviating agents, yielding tighter value error bounds; empirically superior when the offline data exhibit independence structures.
AI.motivation: Offline MARL struggles to evaluate out-of-distribution joint actions. When behavior policies factorize, agents act independently in data collection. A method that mitigates distribution shift by changing only a subset of actions should improve offline value estimation and policy learning.
AI.method: Introduce Partial Action Replacement (PAR) to update one or a subset of agents' actions while keeping others fixed to the behavior data. Build Soft-Partial Conservative Q-Learning (SPaCQL) that uses PAR with adaptive, uncertainty-informed weighting across different PAR strategies. Provide theoretical guarantees showing linear (not exponential) scaling of distribution shift with the number of deviating agents under factorized policies and derive tighter value error bounds. Complement theory with empirical validation in offline MARL settings with independence structure.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis demonstrates that, under factorized behavior policies, the induced distribution shift scales linearly with the number of deviating agents, yielding a provably tighter value error bound. SPaCQL adaptively addresses distribution shift using uncertainty-informed weights. Empirically, SPaCQL achieves more effective policy learning and demonstrates strong performance advantages over baselines when the offline dataset exhibits independence structure.
AI.conclusion: SPaCQL provides a principled approach for offline MARL by leveraging factorized behavior policies and partial action updates. The method yields tighter error bounds and improved empirical performance in datasets with independence structure, due to adaptive, uncertainty-informed weighting of PAR strategies.

title: Occlusion-Aware Ground Target Search by a UAV in an Urban Environment
summary: This paper considers the problem of searching for a point of interest (POI) moving along an urban road network with an uncrewed aerial vehicle (UAV). The UAV is modeled as a variable-speed Dubins vehicle with a line-of-sight sensor in an urban environment that may occlude the sensor's view of the POI. A search strategy is proposed that exploits a probabilistic visibility volume (VV) to plan its future motion with iterative deepening $A^\ast$. The probabilistic VV is a time-varying three-dimensional representation of the sensing constraints for a particular distribution of the POI's state. To find the path most likely to view the POI, the planner uses a heuristic to optimistically estimate the probability of viewing the POI over a time horizon. The probabilistic VV is max-pooled to create a variable-timestep planner that reduces the search space and balances long-term and short-term planning. The proposed path planning method is compared to prior work with a Monte-Carlo simulation and is shown to outperform the baseline methods in cluttered environments when the UAV's sensor has a higher false alarm probability.

AI.tldr: A probabilistic visibility-volume (VV) based planner for a variable-speed Dubins UAV that searches for a moving POI on an urban road network, using iterative deepening A* with a time-varying 3D VV to account for occlusions and sensor noise; it outperforms Monte-Carlo baselines in cluttered environments with higher false alarms.
AI.motivation: To enable robust, efficient search for a moving POI in urban environments where line-of-sight is frequently occluded and sensor measurements include false alarms, necessitating planning under uncertain, time-varying visibility.
AI.method: Introduce a probabilistic visibility volume (VV) as a time-varying 3D representation of sensing constraints for a POI distribution; plan with iterative deepening A* (IDA*) using a heuristic that optimisticly estimates viewing probability over a horizon; max-pool the probabilistic VV to create a variable-timestep planner that reduces search space and balances long-/short-term planning.
AI.result: Monte-Carlo simulations show that the VV-based planner outperforms baseline methods in cluttered environments, particularly when the sensor false alarm probability is high.
AI.conclusion: The probabilistic VV approach improves the chance of viewing the moving POI by reducing search space, balancing planning horizons, and providing robustness to occlusion and sensor noise, outperforming prior work.

title: Alignment-Aware Quantization for LLM Safety
comment: 9 pages, 3 figures. Includes 7 pages of supplementary material
summary: Safety and efficiency are both important factors when deploying large language models(LLMs). LLMs are trained to follow human alignment for safety, and post training quantization(PTQ) is applied afterward for efficiency. However, these two objectives are often in conflict, revealing a fundamental flaw in the conventional PTQ paradigm: quantization can turn into a safety vulnerability if it only aims to achieve low perplexity. Models can demonstrate low perplexity yet exhibit significant degradation in alignment with the safety policy, highlighting that perplexity alone is an insufficient and often misleading proxy for model safety. To address this, we propose Alignment-Aware Quantization(AAQ), a novel approach that integrates Alignment-Preserving Contrastive(APC) loss into the PTQ pipeline.
