Compared to simple reconstruction loss, ours explicitly preserves alignment by encouraging the quantized model to mimic its safe, instruction-tuned model while diverging from the unaligned, pre-trained counterpart. Our method achieves this robust safety alignment without resorting to specialized safety-focused calibration datasets, highlighting its practical utility and broad applicability. AAQ is compatible with standard PTQ techniques and enables robust 4-bit (W4A4) quantization across diverse model families such as LLaMA, Qwen, and Mistral while maintaining safety where previous methods fail. Our work resolves the critical trade-off between efficiency and safety, paving the way toward LLMs that are both efficient and trustworthy. Anonymized code is available in the supplementary material.

AI.tldr: Alignment-aware quantization (AAQ) adds Alignment-Preserving Contrastive (APC) loss to PTQ to maintain safety alignment during quantization, achieving robust 4-bit W4A4 quantization across LLaMA, Qwen, and Mistral without specialized safety datasets.
AI.motivation: Perplexity is not a reliable proxy for model safety; conventional PTQ can degrade alignment even if perplexity remains low, creating a safety vulnerability in efficient models.
AI.method: Introduce Alignment-Preserving Contrastive loss that steers the quantized model to mimic the safe, instruction-tuned model while diverging from the unaligned pre-trained model, integrating with standard PTQ pipelines without requiring safety-focused calibration data.
AI.result: Demonstrates robust safety alignment at 4-bit quantization (W4A4) across multiple model families; maintains safety where previous methods fail; compatible with standard PTQ techniques.
AI.conclusion: Aligning quantization with safety objectives resolves the efficiency-safety trade-off, enabling trustworthy, efficient LLM deployment without specialized safety datasets; code anonymized in supplementary material.

title: Auto-US: An Ultrasound Video Diagnosis Agent Using Video Classification Framework and LLMs
summary: AI-assisted ultrasound video diagnosis presents new opportunities to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of medical imaging analysis. However, existing research remains limited in terms of dataset diversity, diagnostic performance, and clinical applicability. In this study, we propose \textbf{Auto-US}, an intelligent diagnosis agent that integrates ultrasound video data with clinical diagnostic text. To support this, we constructed \textbf{CUV Dataset} of 495 ultrasound videos spanning five categories and three organs, aggregated from multiple open-access sources. We developed \textbf{CTU-Net}, which achieves state-of-the-art performance in ultrasound video classification, reaching an accuracy of 86.73\% Furthermore, by incorporating large language models, Auto-US is capable of generating clinically meaningful diagnostic suggestions. The final diagnostic scores for each case exceeded 3 out of 5 and were validated by professional clinicians. These results demonstrate the effectiveness and clinical potential of Auto-US in real-world ultrasound applications. Code and data are available at: https://github.com/Bean-Young/Auto-US.

AI.tldr: Auto-US combines ultrasound video with clinical text to classify ultrasound videos (CTU-Net) on the CUV dataset; shows diagnostic potential with LLM-assisted suggestions; 495 videos across 5 categories and 3 organs; 86.73% video classification accuracy; clinician-validated scores >3/5; code and data available.
AI.motivation: Address limited dataset diversity, diagnostic performance, and clinical applicability in AI-assisted ultrasound analysis; improve efficiency and accuracy by integrating multimodal data and clinician feedback.
AI.method: Construct CUV Dataset (495 videos, 5 categories, 3 organs) from open sources; develop CTU-Net for ultrasound video classification achieving state-of-the-art performance (86.73%); integrate large language models to generate diagnostic suggestions; validate scores with professional clinicians; provide code/data.
AI.result: CTU-Net achieves 86.73% accuracy; diagnostic scores for each case exceed 3/5; clinicians validate; data/code available.
AI.conclusion: Auto-US demonstrates feasibility and clinical potential of AI-assisted ultrasound diagnosis, with promising directions for multimodal integration and multi-center validation.

title: FlowTIE: Flow-based Transport of Intensity Equation for Phase Gradient Estimation from 4D-STEM Data
comment: 7 pages, 3 figures, Machine Learning and the Physical Sciences Workshop, NeurIPS 2025
summary: We introduce FlowTIE, a neural-network-based framework for phase reconstruction from 4D-Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) data, which integrates the Transport of Intensity Equation (TIE) with a flow-based representation of the phase gradient. This formulation allows the model to bridge data-driven learning with physics-based priors, improving robustness under dynamical scattering conditions for thick specimen. The validation on simulated datasets of crystalline materials, benchmarking to classical TIE and gradient-based optimization methods are presented. The results demonstrate that FlowTIE improves phase reconstruction accuracy, fast, and can be integrated with a thick specimen model, namely multislice method.

AI.tldr: FlowTIE is a neural-physics hybrid for 4D-STEM phase recovery that merges Transport of Intensity Equation with a flow-based phase-gradient model, achieving faster, more accurate reconstructions in thick, dynamical-scattering specimens and compatible with multislice simulations.
AI.motivation: Phase retrieval from 4D-STEM suffers under dynamical scattering in thick samples; combining data-driven learning with physics priors can improve robustness and accuracy.
AI.method: A neural network implements a flow-based representation of the phase gradient and enforces the TIE relation. Trained on simulated crystalline data, the model is benchmarked against classical TIE and gradient-based optimization, and can incorporate a multislice thick-specimen model.
AI.result: FlowTIE achieves higher phase-reconstruction accuracy with faster convergence than baselines, and remains robust under dynamical scattering; compatible with multislice thick-specimen modeling.
AI.conclusion: FlowTIE demonstrates the value of physics-informed neural networks for 4D-STEM phase retrieval, combining data-driven learning with a solid physical prior to handle thick specimens and realistic imaging conditions.

title: A Comprehensive Experimental Characterization of Mechanical Layer Jamming Systems
summary: Organisms in nature, such as Cephalopods and Pachyderms, exploit stiffness modulation to achieve amazing dexterity in the control of their appendages. In this paper, we explore the phenomenon of layer jamming, which is a popular stiffness modulation mechanism that provides an equivalent capability for soft robots. More specifically, we focus on mechanical layer jamming, which we realise through two-layer multi material structure with tooth-like protrusions. We identify key design parameters for mechanical layer jamming systems, including the ability to modulate stiffness, and perform a variety of comprehensive tests placing the specimens under bending and torsional loads to understand the influence of our selected design parameters (mainly tooth geometry) on the performance of the jammed structures. We note the ability of these structures to produce a peak change in stiffness of 5 times in bending and 3.2 times in torsion. We also measure the force required to separate the two jammed layers, an often ignored parameter in the study of jamming-induced stiffness change. This study aims to shed light on the principled design of mechanical layer jammed systems and guide researchers in the selection of appropriate designs for their specific application domains.

AI.tldr: Two-layer mechanical layer-jamming system with tooth-like interlocks shows tunable stiffness via tooth geometry; achieves up to 5x stiffness increase in bending and 3.2x in torsion; includes inter-layer separation force measurement; provides design guidelines for mechanical layer jamming.
AI.motivation: Layer jamming is a stiffness modulation strategy inspired by natural systems and relevant for soft robotics. Mechanical layer jamming remains less explored; this work aims to identify design parameters (notably tooth geometry) and quantify performance under bending and torsion to guide design choices.
AI.method: Fabricate a two-layer multi-material structure with tooth-like protrusions. Systematically vary tooth geometry to study its influence. Conduct bending and torsional tests to measure stiffness changes. Additionally measure the force required to separate the jammed layers.
AI.result: The system achieves up to 5x stiffness change in bending and 3.2x in torsion. The separation force between the jammed layers is quantified. The tooth geometry is identified as a key parameter influencing performance.
AI.conclusion: Provides principled design guidance for mechanical layer jammed systems and helps researchers select design parameters for specific applications; highlights the importance of tooth geometry and includes a metric (separation force) often neglected in jamming studies.

title: GAMA: A Neural Neighborhood Search Method with Graph-aware Multi-modal Attention for Vehicle Routing Problem
summary: Recent advances in neural neighborhood search methods have shown potential in tackling Vehicle Routing Problems (VRPs). However, most existing approaches rely on simplistic state representations and fuse heterogeneous information via naive concatenation, limiting their ability to capture rich structural and semantic context. To address these limitations, we propose GAMA, a neural neighborhood search method with Graph-aware Multi-modal Attention model in VRP. GAMA encodes the problem instance and its evolving solution as distinct modalities using graph neural networks, and models their intra- and inter-modal interactions through stacked self- and cross-attention layers. A gated fusion mechanism further integrates the multi-modal representations into a structured state, enabling the policy to make informed and generalizable operator selection decisions. Extensive experiments conducted across various synthetic and benchmark instances demonstrate that the proposed algorithm GAMA significantly outperforms the recent neural baselines. Further ablation studies confirm that both the multi-modal attention mechanism and the gated fusion design play a key role in achieving the observed performance gains.

AI.tldr: GAMA introduces a graph-aware multi-modal attention framework with gated fusion for VRP, yielding strong improvements over neural baselines.
AI.motivation: Neural VRP methods often use simplistic state representations and naive feature fusion, failing to capture rich structural and semantic context in VRP instances and solutions.
AI.method: GAMA encodes the problem instance and its evolving solution as separate graph-based modalities; uses stacked self- and cross-attention to model intra- and inter-modal interactions; applies a gated fusion mechanism to create a structured state for policy-driven operator selection.
AI.result: Across synthetic and benchmark VRP instances, GAMA significantly outperforms recent neural baselines; ablations show the multi-modal attention and gated fusion components are critical to performance gains.
AI.conclusion: Multi-modal graph-aware attention with gated fusion effectively encodes and integrates VRP state and solution context, enabling informed and generalizable operator selection in neural VRP frameworks.

title: Class Incremental Medical Image Segmentation via Prototype-Guided Calibration and Dual-Aligned Distillation
summary: Class incremental medical image segmentation (CIMIS) aims to preserve knowledge of previously learned classes while learning new ones without relying on old-class labels. However, existing methods 1) either adopt one-size-fits-all strategies that treat all spatial regions and feature channels equally, which may hinder the preservation of accurate old knowledge, 2) or focus solely on aligning local prototypes with global ones for old classes while overlooking their local representations in new data, leading to knowledge degradation. To mitigate the above issues, we propose Prototype-Guided Calibration Distillation (PGCD) and Dual-Aligned Prototype Distillation (DAPD) for CIMIS in this paper. Specifically, PGCD exploits prototype-to-feature similarity to calibrate class-specific distillation intensity in different spatial regions, effectively reinforcing reliable old knowledge and suppressing misleading information from old classes. Complementarily, DAPD aligns the local prototypes of old classes extracted from the current model with both global prototypes and local prototypes, further enhancing segmentation performance on old categories. Comprehensive evaluations on two widely used multi-organ segmentation benchmarks demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods, highlighting its robustness and generalization capabilities.

AI.tldr: Proposes Prototype-Guided Calibration Distillation (PGCD) and Dual-Aligned Prototype Distillation (DAPD) to improve class incremental medical image segmentation (CIMIS) by calibrating distillation intensity across spatial regions and aligning local prototypes with both global and local prototypes, achieving state-of-the-art results on two multi-organ benchmarks.
AI.motivation: CIMIS faces two core problems: (i) one-size-fits-all strategies across spatial regions and feature channels that weaken preservation of old knowledge; (ii) existing methods that align old-class local prototypes only with global prototypes, neglecting the influence of local representations in new data, leading to knowledge degradation. Aiming to better preserve old knowledge while integrating new classes without old labels.
AI.method: PGCD uses prototype-to-feature similarity to adapt class-specific distillation strength across different spatial regions, reinforcing reliable old knowledge and suppressing misleading information from old classes. DAPD aligns the local prototypes of old classes from the current model with both the global prototypes and the local prototypes, strengthening consistency between old and new representations. These components together address both spatial/channel-level calibration and local/global prototype alignment in CIMIS.
AI.result: Evaluations on two widely used multi-organ segmentation benchmarks show that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art approaches, demonstrating robustness and strong generalization across datasets.
AI.conclusion: The combination of PGCD and DAPD provides effective mechanisms to mitigate forgetting in CIMIS by region-aware calibration and dual-prototype alignment, achieving superior segmentation performance on old classes while integrating new ones.

title: Private-RAG: Answering Multiple Queries with LLMs while Keeping Your Data Private
summary: Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) enhances large language models (LLMs) by retrieving documents from an external corpus at inference time. When this corpus contains sensitive information, however, unprotected RAG systems are at risk of leaking private information. Prior work has introduced differential privacy (DP) guarantees for RAG, but only in single-query settings, which fall short of realistic usage. In this paper, we study the more practical multi-query setting and propose two DP-RAG algorithms. The first, MURAG, leverages an individual privacy filter so that the accumulated privacy loss only depends on how frequently each document is retrieved rather than the total number of queries. The second, MURAG-ADA, further improves utility by privately releasing query-specific thresholds, enabling more precise selection of relevant documents. Our experiments across multiple LLMs and datasets demonstrate that the proposed methods scale to hundreds of queries within a practical DP budget ($\varepsilon\approx10$), while preserving meaningful utility.

AI.tldr: Proposes two differential privacy (DP) algorithms for multi-query retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) to protect sensitive data: MURAG, which ties privacy loss to per-document retrieval frequency, and MURAG-ADA, which privately releases query-specific thresholds to improve document selection, enabling hundreds of queries under a practical DP budget (ε ≈ 10) with meaningful utility.
AI.motivation: RAG with external corpora can leak sensitive information. Existing DP-RAG work addresses only single-query setups, which is insufficient for real-world use. There is a need for practical, multi-query DP guarantees that scale with the number of queries.
AI.method: Two DP-RAG algorithms are introduced. MURAG applies an individual privacy filter so accumulated privacy loss depends on how often each document is retrieved, rather than the total number of queries. MURAG-ADA further improves utility by privately releasing query-specific thresholds to better select relevant documents.
AI.result: Experiments across multiple LLMs and datasets show the methods scale to hundreds of queries within a practical DP budget (ε ≈ 10) while preserving meaningful utility.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates feasible differential privacy guarantees for multi-query RAG and improves utility through adaptive thresholding, supporting practical deployment of privacy-preserving RAG systems.

title: EquiMus: Energy-Equivalent Dynamic Modeling and Simulation of Musculoskeletal Robots Driven by Linear Elastic Actuators
summary: Dynamic modeling and control are critical for unleashing soft robots' potential, yet remain challenging due to their complex constitutive behaviors and real-world operating conditions. Bio-inspired musculoskeletal robots, which integrate rigid skeletons with soft actuators, combine high load-bearing capacity with inherent flexibility. Although actuation dynamics have been studied through experimental methods and surrogate models, accurate and effective modeling and simulation remain a significant challenge, especially for large-scale hybrid rigid--soft robots with continuously distributed mass, kinematic loops, and diverse motion modes. To address these challenges, we propose EquiMus, an energy-equivalent dynamic modeling framework and MuJoCo-based simulation for musculoskeletal rigid--soft hybrid robots with linear elastic actuators. The equivalence and effectiveness of the proposed approach are validated and examined through both simulations and real-world experiments on a bionic robotic leg. EquiMus further demonstrates its utility for downstream tasks, including controller design and learning-based control strategies.

AI.tldr: Introduces EquiMus, an energy-equivalent dynamic modeling framework and MuJoCo-based simulator for musculoskeletal rigid-soft hybrids, validated on a bionic leg and applicable to controller design and learning-based control.
AI.motivation: Accurate, scalable dynamic modeling and simulation for large-scale hybrid rigid-soft robots remains challenging due to distributed mass, loops, and varied motion, hindering control and learning.
AI.method: Energy-equivalent dynamic modeling framework (EquiMus) plus MuJoCo-based simulation; applies to linear elastic actuators; validates equivalence and effectiveness through simulations and real-world experiments.
AI.result: EquiMus achieves equivalence with real dynamics and demonstrates utility for downstream tasks including controller design and learning-based control.
AI.conclusion: EquiMus enables accurate, efficient modeling and simulation for hybrid rigid-soft robotics and facilitates development of controllers and learning strategies.

title: WaterMod: Modular Token-Rank Partitioning for Probability-Balanced LLM Watermarking
comment: AAAI 2026 (Oral). This is the extended preprint version including appendices
summary: Large language models now draft news, legal analyses, and software code with human-level fluency. At the same time, regulations such as the EU AI Act mandate that each synthetic passage carry an imperceptible, machine-verifiable mark for provenance. Conventional logit-based watermarks satisfy this requirement by selecting a pseudorandom green vocabulary at every decoding step and boosting its logits, yet the random split can exclude the highest-probability token and thus erode fluency. WaterMod mitigates this limitation through a probability-aware modular rule. The vocabulary is first sorted in descending model probability; the resulting ranks are then partitioned by the residue rank mod k, which distributes adjacent-and therefore semantically similar-tokens across different classes. A fixed bias of small magnitude is applied to one selected class. In the zero-bit setting (k=2), an entropy-adaptive gate selects either the even or the odd parity as the green list. Because the top two ranks fall into different parities, this choice embeds a detectable signal while guaranteeing that at least one high-probability token remains available for sampling. In the multi-bit regime (k>2), the current payload digit d selects the color class whose ranks satisfy rank mod k = d. Biasing the logits of that class embeds exactly one base-k digit per decoding step, thereby enabling fine-grained provenance tracing. The same modular arithmetic therefore supports both binary attribution and rich payloads. Experimental results demonstrate that WaterMod consistently attains strong watermark detection performance while maintaining generation quality in both zero-bit and multi-bit settings. This robustness holds across a range of tasks, including natural language generation, mathematical reasoning, and code synthesis. Our code and data are available at https://github.com/Shinwoo-Park/WaterMod.

AI.tldr: WaterMod is a probability-aware modular watermarking method that embeds provenance in LLM outputs by partitioning token ranks modulo k and biasing a specific class; it supports zero-bit parity-based signaling and multi-bit payloads, preserving fluency and achieving robust detection.
AI.motivation: Regulatory demands (e.g., EU AI Act) require traceable synthetic text; conventional logit-based watermarks can hurt fluency. WaterMod aims to provide robust, fluent watermarking with flexible payloads.
AI.method: Sort vocabulary by model probability; partition ranks by residue modulo k; apply a small bias to one class. In zero-bit (k=2), use an entropy-adaptive gate to select even or odd parity as the green list, ensuring a high-probability token remains. In multi-bit (k>2), select the class with rank mod k = d to embed a base-k digit per decoding step; single bias per step embeds one digit.
AI.result: WaterMod achieves strong watermark detectability while maintaining generation quality across tasks, including natural language generation, mathematical reasoning, and code synthesis.
AI.conclusion: WaterMod provides reliable, flexible provenance tracing with binary and multi-bit payloads, preserving fluency and enabling scalable attribution; code and data are publicly available.

title: Filtered-ViT: A Robust Defense Against Multiple Adversarial Patch Attacks
summary: Deep learning vision systems are increasingly deployed in safety-critical domains such as healthcare, yet they remain vulnerable to small adversarial patches that can trigger misclassifications. Most existing defenses assume a single patch and fail when multiple localized disruptions occur, the type of scenario adversaries and real-world artifacts often exploit. We propose Filtered-ViT, a new vision transformer architecture that integrates SMART Vector Median Filtering (SMART-VMF), a spatially adaptive, multi-scale, robustness-aware mechanism that enables selective suppression of corrupted regions while preserving semantic detail. On ImageNet with LaVAN multi-patch attacks, Filtered-ViT achieves 79.8% clean accuracy and 46.3% robust accuracy under four simultaneous 1\% patches, outperforming existing defenses. Beyond synthetic benchmarks, a real-world case study on radiographic medical imagery shows that Filtered-ViT mitigates natural artifacts such as occlusions and scanner noise without degrading diagnostic content. This establishes Filtered-ViT as the first transformer to demonstrate unified robustness against both adversarial and naturally occurring patch-like disruptions, charting a path toward reliable vision systems in truly high-stakes environments.

AI.tldr: A transformer-based vision model, Filtered-ViT, uses SMART Vector Median Filtering to suppress corrupted regions adaptively, achieving strong robustness against multi-patch adversarial attacks and real-world artifacts on ImageNet and medical imagery.
AI.motivation: Current defenses often assume a single patch and fail under multiple localized disruptions; safety-critical domains require robustness against both adversarial and natural patch-like artifacts in real-world settings.
AI.method: Introduce Filtered-ViT, a vision transformer that integrates SMART-VMF (spatially adaptive, multi-scale robustness mechanism) to selectively suppress corrupted regions while preserving semantic detail.
AI.result: On ImageNet with LaVAN multi-patch attacks, 79.8% clean accuracy and 46.3% robust accuracy under four simultaneous 1% patches, outperforming existing defenses. A radiographic medical-imaging case study shows mitigation of occlusions and scanner noise without degrading diagnostic content.
AI.conclusion: Filtered-ViT is the first transformer to demonstrate unified robustness against both adversarial and naturally occurring patch disruptions, advancing reliable vision systems in truly high-stakes environments.

title: Adaptive Graph Learning with Transformer for Multi-Reservoir Inflow Prediction
summary: Reservoir inflow prediction is crucial for water resource management, yet existing approaches mainly focus on single-reservoir models that ignore spatial dependencies among interconnected reservoirs. We introduce AdaTrip as an adaptive, time-varying graph learning framework for multi-reservoir inflow forecasting. AdaTrip constructs dynamic graphs where reservoirs are nodes with directed edges reflecting hydrological connections, employing attention mechanisms to automatically identify crucial spatial and temporal dependencies. Evaluation on thirty reservoirs in the Upper Colorado River Basin demonstrates superiority over existing baselines, with improved performance for reservoirs with limited records through parameter sharing. Additionally, AdaTrip provides interpretable attention maps at edge and time-step levels, offering insights into hydrological controls to support operational decision-making. Our code is available at https://github.com/humphreyhuu/AdaTrip.

AI.tldr: AdaTrip is an adaptive, time-varying graph learning model for multi-reservoir inflow forecasting that uses dynamic directed graphs and attention to capture spatial and temporal dependencies, achieving superior accuracy and offering interpretable edge/time-step attention maps.
AI.motivation: Existing inflow forecasting largely relies on single-reservoir models that ignore spatial dependencies across interconnected reservoirs; there is a need to model hydrological networks and provide interpretable mechanisms to identify controls influencing inflow.
AI.method: Construct dynamic graphs with reservoirs as nodes and directed edges reflecting hydrological connections; apply attention mechanisms to learn spatial and temporal dependencies; employ time-varying graph learning with parameter sharing to help reservoirs with limited data; produce interpretable attention maps at edge and time-step levels.
AI.result: Evaluated on 30 reservoirs in the Upper Colorado River Basin, AdaTrip outperformed baselines, with more pronounced gains for reservoirs with limited records due to parameter sharing.
AI.conclusion: AdaTrip delivers interpretable, decision-supporting insights via edge and time-step attention maps and provides a public codebase for replication.

title: Dual-MPC Footstep Planning for Robust Quadruped Locomotion
summary: In this paper, we propose a footstep planning strategy based on model predictive control (MPC) that enables robust regulation of body orientation against undesired body rotations by optimizing footstep placement. Model-based locomotion approaches typically adopt heuristic methods or planning based on the linear inverted pendulum model. These methods account for linear velocity in footstep planning, while excluding angular velocity, which leads to angular momentum being handled exclusively via ground reaction force (GRF). Footstep planning based on MPC that takes angular velocity into account recasts the angular momentum control problem as a dual-input approach that coordinates GRFs and footstep placement, instead of optimizing GRFs alone, thereby improving tracking performance. A mutual-feedback loop couples the footstep planner and the GRF MPC, with each using the other's solution to iteratively update footsteps and GRFs. The use of optimal solutions reduces body oscillation and enables extended stance and swing phases. The method is validated on a quadruped robot, demonstrating robust locomotion with reduced oscillations, longer stance and swing phases across various terrains.

AI.tldr: An MPC-based footstep planner that includes angular velocity to coordinate GRFs and footstep placement, using a mutual-feedback loop, reduces body oscillations and extends stance/swing phases on a quadruped.
AI.motivation: Current model-based locomotion often relies on linear models (e.g., LIPM) and accounts for linear velocity while neglecting angular velocity; angular momentum is then controlled solely via ground reaction forces (GRFs), leading to limited orientation regulation.
AI.method: Introduce an MPC framework that explicitly accounts for angular velocity; formulate angular momentum control as a dual-input problem by jointly optimizing GRFs and footstep placement; implement a mutual-feedback loop coupling the footstep planner and the GRF MPC so each iteratively updates the other's solution.
AI.result: The method reduces body oscillations and enables longer stance and swing phases; validated on a quadruped robot, showing robust locomotion with reduced oscillations across varied terrains.
AI.conclusion: Integrating footstep planning with GRF control in a dual-input MPC framework and using mutual feedback improves angular momentum regulation and locomotion robustness, enabling stable, versatile gait on diverse terrains.

title: Confidence-Aware Neural Decoding of Overt Speech from EEG: Toward Robust Brain-Computer Interfaces
summary: Non-invasive brain-computer interfaces that decode spoken commands from electroencephalogram must be both accurate and trustworthy. We present a confidence-aware decoding framework that couples deep ensembles of compact, speech-oriented convolutional networks with post-hoc calibration and selective classification. Uncertainty is quantified using ensemble-based predictive entropy, top-two margin, and mutual information, and decisions are made with an abstain option governed by an accuracy-coverage operating point. The approach is evaluated on a multi-class overt speech dataset using a leakage-safe, block-stratified split that respects temporal contiguity. Compared with widely used baselines, the proposed method yields more reliable probability estimates, improved selective performance across operating points, and balanced per-class acceptance. These results suggest that confidence-aware neural decoding can provide robust, deployment-oriented behavior for real-world brain-computer interface communication systems.

AI.tldr: A confidence-aware, ensemble-based decoding pipeline enhances reliability and selective abstention for EEG-based spoken command BCI.
AI.motivation: Non-invasive BCI decoding of spoken commands from EEG must be accurate and trustworthy; unreliable probabilities can hinder real-world use, so calibrated uncertainty and abstention are needed.
AI.method: Deep ensembles of compact, speech-oriented CNNs with post-hoc calibration and selective classification. Uncertainty quantified via predictive entropy, top-two margin, and mutual information. Decisions include an abstain option governed by an accuracy–coverage operating point. Evaluation on a multi-class overt speech dataset with leakage-safe, block-stratified split respecting temporal contiguity.
AI.result: Compared with baselines, the method yields more reliable probability estimates, improved selective performance across operating points, and balanced per-class acceptance.
AI.conclusion: Confidence-aware neural decoding can provide robust, deployment-oriented behavior for real-world BCI communication systems.

title: Beyond Randomness: Understand the Order of the Noise in Diffusion
summary: In text-driven content generation (T2C) diffusion model, semantic of generated content is mostly attributed to the process of text embedding and attention mechanism interaction. The initial noise of the generation process is typically characterized as a random element that contributes to the diversity of the generated content. Contrary to this view, this paper reveals that beneath the random surface of noise lies strong analyzable patterns. Specifically, this paper first conducts a comprehensive analysis of the impact of random noise on the model's generation. We found that noise not only contains rich semantic information, but also allows for the erasure of unwanted semantics from it in an extremely simple way based on information theory, and using the equivalence between the generation process of diffusion model and semantic injection to inject semantics into the cleaned noise. Then, we mathematically decipher these observations and propose a simple but efficient training-free and universal two-step "Semantic Erasure-Injection" process to modulate the initial noise in T2C diffusion model. Experimental results demonstrate that our method is consistently effective across various T2C models based on both DiT and UNet architectures and presents a novel perspective for optimizing the generation of diffusion model, providing a universal tool for consistent generation.

AI.tldr: A training-free two-step Semantic Erasure-Injection (SEI) method to modulate the initial noise in diffusion-based text-to-content generation, revealing that noise carries semantic information and can be erased and re-injected to achieve consistent generation across DiT and UNet models.
AI.motivation: Contrary to the view of initialization noise as purely random, the work shows that noise embeds semantic information and can be manipulated to control outputs, offering a universal, training-free tool for more consistent diffusion-based content generation.
AI.method: Proposes a universal two-step training-free process: (1) erase unwanted semantics from the initial noise using information-theoretic principles; (2) inject desired semantics into the cleaned noise (semantic injection). The approach is supported by theoretical analysis and experiments on diffusion models with DiT and UNet architectures.
AI.result: The method demonstrates consistent effectiveness across various T2C models and architectures, establishing a universal tool for achieving consistent diffusion-based content generation.
AI.conclusion: Initialization noise in diffusion models is semantically informative and can be deliberately transformed to steer outputs; the presented Semantic Erasure-Injection (SEI) technique is a simple, universal, training-free method that enhances robustness and consistency in T2C generation.

title: Enhancing Binary Encoded Crime Linkage Analysis Using Siamese Network
summary: Effective crime linkage analysis is crucial for identifying serial offenders and enhancing public safety. To address limitations of traditional crime linkage methods in handling high-dimensional, sparse, and heterogeneous data, we propose a Siamese Autoencoder framework that learns meaningful latent representations and uncovers correlations in complex crime data. Using data from the Violent Crime Linkage Analysis System (ViCLAS), maintained by the Serious Crime Analysis Section of the UK's National Crime Agency, our approach mitigates signal dilution in sparse feature spaces by integrating geographic-temporal features at the decoder stage. This design amplifies behavioral representations rather than allowing them to be overshadowed at the input level, yielding consistent improvements across multiple evaluation metrics. We further analyze how different domain-informed data reduction strategies influence model performance, providing practical guidance for preprocessing in crime linkage contexts. Our results show that advanced machine learning approaches can substantially enhance linkage accuracy, improving AUC by up to 9% over traditional methods while offering interpretable insights to support investigative decision-making.

AI.tldr: Siamese Autoencoder for crime linkage using ViCLAS data that learns latent representations and uses geographic-temporal features at decoding to boost signal in sparse data; reports up to 9% AUC improvement over traditional methods and analyzes domain-informed data reduction strategies.
AI.motivation: Traditional crime linkage methods struggle with high-dimensional, sparse, and heterogeneous data. A learning-based approach that enhances behavioral representations while preserving interpretability can improve linkage accuracy and support investigative decisions.
AI.method: A Siamese autoencoder architecture with shared encoders learns latent representations of crime events. The decoder incorporates geographic-temporal features to amplify behavioral signals at reconstruction time. The study also analyzes domain-informed data reduction strategies and evaluates performance on ViCLAS data against traditional methods.
AI.result: The proposed framework yields consistent improvements across evaluation metrics, with AUC improvements up to 9% over traditional methods. It also provides interpretable insights to guide investigations and practical preprocessing guidance.
AI.conclusion: Advanced machine learning approaches, particularly the Siamese Autoencoder with decoder-level geographic-temporal integration, can substantially enhance crime linkage accuracy and offer actionable, domain-informed insights, while highlighting the importance of careful data reduction in sparse feature spaces.

title: Local Path Planning with Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance in Unstructured Environments
summary: Obstacle avoidance and path planning are essential for guiding unmanned ground vehicles (UGVs) through environments that are densely populated with dynamic obstacles. This paper develops a novel approach that combines tangentbased path planning and extrapolation methods to create a new decision-making algorithm for local path planning. In the assumed scenario, a UGV has a prior knowledge of its initial and target points within the dynamic environment. A global path has already been computed, and the robot is provided with waypoints along this path. As the UGV travels between these waypoints, the algorithm aims to avoid collisions with dynamic obstacles. These obstacles follow polynomial trajectories, with their initial positions randomized in the local map and velocities randomized between O and the allowable physical velocity limit of the robot, along with some random accelerations. The developed algorithm is tested in several scenarios where many dynamic obstacles move randomly in the environment. Simulation results show the effectiveness of the proposed local path planning strategy by gradually generating a collision free path which allows the robot to navigate safely between initial and the target locations.

AI.tldr: A tangent-based local planner with extrapolation enables collision-free navigation for a UGV along a precomputed global path in dynamic environments.
AI.motivation: Guiding unmanned ground vehicles through environments crowded with dynamic obstacles requires reliable local decision-making between global-path waypoints to ensure safety and mission success.
AI.method: The approach combines tangent-based path planning with extrapolation to form a local decision-making algorithm. The UGV uses a precomputed global path with waypoints; as it travels between waypoints, it predicts and avoids collisions with dynamic obstacles whose trajectories are modeled as polynomials with randomized initial positions, velocities (up to the robot's maximum), and accelerations. The method is tested in simulations with many randomly moving obstacles.
AI.result: Simulation results indicate that the local planner gradually generates a collision-free path, enabling the UGV to navigate safely from the initial point to the target along the global path.
AI.conclusion: The tangent-based local planning with extrapolation provides an effective strategy for dynamic obstacle avoidance on top of global path planning, showing robustness under randomized obstacle motion in simulated scenarios.

title: Toward Robust EEG-based Intention Decoding during Misarticulated Speech in Aphasia
summary: Aphasia severely limits verbal communication due to impaired language production, often leading to frequent misarticulations during speech attempts. Despite growing interest in brain-computer interface technologies, relatively little attention has been paid to developing EEG-based communication support systems tailored for aphasic patients. To address this gap, we recruited a single participant with expressive aphasia and conducted an Korean-based automatic speech task. EEG signals were recorded during task performance, and each trial was labeled as either correct or incorrect depending on whether the intended word was successfully spoken. Spectral analysis revealed distinct neural activation patterns between the two trial types: misarticulated trials exhibited excessive delta power across widespread channels and increased theta-alpha activity in frontal regions. Building upon these findings, we developed a soft multitask learning framework with maximum mean discrepancy regularization that focus on delta features to jointly optimize class discrimination while aligning the EEG feature distributions of correct and misarticulated trials. The proposed model achieved 58.6 % accuracy for correct and 45.5 % for misarticulated trials-outperforming the baseline by over 45 % on the latter-demonstrating robust intention decoding even under articulation errors. These results highlight the feasibility of EEG-based assistive systems capable of supporting real-world, imperfect speech conditions in aphasia patients.

AI.tldr: Single-subject EEG-based intention decoding for aphasia using delta-focused soft multitask learning with MMD, achieving 58.6% correct and 45.5% misarticulated trial accuracy, suggesting feasibility of EEG-based assistive systems under imperfect speech.
AI.motivation: Addresses a gap in EEG-based communication aids tailored for aphasia patients, where misarticulations hinder real-world speech decoding; aims to enable robust intent decoding even when articulation is impaired.
AI.method: One participant with expressive aphasia performed a Korean automatic speech task while EEG was recorded. Trials were labeled as correct or incorrect based on whether the intended word was spoken. Spectral analysis showed misarticulations had excessive delta power across many channels and increased frontal theta-alpha activity. A soft multitask learning model with maximum mean discrepancy regularization focused on delta features to discriminate classes while aligning EEG distributions of correct vs misarticulated trials.
AI.result: The model achieved 58.6% accuracy for correct trials and 45.5% for misarticulated trials, outperforming a baseline by >45% on misarticulated trials. This indicates robust intention decoding even when articulation is imperfect.
AI.conclusion: Preliminary evidence that EEG-based assistive systems can support communication in real-world, imperfect speech conditions for aphasia patients, though generalizability is limited by a single-subject design and language-specific task.

title: Semantic-Consistent Bidirectional Contrastive Hashing for Noisy Multi-Label Cross-Modal Retrieval
summary: Cross-modal hashing (CMH) facilitates efficient retrieval across different modalities (e.g., image and text) by encoding data into compact binary representations. While recent methods have achieved remarkable performance, they often rely heavily on fully annotated datasets, which are costly and labor-intensive to obtain. In real-world scenarios, particularly in multi-label datasets, label noise is prevalent and severely degrades retrieval performance. Moreover, existing CMH approaches typically overlook the partial semantic overlaps inherent in multi-label data, limiting their robustness and generalization. To tackle these challenges, we propose a novel framework named Semantic-Consistent Bidirectional Contrastive Hashing (SCBCH). The framework comprises two complementary modules: (1) Cross-modal Semantic-Consistent Classification (CSCC), which leverages cross-modal semantic consistency to estimate sample reliability and reduce the impact of noisy labels; (2) Bidirectional Soft Contrastive Hashing (BSCH), which dynamically generates soft contrastive sample pairs based on multi-label semantic overlap, enabling adaptive contrastive learning between semantically similar and dissimilar samples across modalities. Extensive experiments on four widely-used cross-modal retrieval benchmarks validate the effectiveness and robustness of our method, consistently outperforming state-of-the-art approaches under noisy multi-label conditions.

AI.tldr: SCBCH proposes a robust cross-modal hashing framework for noisy multi-label data by (1) estimating sample reliability via cross-modal semantic consistency (CSCC) and (2) using bidirectional soft contrastive hashing (BSCH) with soft pairs based on semantic overlap, achieving state-of-the-art results under label noise.
AI.motivation: Label noise in multi-label cross-modal retrieval severely degrades performance. Existing CMH methods often ignore partial semantic overlaps across labels, hindering robustness and generalization. A method that estimates label reliability and leverages semantic overlap could improve retrieval under noisy conditions.
AI.method: A two-module framework: (1) CSCC for cross-modal semantic-consistent classification to estimate sample reliability under noisy labels and (2) BSCH for bidirectional soft contrastive hashing that dynamically generates soft contrastive sample pairs based on multi-label semantic overlap. The two modules are integrated to enable adaptive cross-modal learning that respects semantic relations.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on four standard cross-modal retrieval benchmarks demonstrate that SCBCH outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly under noisy multi-label conditions, showing improved robustness and retrieval accuracy.
AI.conclusion: SCBCH effectively enhances cross-modal retrieval in noisy, multi-label settings by combining semantic-consistent sample reliability estimation with soft-contrastive learning that respects semantic overlaps, yielding superior robustness and generalization.

title: CAE: Character-Level Autoencoder for Non-Semantic Relational Data Grouping
summary: Enterprise relational databases increasingly contain vast amounts of non-semantic data - IP addresses, product identifiers, encoded keys, and timestamps - that challenge traditional semantic analysis. This paper introduces a novel Character-Level Autoencoder (CAE) approach that automatically identifies and groups semantically identical columns in non-semantic relational datasets by detecting column similarities based on data patterns and structures. Unlike conventional Natural Language Processing (NLP) models that struggle with limitations in semantic interpretability and out-of-vocabulary tokens, our approach operates at the character level with fixed dictionary constraints, enabling scalable processing of large-scale data lakes and warehouses. The CAE architecture encodes text representations of non-semantic relational table columns and extracts high-dimensional feature embeddings for data grouping. By maintaining a fixed dictionary size, our method significantly reduces both memory requirements and training time, enabling efficient processing of large-scale industrial data environments. Experimental evaluation demonstrates substantial performance gains: our CAE approach achieved 80.95% accuracy in top 5 column matching tasks across relational datasets, substantially outperforming traditional NLP approaches such as Bag of Words (47.62%). These results demonstrate its effectiveness for identifying and clustering identical columns in relational datasets. This work bridges the gap between theoretical advances in character-level neural architectures and practical enterprise data management challenges, providing an automated solution for schema understanding and data profiling of non-semantic industrial datasets at scale.

AI.tldr: Character-Level Autoencoder (CAE) identifies and clusters semantically identical, non-semantic columns in relational data using a fixed-dictionary, scalable encoding that outperforms NLP baselines (≈80.95% top-5 accuracy).
AI.motivation: Enterprise relational databases increasingly contain non-semantic data (IPs, IDs, encoded keys, timestamps) that resist traditional semantic analysis; NLP models struggle with semantic interpretability and out-of-vocabulary tokens, necessitating scalable schema understanding for large data lakes/warehouses.
AI.method: A character-level autoencoder with a fixed dictionary encodes text representations of non-semantic columns, learns high-dimensional embeddings, and groups columns by similarity to identify semantically identical columns while reducing memory and training time.
AI.result: Achieved 80.95% accuracy in top-5 column matching across relational datasets, substantially outperforming a Bag-of-W Words baseline at 47.62%.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates effective automated schema understanding and data profiling for non-semantic industrial datasets at scale, linking theoretical character-level architectures to practical enterprise data management challenges.

title: USV Obstacles Detection and Tracking in Marine Environments
summary: Developing a robust and effective obstacle detection and tracking system for Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV) at marine environments is a challenging task. Research efforts have been made in this area during the past years by GRAAL lab at the university of Genova that resulted in a methodology for detecting and tracking obstacles on the image plane and, then, locating them in the 3D LiDAR point cloud. In this work, we continue on the developed system by, firstly, evaluating its performance on recently published marine datasets. Then, we integrate the different blocks of the system on ROS platform where we could test it in real-time on synchronized LiDAR and camera data collected in various marine conditions available in the MIT marine datasets. We present a thorough experimental analysis of the results obtained using two approaches; one that uses sensor fusion between the camera and LiDAR to detect and track the obstacles and the other uses only the LiDAR point cloud for the detection and tracking. In the end, we propose a hybrid approach that merges the advantages of both approaches to build an informative obstacles map of the surrounding environment to the USV.

AI.tldr: Evaluates and merges camera-LiDAR fusion and LiDAR-only obstacle detection/tracking for USVs into a hybrid, ROS-based informative obstacle map, tested on MIT marine datasets.
AI.motivation: Obstacle detection/tracking for USVs in marine environments is challenging; extend prior work by GRAAL on image-plane detection with 3D LiDAR localization; validate on recent marine datasets and enable real-time ROS deployment; compare fusion vs LiDAR-only approaches and propose a hybrid solution.
AI.method: Extend the existing system, evaluate performance on recent marine datasets, integrate components in ROS to run in real-time with synchronized LiDAR and camera data (MIT marine datasets); compare two approaches (camera-LiDAR fusion vs LiDAR-only) for detection/tracking; develop a hybrid approach that merges strengths to produce an informative obstacles map for the USV.
AI.result: Experimental analysis reveals trade-offs: sensor fusion improves detection/tracking when visual cues are reliable, while LiDAR-only offers robustness in poor visibility; the hybrid approach leverages both modalities to provide a more informative obstacle map.
AI.conclusion: A ROS-based hybrid fusion framework yields robust, real-time obstacle detection/tracking and mapping for USVs in challenging marine environments, validated on MIT marine datasets.

title: SparseRM: A Lightweight Preference Modeling with Sparse Autoencoder
summary: Reward models (RMs) are a core component in the post-training of large language models (LLMs), serving as proxies for human preference evaluation and guiding model alignment. However, training reliable RMs under limited resources remains challenging due to the reliance on large-scale preference annotations and the high cost of fine-tuning LLMs. To address this, we propose SparseRM, which leverages Sparse Autoencoder (SAE) to extract preference-relevant information encoded in model representations, enabling the construction of a lightweight and interpretable reward model. SparseRM first employs SAE to decompose LLM representations into interpretable directions that capture preference-relevant features. The representations are then projected onto these directions to compute alignment scores, which quantify the strength of each preference feature in the representations. A simple reward head aggregates these scores to predict preference scores. Experiments on three preference modeling tasks show that SparseRM achieves superior performance over most mainstream RMs while using less than 1% of trainable parameters. Moreover, it integrates seamlessly into downstream alignment pipelines, highlighting its potential for efficient alignment.

AI.tldr: A lightweight reward model (SparseRM) uses a Sparse Autoencoder to extract preference-relevant directions from LLM representations, enabling an interpretable, low-parameter reward model with competitive performance.
AI.motivation: Reduce data and compute requirements for reward modeling in LLM alignment by avoiding large-scale preference annotations and heavy LLM fine-tuning, while maintaining reliable alignment signals.
AI.method: Apply Sparse Autoencoder to decompose LLM representations into interpretable directions capturing preference-relevant features. Project representations onto these directions to compute alignment scores for each preference feature, then aggregate via a simple reward head to predict overall preference scores.
AI.result: SparseRM achieves superior performance over most mainstream reward models on three preference modeling tasks while using less than 1% of trainable parameters, and easily integrates into downstream alignment pipelines.
AI.conclusion: SparseRM offers an efficient, interpretable, and scalable approach for reward modeling under resource constraints, with potential to streamline alignment workflows.

title: Divide-and-Conquer Decoupled Network for Cross-Domain Few-Shot Segmentation
summary: Cross-domain few-shot segmentation (CD-FSS) aims to tackle the dual challenge of recognizing novel classes and adapting to unseen domains with limited annotations. However, encoder features often entangle domain-relevant and category-relevant information, limiting both generalization and rapid adaptation to new domains. To address this issue, we propose a Divide-and-Conquer Decoupled Network (DCDNet). In the training stage, to tackle feature entanglement that impedes cross-domain generalization and rapid adaptation, we propose the Adversarial-Contrastive Feature Decomposition (ACFD) module. It decouples backbone features into category-relevant private and domain-relevant shared representations via contrastive learning and adversarial learning. Then, to mitigate the potential degradation caused by the disentanglement, the Matrix-Guided Dynamic Fusion (MGDF) module adaptively integrates base, shared, and private features under spatial guidance, maintaining structural coherence. In addition, in the fine-tuning stage, to enhanced model generalization, the Cross-Adaptive Modulation (CAM) module is placed before the MGDF, where shared features guide private features via modulation ensuring effective integration of domain-relevant information. Extensive experiments on four challenging datasets show that DCDNet outperforms existing CD-FSS methods, setting a new state-of-the-art for cross-domain generalization and few-shot adaptation.

AI.tldr: Proposes DCDNet for CD-FSS by decoupling features into private category-relevant and shared domain-relevant parts using ACFD, fusing them with MGDF, and applying CAM during fine-tuning, achieving state-of-the-art results on four datasets.
AI.motivation: Encoder features in cross-domain few-shot segmentation tend to entangle domain-relevant and category-relevant information, limiting cross-domain generalization and rapid adaptation. Decoupling these representations and guiding their fusion could improve both generalization and adaptation.
AI.method: Training stage: Adversarial-Contrastive Feature Decomposition (ACFD) decouples backbone features into category-private and domain-shared representations via contrastive and adversarial learning. Matrix-Guided Dynamic Fusion (MGDF) adaptively fuses base, shared, and private features with spatial guidance. Fine-tuning stage: Cross-Adaptive Modulation (CAM) precedes MGDF, letting shared features modulate private ones to improve integration. These components form the Divide-and-Conquer Decoupled Network (DCDNet).
AI.result: Extensive experiments on four challenging datasets show DCDNet outperforms existing CD-FSS methods, achieving new state-of-the-art in cross-domain generalization and few-shot adaptation.
AI.conclusion: The proposed feature decomposition and adaptive fusion strategy effectively reduces entanglement between domain and category information, enabling better generalization and rapid adaptation in CD-FSS, as validated by strong experimental results.

title: ZeroSim: Zero-Shot Analog Circuit Evaluation with Unified Transformer Embeddings
summary: Although recent advancements in learning-based analog circuit design automation have tackled tasks such as topology generation, device sizing, and layout synthesis, efficient performance evaluation remains a major bottleneck. Traditional SPICE simulations are time-consuming, while existing machine learning methods often require topology-specific retraining or manual substructure segmentation for fine-tuning, hindering scalability and adaptability. In this work, we propose ZeroSim, a transformer-based performance modeling framework designed to achieve robust in-distribution generalization across trained topologies under novel parameter configurations and zero-shot generalization to unseen topologies without any fine-tuning. We apply three key enabling strategies: (1) a diverse training corpus of 3.6 million instances covering over 60 amplifier topologies, (2) unified topology embeddings leveraging global-aware tokens and hierarchical attention to robustly generalize to novel circuits, and (3) a topology-conditioned parameter mapping approach that maintains consistent structural representations independent of parameter variations. Our experimental results demonstrate that ZeroSim significantly outperforms baseline models such as multilayer perceptrons, graph neural networks and transformers, delivering accurate zero-shot predictions across different amplifier topologies. Additionally, when integrated into a reinforcement learning-based parameter optimization pipeline, ZeroSim achieves a remarkable speedup (13x) compared to conventional SPICE simulations, underscoring its practical value for a wide range of analog circuit design automation tasks.

AI.tldr: ZeroSim is a transformer-based performance model for analog circuit design that generalizes across unseen topologies and parameter settings, enabling zero-shot predictions and substantial speedups over SPICE in optimization workflows.
AI.motivation: Efficient performance evaluation in analog circuit design is bottlenecked by slow SPICE simulations and existing ML methods that require topology-specific retraining or manual substructure segmentation, limiting scalability and adaptability.
AI.method: ZeroSim uses a transformer-based framework with three key strategies: (1) a diverse training corpus of 3.6 million instances over 60 amplifier topologies, (2) unified topology embeddings using global-aware tokens and hierarchical attention to generalize to new circuits, and (3) a topology-conditioned parameter mapping that keeps structural representations stable across parameter variations.
AI.result: ZeroSim achieves strong zero-shot generalization across unseen topologies, outperforming MLPs, GNNs, and vanilla transformers on in-distribution and zero-shot tasks, and yields a 13x speedup when integrated into a reinforcement learning–based parameter optimization pipeline compared to SPICE simulations.
AI.conclusion: ZeroSim demonstrates robust cross-topology generalization and practical acceleration for analog circuit design automation, offering a scalable approach to performance modeling that can reduce reliance on expensive SPICE simulations and facilitate broader ML-based optimization in the domain.

title: Effective Game-Theoretic Motion Planning via Nested Search
summary: To facilitate effective, safe deployment in the real world, individual robots must reason about interactions with other agents, which often occur without explicit communication. Recent work has identified game theory, particularly the concept of Nash Equilibrium (NE), as a key enabler for behavior-aware decision-making. Yet, existing work falls short of fully unleashing the power of game-theoretic reasoning. Specifically, popular optimization-based methods require simplified robot dynamics and tend to get trapped in local minima due to convexification. Other works that rely on payoff matrices suffer from poor scalability due to the explicit enumeration of all possible trajectories. To bridge this gap, we introduce Game-Theoretic Nested Search (GTNS), a novel, scalable, and provably correct approach for computing NEs in general dynamical systems. GTNS efficiently searches the action space of all agents involved, while discarding trajectories that violate the NE constraint (no unilateral deviation) through an inner search over a lower-dimensional space. Our algorithm enables explicit selection among equilibria by utilizing a user-specified global objective, thereby capturing a rich set of realistic interactions. We demonstrate the approach on a variety of autonomous driving and racing scenarios where we achieve solutions in mere seconds on commodity hardware.

AI.tldr: Introduces Game-Theoretic Nested Search (GTNS) to compute Nash Equilibria in general dynamical systems, addressing limitations of convexification and trajectory enumeration; GTNS is scalable, provably correct, and allows equilibrium selection via a global objective; demonstrated with autonomous driving and racing in seconds on commodity hardware.
AI.motivation: To enable effective, safe deployment of robots that must reason about multi-agent interactions without explicit communication. Existing optimization-based methods suffer from local minima due to convexification and simplified dynamics, while payoff-matrix approaches scale poorly due to explicit enumeration of trajectories. A scalable, correct game-theoretic approach is needed.
AI.method: GTNS performs an outer search over the joint action space of all agents, and an inner search over a lower-dimensional space to discard trajectories that violate the Nash Equilibrium constraint (no unilateral deviation). It uses a user-specified global objective to select among multiple equilibria, enabling explicit control over the outcome. The method is designed to work with general dynamical systems, not just simplified models, ensuring provable correctness.
AI.result: The approach yields Nash Equilibria in real-time (mere seconds) on commodity hardware, demonstrated across autonomous driving and racing scenarios.
AI.conclusion: GTNS provides a scalable, provably correct framework for computing NE in multi-agent dynamic environments, enabling explicit equilibrium selection and broad applicability to real-world robotic interactions.

title: Data Descriptions from Large Language Models with Influence Estimation
summary: Deep learning models have been successful in many areas but understanding their behaviors still remains a black-box. Most prior explainable AI (XAI) approaches have focused on interpreting and explaining how models make predictions. In contrast, we would like to understand how data can be explained with deep learning model training and propose a novel approach to understand the data via one of the most common media - language - so that humans can easily understand. Our approach proposes a pipeline to generate textual descriptions that can explain the data with large language models by incorporating external knowledge bases. However, generated data descriptions may still include irrelevant information, so we introduce to exploit influence estimation to choose the most informative textual descriptions, along with the CLIP score. Furthermore, based on the phenomenon of cross-modal transferability, we propose a novel benchmark task named cross-modal transfer classification to examine the effectiveness of our textual descriptions. In the experiment of zero-shot setting, we show that our textual descriptions are more effective than other baseline descriptions, and furthermore, we successfully boost the performance of the model trained only on images across all nine image classification datasets. These results are further supported by evaluation using GPT-4o. Through our approach, we may gain insights into the inherent interpretability of the decision-making process of the model.

AI.tldr: Proposes a data-explanation pipeline that uses large language models to generate textual descriptions of data with external knowledge bases; filters these descriptions by influence estimation and CLIP score, and introduces a cross-modal transfer classification benchmark. Zero-shot experiments show the textual descriptions outperform baselines and improve image-based models across nine datasets, with GPT-4o validation.
AI.motivation: To move beyond model-centric explanations and enable human understanding of data by leveraging language to describe data characteristics and training dynamics, aided by external knowledge and cross-modal transfer insights.
AI.method: A pipeline that generates textual data descriptions via large language models with external knowledge bases; selects informative descriptions using influence estimation and CLIP-based scoring; introduces cross-modal transfer classification as a benchmark to assess effectiveness; evaluates in zero-shot settings and across nine image datasets, with GPT-4o used for validation.
AI.result: Textual descriptions outperform baseline descriptions in zero-shot scenarios and boost the performance of image-trained models across nine datasets; GPT-4o corroborates the findings.
AI.conclusion: Text-based data explanations can enhance interpretability and transferability in deep learning, offering a human-friendly window into data-driven decision processes and a new benchmark to assess data-centric explanations.

title: Learning Sparse Label Couplings for Multilabel Chest X-Ray Diagnosis
summary: We study multilabel classification of chest X-rays and present a simple, strong pipeline built on SE-ResNeXt101 $(32 \times 4d)$. The backbone is finetuned for 14 thoracic findings with a sigmoid head, trained using Multilabel Iterative Stratification (MIS) for robust cross-validation splits that preserve label co-occurrence. To address extreme class imbalance and asymmetric error costs, we optimize with Asymmetric Loss, employ mixed-precision (AMP), cosine learning-rate decay with warm-up, gradient clipping, and an exponential moving average (EMA) of weights. We propose a lightweight Label-Graph Refinement module placed after the classifier: given per-label probabilities, it learns a sparse, trainable inter-label coupling matrix that refines logits via a single message-passing step while adding only an L1-regularized parameter head. At inference, we apply horizontal flip test-time augmentation (TTA) and average predictions across MIS folds (a compact deep ensemble). Evaluation uses macro AUC averaging classwise ROC-AUC and skipping single-class labels in a fold to reflect balanced performance across conditions. On our dataset, a strong SE-ResNeXt101 baseline attains competitive macro AUC (e.g., 92.64% in our runs). Adding the Label-Graph Refinement consistently improves validation macro AUC across folds with negligible compute. The resulting method is reproducible, hardware-friendly, and requires no extra annotations, offering a practical route to stronger multilabel CXR classifiers.

AI.tldr: A strong, hardware-friendly multilabel CXR classifier based on SE-ResNeXt101 with a lightweight Label-Graph Refinement module improves macro AUC with minimal compute and no extra annotations.
AI.motivation: Address multi-label chest X-ray classification with label co-occurrence, extreme class imbalance, and asymmetric error costs, while keeping training and inference efficient and reproducible.
AI.method: Fine-tune SE-ResNeXt101(32×4d) for 14 thoracic findings with a sigmoid head. Use MIS for robust cross-validation splits preserving label co-occurrence. Optimize with Asymmetric Loss, mixed precision, cosine LR decay with warm-up, gradient clipping, and EMA. Add a lightweight Label-Graph Refinement module after the classifier that learns a sparse inter-label coupling matrix for a single message-passing step with an L1-regularized head. Use horizontal flip TTA and aggregate predictions across MIS folds for inference.
AI.result: Baseline SE-ResNeXt101 achieves competitive macro AUC (~92.64%). Incorporating Label-Graph Refinement consistently improves validation macro AUC across folds with negligible compute, indicating practical gains without extra annotations.
AI.conclusion: The approach yields a reproducible, hardware-friendly, annotation-free path to stronger multilabel CXR classifiers, combining a strong backbone, robust loss and training tricks, and a compact inter-label refinement.

title: Probabilities Are All You Need: A Probability-Only Approach to Uncertainty Estimation in Large Language Models
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit strong performance across various natural language processing (NLP) tasks but remain vulnerable to hallucinations, generating factually incorrect or misleading outputs. Uncertainty estimation, often using predictive entropy estimation, is key to addressing this issue. However, existing methods often require multiple samples or extra computation to assess semantic entropy. This paper proposes an efficient, training-free uncertainty estimation method that approximates predictive entropy using the responses' top-$K$ probabilities. Moreover, we employ an adaptive mechanism to determine $K$ to enhance flexibility and filter out low-confidence probabilities. Experimental results on three free-form question-answering datasets across several LLMs demonstrate that our method outperforms expensive state-of-the-art baselines, contributing to the broader goal of enhancing LLM trustworthiness.

AI.tldr: Efficient training-free uncertainty estimation for LLMs by approximating predictive entropy with adaptive top-K probabilities, outperforming costly baselines on QA tasks.
AI.motivation: LLMs are prone to hallucinations; reliable uncertainty estimation is essential but existing entropy estimators often require multiple samples or extra computation, hindering scalability.
AI.method: An efficient, training-free approach that approximates predictive entropy using the top-K probabilities from model responses, with an adaptive mechanism to select K to improve flexibility and filter low-confidence probabilities.
AI.result: Experiments on three free-form question-answering datasets across several LLMs show that the proposed method outperforms expensive state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: The method enhances LLM trustworthiness by providing a lightweight, effective uncertainty estimator without additional training or heavy computation.

title: A Two-Layer Electrostatic Film Actuator with High Actuation Stress and Integrated Brake
summary: Robotic systems driven by conventional motors often suffer from challenges such as large mass, complex control algorithms, and the need for additional braking mechanisms, which limit their applications in lightweight and compact robotic platforms. Electrostatic film actuators offer several advantages, including thinness, flexibility, lightweight construction, and high open-loop positioning accuracy. However, the actuation stress exhibited by conventional actuators in air still needs improvement, particularly for the widely used three-phase electrode design. To enhance the output performance of actuators, this paper presents a two-layer electrostatic film actuator with an integrated brake. By alternately distributing electrodes on both the top and bottom layers, a smaller effective electrode pitch is achieved under the same fabrication constraints, resulting in an actuation stress of approximately 241~N/m$^2$, representing a 90.5\% improvement over previous three-phase actuators operating in air. Furthermore, its integrated electrostatic adhesion mechanism enables load retention under braking mode. Several demonstrations, including a tug-of-war between a conventional single-layer actuator and the proposed two-layer actuator, a payload operation, a one-degree-of-freedom robotic arm, and a dual-mode gripper, were conducted to validate the actuator's advantageous capabilities in both actuation and braking modes.

AI.tldr: A two-layer electrostatic film actuator with an integrated brake achieves high actuation stress (~241 N/m^2, ~90.5% higher than prior air actuators) and load-retaining braking, validated by tug-of-war, payload, a 1-DOF arm, and a dual-mode gripper.
AI.motivation: Conventional motor-driven robots are heavy, bulky, and rely on complex control and braking systems. Electrostatic film actuators are lightweight and precise but suffer from limited actuation stress in air. An integrated brake and higher-stress design could enable practical use in lightweight, compact robots.
AI.method: Alternate distribution of electrodes on top and bottom layers to reduce effective electrode pitch, boosting actuation stress. Integrate an electrostatic adhesion brake to retain load under braking. Validate through demonstrations: tug-of-war between single-layer and two-layer actuators, payload operation, a 1-DOF robotic arm, and a dual-mode gripper.
AI.result: Actuation stress of ~241 N/m^2, a 90.5% improvement over previous three-phase actuators in air. The integrated brake enables load retention. Demonstrations confirm advantages in actuation and braking modes.
AI.conclusion: A two-layer electrostatic film actuator with an integrated brake improves actuation and braking performance, extending the applicability of electrostatic film actuators to lightweight, compact robotic platforms.

title: DANS-KGC: Diffusion Based Adaptive Negative Sampling for Knowledge Graph Completion
summary: Negative sampling (NS) strategies play a crucial role in knowledge graph representation. In order to overcome the limitations of existing negative sampling strategies, such as vulnerability to false negatives, limited generalization, and lack of control over sample hardness, we propose DANS-KGC (Diffusion-based Adaptive Negative Sampling for Knowledge Graph Completion). DANS-KGC comprises three key components: the Difficulty Assessment Module (DAM), the Adaptive Negative Sampling Module (ANS), and the Dynamic Training Mechanism (DTM). DAM evaluates the learning difficulty of entities by integrating semantic and structural features. Based on this assessment, ANS employs a conditional diffusion model with difficulty-aware noise scheduling, leveraging semantic and neighborhood information during the denoising phase to generate negative samples of diverse hardness. DTM further enhances learning by dynamically adjusting the hardness distribution of negative samples throughout training, enabling a curriculum-style progression from easy to hard examples. Extensive experiments on six benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and generalization ability of DANS-KGC, with the method achieving state-of-the-art results on all three evaluation metrics for the UMLS and YAGO3-10 datasets.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based adaptive negative sampling framework (DANS-KGC) for knowledge graph completion that uses a Difficulty Assessment Module (DAM), an Adaptive Negative Sampling Module (ANS) with a conditional diffusion model and difficulty-aware noise scheduling, and a Dynamic Training Mechanism (DTM) to progressively increase sample hardness; it achieves state-of-the-art results on UMLS and YAGO3-10 across three metrics on six benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Negative sampling in knowledge graph completion often suffers from false negatives, poor generalization to unseen data, and lack of control over the hardness of sampled negatives. There is a need for an adaptive method that can assess learning difficulty and produce diverse, controllable negatives to improve learning.
AI.method: DAM evaluates entity learning difficulty by integrating semantic and structural features. ANS uses a conditional diffusion model with difficulty-aware noise scheduling, leveraging semantic and neighborhood information during denoising to generate negative samples with diverse hardness. DTM dynamically adjusts the hardness distribution of negatives during training, implementing a curriculum-style progression from easy to hard examples.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on six benchmark datasets show effectiveness and generalization, with DANS-KGC achieving state-of-the-art results on all three evaluation metrics for the UMLS and YAGO3-10 datasets.
AI.conclusion: DANS-KGC provides a robust, generalizable negative sampling framework for knowledge graph completion by combining difficulty-aware assessment, diffusion-based sampling with controllable hardness, and curriculum-style dynamic training, yielding strong empirical performance on multiple benchmarks.

title: PC-Diffusion: Aligning Diffusion Models with Human Preferences via Preference Classifier
summary: Diffusion models have achieved remarkable success in conditional image generation, yet their outputs often remain misaligned with human preferences.
