Lastly, we integrate both local cluster features and generalized scene memory into object queries, guiding attention toward informative regions. Exploiting a unified local clustering and generalized scene memory strategy, MonoCLUE enables robust monocular 3D detection under occlusion and limited visibility, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the KITTI benchmark.

AI.tldr: MonoCLUE proposes a dual-branch strategy for monocular 3D detection: local clustering of visual features via K-means to capture object-level parts, and a generalized scene memory that aggregates clustered features across images. These are integrated into object queries to guide attention, improving robustness to occlusion and restricted visibility, achieving state-of-the-art on KITTI.
AI.motivation: Monocular 3D detection suffers from ill-posed depth and limited FOV; lack of geometric cues leads to poor performance in occlusion/truncation. Existing methods that add depth information still miss visual cues essential for robust recognition. A method that leverages both local appearance parts and cross-image memory could provide stable, generalizable features.
AI.method: Two components: (1) local clustering: K-means on visual features to capture distinct object parts; propagate cluster features across regions to help detect partially visible objects; (2) generalized scene memory: aggregate clustered features across images to create consistent cross-scene representations; integrate both into object queries to guide attention toward informative regions.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on the KITTI benchmark for monocular 3D detection, particularly under occlusion and limited visibility.
AI.conclusion: A unified framework combining local feature clustering with generalized scene memory improves robustness and generalization in monocular 3D detection, addressing occlusion and depth ambiguity.

title: Schedulers for Schedule-free: Theoretically inspired hyperparameters
summary: The recently proposed schedule-free method has been shown to achieve strong performance when hyperparameter tuning is limited. The current theory for schedule-free only supports a constant learning rate, where-as the implementation used in practice uses a warm-up schedule. We show how to extend the last-iterate convergence theory of schedule-free to allow for any scheduler, and how the averaging parameter has to be updated as a function of the learning rate. We then perform experiments showing how our convergence theory has some predictive power with regards to practical executions on deep neural networks, despite that this theory relies on assuming convexity. When applied to the warmup-stable-decay (wsd) schedule, our theory shows the optimal convergence rate of $\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T})$. We then use convexity to design a new adaptive Polyak learning rate schedule for schedule-free. We prove an optimal anytime last-iterate convergence for our new Polyak schedule, and show that it performs well compared to a number of baselines on a black-box model distillation task.

AI.tldr: Extends last-iterate convergence of schedule-free to arbitrary learning-rate schedulers, deriving adaptive averaging, and introduces a Polyak-based schedule with optimal anytime convergence and competitive distillation performance.
AI.motivation: The current schedule-free theory assumes a constant learning rate, but practical use employs warm-up and other schedules; extending theory to arbitrary schedulers supports better theoretical guarantees and practical guidance.
AI.method: Theoretically extend last-iterate convergence to general schedulers; determine how averaging parameter should depend on the learning rate; empirically validate on deep nets; derive O(1/√T) rate for warmup-stable-decay; design an adaptive Polyak learning rate; prove optimal anytime last-iterate convergence; evaluate on black-box model distillation.
AI.result: The theory shows predictive power even under convexity; warmup-stable-decay achieves O(1/√T) convergence; adaptive Polyak schedule attains optimal anytime last-iterate convergence and performs well against baselines on distillation tasks.
AI.conclusion: Generalized schedule-free analysis to arbitrary schedulers is feasible and beneficial; adaptive Polyak scheduling offers strong guarantees and practical gains, inviting further work to relax convexity and extend to other tasks.

title: A CODECO Case Study and Initial Validation for Edge Orchestration of Autonomous Mobile Robots
summary:
Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs) increasingly adopt containerized micro-services across the Edge-Cloud continuum. While Kubernetes is the de-facto orchestrator for such systems, its assumptions of stable networks, homogeneous resources, and ample compute capacity do not fully hold in mobile, resource-constrained robotic environments.
  This paper describes a case study on smart-manufacturing AMRs and performs an initial comparison between CODECO orchestration and standard Kubernetes using a controlled KinD environment. Metrics include pod deployment and deletion times, CPU and memory usage, and inter-pod data rates. The observed results indicate that CODECO offers reduced CPU consumption and more stable communication patterns, at the cost of modest memory overhead (10-15%) and slightly increased pod lifecycle latency due to secure overlay initialization.

AI.tldr: In resource-constrained mobile edge robotics, a case study suggests CODECO outperforms Kubernetes in CPU and communication stability but incurs modest memory overhead and slightly higher pod startup latency.
AI.motivation: Kubernetes assumptions (stable networks, homogeneous resources) do not hold in mobile AMRs; there is a need to evaluate orchestration alternatives across the Edge-Cloud continuum.
AI.method: Controlled KinD environment comparing CODECO versus Kubernetes; measure pod deployment/deletion times, CPU/memory usage, and inter-pod data rates.
AI.result: CODECO reduces CPU consumption and yields more stable inter-pod communication; memory overhead is in the 10–15% range; pod lifecycle latency is slightly higher due to secure overlay initialization.
AI.conclusion: CODECO offers a favorable CPU and stability trade-off for resource-constrained AMRs, at the cost of modest memory use and a small increase in startup latency; further optimization of the overlay and broader validation are warranted.

title: Towards Fine-Grained Interpretability: Counterfactual Explanations for Misclassification with Saliency Partition
summary: Attribution-based explanation techniques capture key patterns to enhance visual interpretability; however, these patterns often lack the granularity needed for insight in fine-grained tasks, particularly in cases of model misclassification, where explanations may be insufficiently detailed. To address this limitation, we propose a fine-grained counterfactual explanation framework that generates both object-level and part-level interpretability, addressing two fundamental questions: (1) which fine-grained features contribute to model misclassification, and (2) where dominant local features influence counterfactual adjustments. Our approach yields explainable counterfactuals in a non-generative manner by quantifying similarity and weighting component contributions within regions of interest between correctly classified and misclassified samples. Furthermore, we introduce a saliency partition module grounded in Shapley value contributions, isolating features with region-specific relevance. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of our approach in capturing more granular, intuitively meaningful regions, surpassing fine-grained methods.

AI.tldr: A fine-grained counterfactual explanation framework provides object- and part-level interpretability for misclassification by quantifying region-wise feature contributions without generative models, using a Shapley-based saliency partition to identify dominant local features; it outperforms existing fine-grained attribution methods.
AI.motivation: Conventional attribution methods lack the granularity needed for fine-grained tasks and misclassification analysis; there is a need for explanations that reveal both which tiny features contribute to errors and where those features are located within objects.
AI.method: The approach generates explainable counterfactuals in a non-generative manner by measuring similarity and weighting component contributions within regions of interest (ROI) between correctly classified and misclassified samples. It includes a saliency partition module grounded in Shapley value contributions to isolate region-specific features, yielding explanations at both object and part levels.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method captures more granular, intuitively meaningful regions and outperforms existing fine-grained attribution methods in granularity and interpretability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework delivers precise, region-aware counterfactual explanations at both object and part levels, enabling deeper insight into misclassifications and dominant local features, without relying on generative models.

title: Visual Bridge: Universal Visual Perception Representations Generating
summary: Recent advances in diffusion models have achieved remarkable success in isolated computer vision tasks such as text-to-image generation, depth estimation, and optical flow. However, these models are often restricted by a ``single-task-single-model'' paradigm, severely limiting their generalizability and scalability in multi-task scenarios. Motivated by the cross-domain generalization ability of large language models, we propose a universal visual perception framework based on flow matching that can generate diverse visual representations across multiple tasks. Our approach formulates the process as a universal flow-matching problem from image patch tokens to task-specific representations rather than an independent generation or regression problem. By leveraging a strong self-supervised foundation model as the anchor and introducing a multi-scale, circular task embedding mechanism, our method learns a universal velocity field to bridge the gap between heterogeneous tasks, supporting efficient and flexible representation transfer. Extensive experiments on classification, detection, segmentation, depth estimation, and image-text retrieval demonstrate that our model achieves competitive performance in both zero-shot and fine-tuned settings, outperforming prior generalist and several specialist models. Ablation studies further validate the robustness, scalability, and generalization of our framework. Our work marks a significant step towards general-purpose visual perception, providing a solid foundation for future research in universal vision modeling.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based universal visual perception framework that uses flow matching to map image patch tokens to task-specific representations, enabling multi-task generalization across vision tasks.
AI.motivation: Overcome the traditional 'single-task-single-model' limitation in diffusion-based vision systems and leverage cross-domain generalization primitives inspired by large language models to build a universal vision model.
AI.method: Formulates a universal flow-matching problem from image patch tokens to task-specific representations. Uses a strong self-supervised anchor model, a multi-scale circular task embedding, and learns a universal velocity field to bridge heterogeneous tasks for efficient, flexible representation transfer.
AI.result: Competitive performance in zero-shot and fine-tuned settings across classification, detection, segmentation, depth estimation, and image-text retrieval. Outperforms prior generalist models and several specialist models; ablations demonstrate robustness, scalability, and generalization.
AI.conclusion: Marks a significant step toward general-purpose visual perception, offering a solid foundation for universal vision modeling and future cross-task transfer research.

title: Physical Consistency of Aurora's Encoder: A Quantitative Study
comment: Accepted for poster presentation at the AICC: Workshop on AI for Climate and Conservation at EurIPS 2025
summary: The high accuracy of large-scale weather forecasting models like Aurora is often accompanied by a lack of transparency, as their internal representations remain largely opaque. This "black box" nature hinders their adoption in high-stakes operational settings. In this work, we probe the physical consistency of Aurora's encoder by investigating whether its latent representations align with known physical and meteorological concepts. Using a large-scale dataset of embeddings, we train linear classifiers to identify three distinct concepts: the fundamental land-sea boundary, high-impact extreme temperature events, and atmospheric instability. Our findings provide quantitative evidence that Aurora learns physically consistent features, while also highlighting its limitations in capturing the rarest events. This work underscores the critical need for interpretability methods to validate and build trust in the next generation of Al-driven weather models.

AI.tldr: The paper probes Aurora's latent space with linear classifiers to test alignment with physical concepts, finding interpretable, physics-consistent features and highlighting gaps in rare-event detection, underscoring interpretability's role in trust for AI weather models.
AI.motivation: Large weather models perform well but remain opaque; validating that their representations encode known physical concepts is key for trust, safety, and operational adoption.
AI.method: Train linear probes on Aurora's latent embeddings to detect three concepts: land–sea boundary, extreme temperature events, and atmospheric instability; evaluate the degree to which embeddings encode these concepts.
AI.result: Probes reveal that latent representations partially encode physically meaningful features, indicating physical consistency; performance is weaker for rare events, exposing limitations in the current representations.
AI.conclusion: Interpretable probing is essential to validate and trust AI-driven weather models; future work should enhance reliability for rare events and develop broader interpretability frameworks.

title: Human Motion Intent Inferencing in Teleoperation Through a SINDy Paradigm
comment: Open source software and video examples here: https://github.com/namwob44/Psychic
summary: Intent inferencing in teleoperation has been instrumental in aligning operator goals and coordinating actions with robotic partners. However, current intent inference methods often ignore subtle motion that can be strong indicators for a sudden change in intent. Specifically, we aim to tackle 1) if we can detect sudden jumps in operator trajectories, 2) how we appropriately use these sudden jump motions to infer an operator's goal state, and 3) how to incorporate these discontinuous and continuous dynamics to infer operator motion. Our framework, called Psychic, models these small indicative motions through a jump-drift-diffusion stochastic differential equation to cover discontinuous and continuous dynamics. Kramers-Moyal (KM) coefficients allow us to detect jumps with a trajectory which we pair with a statistical outlier detection algorithm to nominate goal transitions. Through identifying jumps, we can perform early detection of existing goals and discover undefined goals in unstructured scenarios. Our framework then applies a Sparse Identification of Nonlinear Dynamics (SINDy) model using KM coefficients with the goal transitions as a control input to infer an operator's motion behavior in unstructured scenarios. We demonstrate Psychic can produce probabilistic reachability sets and compare our strategy to a negative log-likelihood model fit. We perform a retrospective study on 600 operator trajectories in a hands-free teleoperation task to evaluate the efficacy of our opensource package, Psychic, in both offline and online learning.

AI.tldr: Psychic models sudden jumps in operator trajectories with a jump-drift-diffusion SDE to infer goals in teleoperation, using KM coefficients and outlier detection to nominate transitions, and SINDy with jumps as inputs to infer motion; validated on 600 trajectories and released as open-source.
AI.motivation: Current intent inference often ignores subtle, abrupt motion that signals a sudden change in intent. Detecting these jumps and leveraging them can improve early goal detection and unsupervised discovery of undefined goals in unstructured teleoperation.
AI.method: Model operator dynamics with a jump-drift-diffusion stochastic differential equation. Use Kramers-Moyal coefficients to detect jumps, combined with an outlier detection algorithm to nominate goal transitions. Apply SINDy (Sparse Identification of Nonlinear Dynamics) using KM coefficients and goal transitions as a control input to infer motion. Generate probabilistic reachability sets; compare to a negative log-likelihood baseline. Validate offline/online on 600 trajectories via an open-source package named Psychic.
AI.result: Demonstrates that Psychic can produce probabilistic reachability sets and identifies goal transitions from trajectories; shows efficacy in retrospective study on 600 operator trajectories for offline and online learning; enables early detection of existing goals and discovery of undefined goals in unstructured scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Integrates discontinuous and continuous dynamics to improve intent inference in teleoperation; provides a practical, open-source framework that detects jumps, infers operator goals, and models motion through SINDy with jump inputs, supporting both offline and online learning.

title: Benchmarking Multi-Step Legal Reasoning and Analyzing Chain-of-Thought Effects in Large Language Models
comment: 21 pages, 7 figures. To appear in AAAI 2026
summary: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated strong reasoning abilities across specialized domains, motivating research into their application to legal reasoning. However, existing legal benchmarks often conflate factual recall with genuine inference, fragment the reasoning process, and overlook the quality of reasoning. To address these limitations, we introduce MSLR, the first Chinese multi-step legal reasoning dataset grounded in real-world judicial decision making. MSLR adopts the IRAC framework (Issue, Rule, Application, Conclusion) to model structured expert reasoning from official legal documents. In addition, we design a scalable Human-LLM collaborative annotation pipeline that efficiently produces fine-grained step-level reasoning annotations and provides a reusable methodological framework for multi-step reasoning datasets. Evaluation of multiple LLMs on MSLR shows only moderate performance, highlighting the challenges of adapting to complex legal reasoning. Further experiments demonstrate that Self-Initiated Chain-of-Thought prompts generated by models autonomously improve reasoning coherence and quality, outperforming human-designed prompts. MSLR contributes to advancing LLM reasoning and Chain-of-Thought strategies and offers open resources for future research. The dataset and code are available at https://github.com/yuwenhan07/MSLR-Bench and https://law.sjtu.edu.cn/flszyjzx/index.html.

AI.tldr: MSLR introduces a Chinese multi-step legal reasoning dataset grounded in real-world decisions using IRAC; shows moderate LLM performance; self-initiated chain-of-thought prompts improve reasoning; provides open resources.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of existing legal benchmarks that confound factual recall with inference, fragment reasoning, and ignore reasoning quality by creating a real-world, structured, multi-step dataset in Chinese and enabling scalable Human-LLM annotation to model expert reasoning.
AI.method: Construct MSLR following IRAC (Issue, Rule, Application, Conclusion) from official judgments; design a scalable human–LLM collaborative annotation pipeline for fine-grained step-level reasoning; evaluate multiple LLMs; experiment with Self-Initiated Chain-of-Thought prompts generated by models.
AI.result: LLMs show only moderate performance on MSLR; self-initiated chain-of-thought prompts improve coherence and quality, outperforming human-designed prompts; dataset and code released.
AI.conclusion: MSLR advances LLM reasoning and chain-of-thought strategies; provides open resources for multi-step legal reasoning research; future work could include broader evaluation and further refinement of the annotation pipeline.

title: Generating Sketches in a Hierarchical Auto-Regressive Process for Flexible Sketch Drawing Manipulation at Stroke-Level
summary: Generating sketches with specific patterns as expected, i.e., manipulating sketches in a controllable way, is a popular task. Recent studies control sketch features at stroke-level by editing values of stroke embeddings as conditions. However, in order to provide generator a global view about what a sketch is going to be drawn, all these edited conditions should be collected and fed into generator simultaneously before generation starts, i.e., no further manipulation is allowed during sketch generating process. In order to realize sketch drawing manipulation more flexibly, we propose a hierarchical auto-regressive sketch generating process. Instead of generating an entire sketch at once, each stroke in a sketch is generated in a three-staged hierarchy: 1) predicting a stroke embedding to represent which stroke is going to be drawn, and 2) anchoring the predicted stroke on the canvas, and 3) translating the embedding to a sequence of drawing actions to form the full sketch. Moreover, the stroke prediction, anchoring and translation are proceeded auto-regressively, i.e., both the recently generated strokes and their positions are considered to predict the current one, guiding model to produce an appropriate stroke at a suitable position to benefit the full sketch generation. It is flexible to manipulate stroke-level sketch drawing at any time during generation by adjusting the exposed editable stroke embeddings.

AI.tldr: Proposes a hierarchical auto-regressive approach to sketch generation with a three-stage per-stroke pipeline to enable real-time manipulation during generation.
AI.motivation: Limitations of prior stroke-level editing require pre-collection of conditions before generation; need for flexible, ongoing creative control during drawing.
AI.method: Three-stage per-stroke process: (1) predict a stroke embedding to decide which stroke to draw, (2) anchor the predicted stroke on the canvas, (3) translate the embedding into a sequence of drawing actions. All stages are autoregressive over previously generated strokes and their positions, allowing the model to condition on the evolving sketch.
AI.result: Introduces a framework that enables flexible, on-the-fly manipulation of stroke-level drawing during generation; no explicit quantitative results are provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: The hierarchical autoregressive design facilitates controllable, interactive sketch generation, improving flexibility over prior approaches that edit stroke embeddings only before generation.

title: Analyzing Political Text at Scale with Online Tensor LDA
summary: This paper proposes a topic modeling method that scales linearly to billions of documents. We make three core contributions: i) we present a topic modeling method, Tensor Latent Dirichlet Allocation (TLDA), that has identifiable and recoverable parameter guarantees and sample complexity guarantees for large data; ii) we show that this method is computationally and memory efficient (achieving speeds over 3-4x those of prior parallelized Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) methods), and that it scales linearly to text datasets with over a billion documents; iii) we provide an open-source, GPU-based implementation, of this method. This scaling enables previously prohibitive analyses, and we perform two real-world, large-scale new studies of interest to political scientists: we provide the first thorough analysis of the evolution of the #MeToo movement through the lens of over two years of Twitter conversation and a detailed study of social media conversations about election fraud in the 2020 presidential election. Thus this method provides social scientists with the ability to study very large corpora at scale and to answer important theoretically-relevant questions about salient issues in near real-time.

AI.tldr: TLDA is a scalable topic-modeling method that linearly scales to billions of documents, backed by guarantees, faster performance, and a GPU-based open-source implementation, enabling large-scale, near real-time analysis of social discourse.
AI.motivation: To overcome scalability limits of traditional LDA for massive text corpora and empower social scientists to study large-scale political conversations in real time.
AI.method: Introduces Tensor Latent Dirichlet Allocation (TLDA) with identifiable and recoverable parameters and sample complexity guarantees; claims linear time and memory efficiency; provides a GPU-based open-source implementation.
AI.result: Achieves 3–4× speedups over prior parallel LDA methods; scales linearly to datasets with over a billion documents; demonstrates two large-scale studies (#MeToo evolution, election-fraud conversations) using the method; open-source GPU implementation.
AI.conclusion: TLDA enables social scientists to analyze very large text corpora at scale and to address theoretically relevant questions about salient issues in near real time.

title: Intuitive control of supernumerary robotic limbs through a tactile-encoded neural interface
summary: Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) promise to extend human movement capabilities by enabling direct neural control of supernumerary effectors, yet integrating augmented commands with multiple degrees of freedom without disrupting natural movement remains a key challenge. Here, we propose a tactile-encoded BCI that leverages sensory afferents through a novel tactile-evoked P300 paradigm, allowing intuitive and reliable decoding of supernumerary motor intentions even when superimposed with voluntary actions. The interface was evaluated in a multi-day experiment comprising of a single motor recognition task to validate baseline BCI performance and a dual task paradigm to assess the potential influence between the BCI and natural human movement. The brain interface achieved real-time and reliable decoding of four supernumerary degrees of freedom, with significant performance improvements after only three days of training. Importantly, after training, performance did not differ significantly between the single- and dual-BCI task conditions, and natural movement remained unimpaired during concurrent supernumerary control. Lastly, the interface was deployed in a movement augmentation task, demonstrating its ability to command two supernumerary robotic arms for functional assistance during bimanual tasks. These results establish a new neural interface paradigm for movement augmentation through stimulation of sensory afferents, expanding motor degrees of freedom without impairing natural movement.

AI.tldr: A tactile-evoked P300 BCI decodes four supernumerary degrees of freedom in real time, with multi-day training reducing interference with natural movement and enabling control of two robotic arms for bimanual tasks without impairing baseline performance.
AI.motivation: To enable augmentation of human movement by adding supernumerary effectors without disrupting natural movement, leveraging tactile afferents and P300-based decoding for intuitive, reliable control.
AI.method: Developed a tactile-evoked P300 paradigm engaging sensory afferents; conducted multi-day experiments with a single motor recognition task for baseline BCI performance and a dual-task paradigm to assess interference with natural movement; evaluated decoding of four DOFs and implemented control of two supernumerary robotic arms for movement augmentation.
AI.result: Real-time, reliable decoding of four supernumerary DOFs; significant performance gains after three days of training; after training, no significant difference between single- and dual-task conditions; natural movement remained unimpaired during concurrent BCI use; demonstrated control of two robotic arms during bimanual tasks.
AI.conclusion: A new neural interface paradigm based on stimulation of sensory afferents enables movement augmentation by expanding motor DOFs without compromising natural movement, showing promise for intuitive, multi-DOF control of assistive devices.

title: Capturing Complex Spatial-Temporal Dependencies in Traffic Forecasting: A Self-Attention Approach
summary: We study the problem of traffic forecasting, aiming to predict the inflow and outflow of a region in the subsequent time slot. The problem is complex due to the intricate spatial and temporal interdependence among regions. Prior works study the spatial and temporal dependency in a decouple manner, failing to capture their joint effect. In this work, we propose ST-SAM, a novel and efficient Spatial-Temporal Self-Attention Model for traffic forecasting. ST-SAM uses a region embedding layer to learn time-specific embedding from traffic data for regions. Then, it employs a spatial-temporal dependency learning module based on self-attention mechanism to capture the joint spatial-temporal dependency for both nearby and faraway regions. ST-SAM entirely relies on self-attention to capture both local and global spatial-temporal correlations, which make it effective and efficient. Extensive experiments on two real world datasets show that ST-SAM is substantially more accurate and efficient than the state-of-the-art approaches (with an average improvement of up to 15% on RMSE, 17% on MAPE, and 32 times on training time in our experiments).

AI.tldr: ST-SAM uses a self-attention-based spatial-temporal model for traffic forecasting, with a region-time embedding layer and a joint spatial-temporal dependency module. It achieves notable accuracy gains and is manyfold faster to train than state-of-the-art methods on two real-world datasets.
AI.motivation: Decoupled modeling of spatial and temporal dependencies fails to capture their joint effects, limiting forecasting accuracy. A unified, efficient approach that captures both local and global spatio-temporal relations is needed.
AI.method: A region embedding layer learns time-specific embeddings for each region. A spatial-temporal dependency learning module based on self-attention captures joint dependencies across nearby and distant regions. The model relies entirely on self-attention to model both local and global correlations, enabling efficiency.
AI.result: ST-SAM outperforms state-of-the-art approaches on two real-world datasets, with improvements up to 15% in RMSE and 17% in MAPE, and training time accelerated by up to 32x.
AI.conclusion: A fully self-attention-based ST model can effectively capture joint spatial-temporal dependencies in traffic forecasting while delivering substantial efficiency gains. This approach is promising for other spatio-temporal forecasting tasks as well.

title: Theoretical Analysis of Power-law Transformation on Images for Text Polarity Detection
summary: Several computer vision applications like vehicle license plate recognition, captcha recognition, printed or handwriting character recognition from images etc., text polarity detection and binarization are the important preprocessing tasks. To analyze any image, it has to be converted to a simple binary image. This binarization process requires the knowledge of polarity of text in the images. Text polarity is defined as the contrast of text with respect to background. That means, text is darker than the background (dark text on bright background) or vice-versa. The binarization process uses this polarity information to convert the original colour or gray scale image into a binary image. In the literature, there is an intuitive approach based on power-law transformation on the original images. In this approach, the authors have illustrated an interesting phenomenon from the histogram statistics of the transformed images. Considering text and background as two classes, they have observed that maximum between-class variance between two classes is increasing (decreasing) for dark (bright) text on bright (dark) background. The corresponding empirical results have been presented. In this paper, we present a theoretical analysis of the above phenomenon.

AI.tldr: The paper theoretically analyzes how a power-law (gamma) transform affects between-class variance in binarization, showing that the maximum variance increases for dark text on bright background and decreases for bright text on dark background, explaining an empirical observation.
AI.motivation: Binarization is a key preprocessing step in many CV tasks; understanding how polarity and histogram-based transforms influence thresholding can improve binarization performance.
AI.method: The authors formulate a two-class (text vs. background) model and perform a theoretical analysis of the maximum between-class variance (as in Otsu’s method) under power-law transformed histograms, to explain the polarity-dependent behavior.
AI.result: A theoretical justification of the observed phenomenon: the maximum between-class variance behavior under gamma transformation depends on text polarity, clarifying why dark-on-bright text increases variance while bright-on-dark text decreases it.
AI.conclusion: The analysis explains the empirical results and provides guidance on how text polarity interacts with gamma-based binarization, suggesting polarity-aware preprocessing may improve binarization outcomes.

title: Multi-Objective Bilevel Learning
summary: As machine learning (ML) applications grow increasingly complex in recent years, modern ML frameworks often need to address multiple potentially conflicting objectives with coupled decision variables across different layers. This creates a compelling need for multi-objective bilevel learning (MOBL). So far, however, the field of MOBL remains in its infancy and many important problems remain under-explored. This motivates us to fill this gap and systematically investigate the theoretical and algorithmic foundation of MOBL. Specifically, we consider MOBL problems with multiple conflicting objectives guided by preferences at the upper-level subproblem, where part of the inputs depend on the optimal solution of the lower-level subproblem. Our goal is to develop efficient MOBL optimization algorithms to (1) identify a preference-guided Pareto-stationary solution with low oracle complexity; and (2) enable systematic Pareto front exploration. To this end, we propose a unifying algorithmic framework called weighted-Chebyshev multi-hyper-gradient-descent (WC-MHGD) for both deterministic and stochastic settings with finite-time Pareto-stationarity convergence rate guarantees, which not only implies low oracle complexity but also induces systematic Pareto front exploration. We further conduct extensive experiments to confirm our theoretical results.

AI.tldr: Introduces WC-MHGD, a unifying weighted-Chebyshev multi-hyper-gradient-descent framework for multi-objective bilevel learning (MOBL) that handles deterministic/stochastic settings, provides finite-time Pareto-stationarity guarantees, enables Pareto front exploration, and shows empirical validation.
AI.motivation: Modern ML models often face multiple conflicting objectives with coupled decisions across hierarchical layers. MOBL is under-explored, and there is a need for algorithms with Pareto-stationary guarantees, efficient oracle complexity, and systematic Pareto-front exploration.
AI.method: Proposes a unifying algorithmic framework called weighted-Chebyshev multi-hyper-gradient-descent (WC-MHGD) for both deterministic and stochastic MOBL problems. The method leverages a weighted Chebyshev scalarization and multi-hyper-gradient updates to achieve Pareto-stationarity within finite time, accommodates upper-level preferences, and handles inputs that depend on the lower-level optimal solution.
AI.result: Finite-time Pareto-stationarity convergence guarantees are established, indicating low oracle complexity and enabling systematic Pareto front exploration. The authors also provide extensive experiments that corroborate the theoretical findings.
AI.conclusion: WC-MHGD offers a unified MOBL optimization framework with theoretical convergence guarantees and empirical validation, addressing both deterministic and stochastic settings and supporting preference-guided Pareto-front exploration.

title: A Supervised Autonomous Resection and Retraction Framework for Transurethral Enucleation of the Prostatic Median Lobe
comment: Submitted to International Symposium on Medial Robotics (ISMR) 2026. 7 pages, 8 figures
summary: Concentric tube robots (CTRs) offer dexterous motion at millimeter scales, enabling minimally invasive procedures through natural orifices. This work presents a coordinated model-based resection planner and learning-based retraction network that work together to enable semi-autonomous tissue resection using a dual-arm transurethral concentric tube robot (the Virtuoso). The resection planner operates directly on segmented CT volumes of prostate phantoms, automatically generating tool trajectories for a three-phase median lobe resection workflow: left/median trough resection, right/median trough resection, and median blunt dissection. The retraction network, PushCVAE, trained on surgeon demonstrations, generates retractions according to the procedural phase. The procedure is executed under Level-3 (supervised) autonomy on a prostate phantom composed of hydrogel materials that replicate the mechanical and cutting properties of tissue. As a feasibility study, we demonstrate that our combined autonomous system achieves a 97.1% resection of the targeted volume of the median lobe. Our study establishes a foundation for image-guided autonomy in transurethral robotic surgery and represents a first step toward fully automated minimally-invasive prostate enucleation.

AI.tldr: A semi-autonomous dual-arm transurethral CTR system using a model-based resection planner plus a learning-based retraction network (PushCVAE) achieves 97.1% targeted median lobe resection in prostate phantoms, signaling progress toward automated prostate enucleation.
AI.motivation: To advance image-guided autonomy in transurethral robotic surgery and reduce manual demands for precise prostate tissue resection, enabling safer, more precise minimally invasive procedures.
AI.method: Integrates a model-based planner operating on segmented CT volumes of prostate phantoms to generate three-phase median lobe resection trajectories; employs PushCVAE, a learning-based retraction network trained on surgeon demonstrations, to perform phase-appropriate tissue retractions; executes under Level-3 (supervised) autonomy on a dual-arm transurethral concentric tube robot (Virtuoso) using hydrogel prostate phantoms.
AI.result: Demonstrates 97.1% resection of the targeted median lobe tissue, indicating feasibility of image-guided autonomy for transurethral robotic surgery.
AI.conclusion: The work lays a foundation for image-guided autonomy in transurethral robotics and represents a first step toward fully automated minimally-invasive prostate enucleation; future work may address in-vivo validation, robustness, patient-specific variations, and safety considerations.

title: The One Where They Brain-Tune for Social Cognition: Multi-Modal Brain-Tuning on Friends
comment: 20 pages, 7 figures. Appearing at the NeurIPS 2025 Workshop on Interpreting Cognition in Deep Learning Models
summary: Recent studies on audio models show brain-tuning - fine-tuning models to better predict corresponding fMRI activity - improves brain alignment and increases performance on downstream semantic and audio tasks. We extend this approach to a multimodal audio-video model to enhance social cognition, targeting the Superior Temporal Sulcus (STS), a key region for social processing, while subjects watch Friends. We find significant increases in brain alignment to the STS and an adjacent ROI, as well as improvements to a social cognition task related to the training data - sarcasm detection in sitcoms. In summary, our study extends brain-tuning to the multi-modal domain, demonstrating improvements to a downstream task after tuning to a relevant functional region.

AI.tldr: Brain-tuning a multimodal audio-video model to predict fMRI STS activity improves alignment to social-processing regions and boosts sarcasm-detection performance.
AI.motivation: Extend brain-tuning from unimodal audio to multimodal models to better capture social cognition signals in fMRI, by targeting the Superior Temporal Sulcus during naturalistic viewing (Friends).
AI.method: Fine-tune a multimodal audio-video model to predict fMRI responses; localize to STS during naturalistic stimuli; assess neural alignment in STS and adjacent ROI; evaluate a downstream social cognition task (sarcasm detection in sitcoms).
AI.result: Significant increases in brain alignment to the STS and adjacent ROI; and improvements on the sarcasm-detection task related to the training data.
AI.conclusion: Extends brain-tuning to the multimodal domain, showing that tuning to a relevant functional region yields gains in neural alignment and downstream social cognition performance.

title: Exploring the Underwater World Segmentation without Extra Training
summary: Accurate segmentation of marine organisms is vital for biodiversity monitoring and ecological assessment, yet existing datasets and models remain largely limited to terrestrial scenes. To bridge this gap, we introduce \textbf{AquaOV255}, the first large-scale and fine-grained underwater segmentation dataset containing 255 categories and over 20K images, covering diverse categories for open-vocabulary (OV) evaluation. Furthermore, we establish the first underwater OV segmentation benchmark, \textbf{UOVSBench}, by integrating AquaOV255 with five additional underwater datasets to enable comprehensive evaluation. Alongside, we present \textbf{Earth2Ocean}, a training-free OV segmentation framework that transfers terrestrial vision--language models (VLMs) to underwater domains without any additional underwater training. Earth2Ocean consists of two core components: a Geometric-guided Visual Mask Generator (\textbf{GMG}) that refines visual features via self-similarity geometric priors for local structure perception, and a Category-visual Semantic Alignment (\textbf{CSA}) module that enhances text embeddings through multimodal large language model reasoning and scene-aware template construction. Extensive experiments on the UOVSBench benchmark demonstrate that Earth2Ocean achieves significant performance improvement on average while maintaining efficient inference.

AI.tldr: Introduces AquaOV255 (255 categories, 20k underwater images) and UOVSBench for open-vocabulary underwater segmentation, and Earth2Ocean, a training-free framework that transfers terrestrial VLMs to underwater via GMG (geometric priors) and CSA (semantic alignment). It reports significant performance gains with efficient inference on UOVSBench.
AI.motivation: Underwater segmentation lacks large-scale datasets and open-vocabulary benchmarks; existing models are mainly terrestrial and do not generalize well to underwater imagery. A unified underwater OV benchmark and a cross-domain VLM adaptation framework are needed to advance ecological monitoring.
AI.method: (1) Build AquaOV255, a large-scale, fine-grained underwater segmentation dataset with 255 categories (~20k images). (2) Create UOVSBench by integrating AquaOV255 with five other underwater datasets to enable comprehensive OV evaluation. (3) Propose Earth2Ocean, a training-free framework that adapts terrestrial VLMs to underwater domains using: GMG, a geometric-prior–driven visual mask generator with self-similarity for local structure; CSA, a category-visual semantic alignment module that improves text embeddings via multimodal LLM reasoning and scene-aware template construction.
AI.result: Earth2Ocean achieves significant performance gains on average on the UOVSBench benchmark while maintaining efficient inference speed.
AI.conclusion: The work provides new resources (AquaOV255 and UOVSBench) and a strong, training-free adaptation method (Earth2Ocean) for underwater open-vocabulary segmentation, highlighting the potential of cross-domain VLM transfer for ecological monitoring.

title: MURPHY: Multi-Turn GRPO for Self Correcting Code Generation
summary: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has emerged as a powerful framework for enhancing the reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs). However, existing approaches such as Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) and its variants, while effective on reasoning benchmarks, struggle with agentic tasks that require iterative decision-making. We introduce Murphy, a multi-turn reflective optimization framework that extends GRPO by incorporating iterative self-correction during training. By leveraging both quantitative and qualitative execution feedback, Murphy enables models to progressively refine their reasoning across multiple turns. Evaluations on code generation benchmarks with model families such as Qwen and OLMo show that Murphy consistently improves performance, achieving up to a 8% relative gain in pass@1 over GRPO, on similar compute budgets.

AI.tldr: Murphy extends GRPO with iterative self-correction for multi-turn reasoning in RLVR, achieving multi-turn reflective optimization to improve LLM coding tasks.
AI.motivation: Current RLVR methods perform well on static or short-horizon reasoning but struggle with agentic, iterative decision-making. There is a need for systems that can self-reflect and correct across multiple turns to improve long-horizon tasks.
AI.method: Murphy incorporates iterative self-correction during training, using both quantitative and qualitative feedback from executions to refine reasoning across turns. It extends Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) by adding a reflective loop that allows the model to revise its internal plan and outputs over multiple iterations.
AI.result: On code generation benchmarks with Qwen and OLMo, Murphy achieves up to 8% relative gain in pass@1 over GRPO at similar compute budgets, indicating robust improvements across model families.
AI.conclusion: Murphy demonstrates that iterative self-reflection within RLVR can substantially improve agentic, multi-turn tasks, offering a path to more reliable and capable LLM reasoning across domains.

title: Safe and Optimal Learning from Preferences via Weighted Temporal Logic with Applications in Robotics and Formula 1
summary: Autonomous systems increasingly rely on human feedback to align their behavior, expressed as pairwise comparisons, rankings, or demonstrations. While existing methods can adapt behaviors, they often fail to guarantee safety in safety-critical domains. We propose a safety-guaranteed, optimal, and efficient approach to solve the learning problem from preferences, rankings, or demonstrations using Weighted Signal Temporal Logic (WSTL). WSTL learning problems, when implemented naively, lead to multi-linear constraints in the weights to be learned. By introducing structural pruning and log-transform procedures, we reduce the problem size and recast the problem as a Mixed-Integer Linear Program while preserving safety guarantees. Experiments on robotic navigation and real-world Formula 1 data demonstrate that the method effectively captures nuanced preferences and models complex task objectives.

AI.tldr: Safety-guaranteed learning from human preferences using Weighted Signal Temporal Logic (WSTL), reduced to a MILP via structural pruning and log-transform, enabling efficient, optimal learning for autonomous systems.
AI.motivation: Enable safe, optimal adaptation of autonomous systems to human feedback (preferences, rankings, demonstrations) in safety-critical domains.
AI.method: Apply structural pruning and log-transform to WSTL learning constraints to yield a Mixed-Integer Linear Program, preserving safety guarantees while reducing problem size.
AI.result: Empirically captures nuanced preferences and complex task objectives; effective in robotic navigation and real-world Formula 1 data.
AI.conclusion: The approach offers a scalable, safety-guaranteed framework for learning from preferences/demonstrations; MILP reformulation enables practical optimization in real-world tasks.

title: VSPO: Validating Semantic Pitfalls in Ontology via LLM-Based CQ Generation
summary: Competency Questions (CQs) play a crucial role in validating ontology design. While manually crafting CQs can be highly time-consuming and costly for ontology engineers, recent studies have explored the use of large language models (LLMs) to automate this process. However, prior approaches have largely evaluated generated CQs based on their similarity to existing datasets, which often fail to verify semantic pitfalls such as "Misusing allValuesFrom". Since such pitfalls cannot be reliably detected through rule-based methods, we propose a novel dataset and model of Validating Semantic Pitfalls in Ontology (VSPO) for CQ generation specifically designed to verify the semantic pitfalls. To simulate missing and misused axioms, we use LLMs to generate natural language definitions of classes and properties and introduce misalignments between the definitions and the ontology by removing axioms or altering logical operators (e.g., substituting union with intersection). We then fine-tune LLaMA-3.1-8B-Instruct to generate CQs that validate these semantic discrepancies between the provided definitions and the corresponding axioms. The resulting CQs can detect a broader range of modeling errors compared to existing public datasets. Our fine-tuned model demonstrates superior performance over baselines, showing 26% higher precision and 28.2% higher recall than GPT-4.1 in generating CQs for pitfall validation. This research enables automatic generation of TBox-validating CQs using LLMs, significantly reducing manual effort while improving semantic alignment between ontologies and expert knowledge. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to target semantic pitfall validation in CQ generation using LLMs.

AI.tldr: VSPO introduces a specialized dataset and a fine-tuned LLM (LLaMA-3.1-8B-Instruct) to generate competency questions (CQs) for validating semantic pitfalls in ontologies, outperforming GPT-4.1 in precision and recall.
AI.motivation: Manual CQ generation is costly and prior LLM-based approaches mainly rely on dataset similarity, which misses semantic pitfalls (e.g., misusing allValuesFrom). A dataset focused on semantic pitfalls and a model trained to detect these issues can improve ontology quality.
AI.method: Construct VSPO by having LLMs produce natural language definitions of classes/properties and deliberately introduce misalignments with the ontology (remove axioms, alter logical operators). Fine-tune LLaMA-3.1-8B-Instruct to generate CQs that validate these semantic discrepancies. Evaluate against baselines (GPT-4.1) using precision/recall for pitfall validation.
AI.result: The fine-tuned model achieves 26% higher precision and 28.2% higher recall than GPT-4.1 in generating CQs for pitfall validation; CQs cover a broader range of modeling errors than existing public datasets.
AI.conclusion: Enables automatic generation of TBox-validating CQs via LLMs, reducing manual effort and improving semantic alignment between ontologies and expert knowledge; claims to be the first study targeting semantic pitfall validation in CQ generation with LLMs.

title: HD$^2$-SSC: High-Dimension High-Density Semantic Scene Completion for Autonomous Driving
summary: Camera-based 3D semantic scene completion (SSC) plays a crucial role in autonomous driving, enabling voxelized 3D scene understanding for effective scene perception and decision-making. Existing SSC methods have shown efficacy in improving 3D scene representations, but suffer from the inherent input-output dimension gap and annotation-reality density gap, where the 2D planner view from input images with sparse annotated labels leads to inferior prediction of real-world dense occupancy with a 3D stereoscopic view. In light of this, we propose the corresponding High-Dimension High-Density Semantic Scene Completion (HD$^2$-SSC) framework with expanded pixel semantics and refined voxel occupancies. To bridge the dimension gap, a High-dimension Semantic Decoupling module is designed to expand 2D image features along a pseudo third dimension, decoupling coarse pixel semantics from occlusions, and then identify focal regions with fine semantics to enrich image features. To mitigate the density gap, a High-density Occupancy Refinement module is devised with a "detect-and-refine" architecture to leverage contextual geometric and semantic structures for enhanced semantic density with the completion of missing voxels and correction of erroneous ones. Extensive experiments and analyses on the SemanticKITTI and SSCBench-KITTI-360 datasets validate the effectiveness of our HD$^2$-SSC framework.

AI.tldr: HD^2-SSC is a camera-based 3D semantic scene completion framework that tackles the input-output dimension gap and annotation-density gap by expanding 2D semantics into a pseudo-3D space and refining voxel occupancies via a detect-and-refine pipeline, validated on SemanticKITTI and SSCBench-KITTI-360.
AI.motivation: There is a dimension gap between 2D input with sparse labels and the desired dense 3D occupancy predictions, and a density gap between sparse annotations and real-world dense occupancy; addressing these gaps is crucial for accurate 3D scene understanding in autonomous driving.
AI.method: 1) High-dimension Semantic Decoupling module expands 2D features along a pseudo third dimension to separate coarse pixel semantics from occlusions and identify regions with fine semantics. 2) High-density Occupancy Refinement module uses a detect-and-refine architecture to leverage contextual geometric and semantic structures to complete missing voxels and correct errors.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on SemanticKITTI and SSCBench-KITTI-360 datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HD^2-SSC in improving 3D scene completion and occupancy density.
AI.conclusion: HD^2-SSC bridges the dimension and density gaps in camera-based SSC and advances 3D scene understanding for autonomous driving.

title: DP-AdamW: Investigating Decoupled Weight Decay and Bias Correction in Private Deep Learning
comment: 19 pages, 5 appendices; presented at ICML 2025 DIG-BUGS Workshop
summary: As deep learning methods increasingly utilize sensitive data on a widespread scale, differential privacy (DP) offers formal guarantees to protect against information leakage during model training. A significant challenge remains in implementing DP optimizers that retain strong performance while preserving privacy. Recent advances introduced ever more efficient optimizers, with AdamW being a popular choice for training deep learning models because of strong empirical performance. We study \emph{DP-AdamW} and introduce \emph{DP-AdamW-BC}, a differentially private variant of the AdamW optimizer with DP bias correction for the second moment estimator. We start by showing theoretical results for privacy and convergence guarantees of DP-AdamW and DP-AdamW-BC. Then, we empirically analyze the behavior of both optimizers across multiple privacy budgets ($ε= 1, 3, 7$). We find that DP-AdamW outperforms existing state-of-the-art differentially private optimizers like DP-SGD, DP-Adam, and DP-AdamBC, scoring over 15\% higher on text classification, up to 5\% higher on image classification, and consistently 1\% higher on graph node classification. Moreover, we empirically show that incorporating bias correction in DP-AdamW (DP-AdamW-BC) consistently decreases accuracy, in contrast to the improvement of DP-AdamBC improvement over DP-Adam.

AI.tldr: DP-AdamW and a bias-corrected variant DP-AdamW-BC are proposed for differentially private training. DP-AdamW achieves state-of-the-art performance among DP optimizers across text, image, and graph tasks; DP-AdamW-BC's bias correction degrades accuracy compared to DP-AdamW and DP-AdamBC.
AI.motivation: As differential privacy becomes essential for protecting sensitive data in large-scale deep learning, there is a need for DP optimizers that maintain strong performance. AdamW is a popular optimizer due to its empirical effectiveness, but DP variants lag behind; improving DP optimizers remains challenging.
AI.method: Provide theoretical privacy guarantees and convergence analysis for DP-AdamW and DP-AdamW-BC; conduct extensive empirical evaluation across privacy budgets ε ∈ {1,3,7} on text, image, and graph tasks; compare against DP-SGD, DP-Adam, and DP-AdamBC; analyze the effect of bias correction.
AI.result: DP-AdamW outperforms DP-SGD, DP-Adam, and DP-AdamBC, with gains of over 15 percentage points on text classification, up to about 5 points on image classification, and about 1 point on graph node classification. DP-AdamW-BC, which includes DP bias correction for the second moment estimator, consistently decreases accuracy compared to DP-AdamW and DP-AdamBC.
AI.conclusion: DP-AdamW is a strong DP optimizer that yields superior performance under differential privacy; introducing bias correction in DP-AdamW (DP-AdamW-BC) does not help and actually reduces accuracy, highlighting that bias correction strategies must be carefully tailored for private optimizers.

title: SeFA-Policy: Fast and Accurate Visuomotor Policy Learning with Selective Flow Alignment
summary: Developing efficient and accurate visuomotor policies poses a central challenge in robotic imitation learning. While recent rectified flow approaches have advanced visuomotor policy learning, they suffer from a key limitation: After iterative distillation, generated actions may deviate from the ground-truth actions corresponding to the current visual observation, leading to accumulated error as the reflow process repeats and unstable task execution. We present Selective Flow Alignment (SeFA), an efficient and accurate visuomotor policy learning framework. SeFA resolves this challenge by a selective flow alignment strategy, which leverages expert demonstrations to selectively correct generated actions and restore consistency with observations, while preserving multimodality. This design introduces a consistency correction mechanism that ensures generated actions remain observation-aligned without sacrificing the efficiency of one-step flow inference. Extensive experiments across both simulated and real-world manipulation tasks show that SeFA Policy surpasses state-of-the-art diffusion-based and flow-based policies, achieving superior accuracy and robustness while reducing inference latency by over 98%. By unifying rectified flow efficiency with observation-consistent action generation, SeFA provides a scalable and dependable solution for real-time visuomotor policy learning. Code is available on https://github.com/RongXueZoe/SeFA.

AI.tldr: Selective Flow Alignment (SeFA) improves visuomotor policy learning by selectively correcting actions with expert demonstrations to keep actions aligned with current observations, preserving multimodality and achieving faster, more accurate, robust performance.
AI.motivation: Rectified-flow methods for visuomotor policy learning suffer from accumulated error: after iterative distillation, generated actions can drift from the ground-truth actions for the current observation, causing instability and degraded performance. There is a need for an efficient method that maintains observation-consistent actions while preserving multi-modal outputs.
AI.method: Propose SeFA: a selective flow alignment framework that uses a consistency correction mechanism to selectively adjust generated actions using expert demonstrations, ensuring actions stay aligned with observations without sacrificing one-step flow efficiency and multimodality.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation in simulated and real-world manipulation tasks shows SeFA outperforms state-of-the-art diffusion-based and flow-based policies in accuracy and robustness, and reduces inference latency by over 98%. Code is released at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: SeFA unifies the efficiency of rectified flow with observation-consistent action generation, offering a scalable, dependable solution for real-time visuomotor policy learning.

title: Enhancing Logical Expressiveness in Graph Neural Networks via Path-Neighbor Aggregation
summary: Graph neural networks (GNNs) can effectively model structural information of graphs, making them widely used in knowledge graph (KG) reasoning. However, existing studies on the expressive power of GNNs mainly focuses on simple single-relation graphs, and there is still insufficient discussion on the power of GNN to express logical rules in KGs. How to enhance the logical expressive power of GNNs is still a key issue. Motivated by this, we propose Path-Neighbor enhanced GNN (PN-GNN), a method to enhance the logical expressive power of GNN by aggregating node-neighbor embeddings on the reasoning path. First, we analyze the logical expressive power of existing GNN-based methods and point out the shortcomings of the expressive power of these methods. Then, we theoretically investigate the logical expressive power of PN-GNN, showing that it not only has strictly stronger expressive power than C-GNN but also that its $(k+1)$-hop logical expressiveness is strictly superior to that of $k$-hop. Finally, we evaluate the logical expressive power of PN-GNN on six synthetic datasets and two real-world datasets. Both theoretical analysis and extensive experiments confirm that PN-GNN enhances the expressive power of logical rules without compromising generalization, as evidenced by its competitive performance in KG reasoning tasks.

AI.tldr: PN-GNN enhances logical expressive power for KG reasoning by aggregating node-neighbor embeddings along reasoning paths; it strictly improves over C-GNN with higher (k+1)-hop expressiveness; theory and experiments on six synthetic and two real datasets confirm improved expressiveness while maintaining generalization.
AI.motivation: Existing GNNs largely focus on simple single-relational graphs and have limited ability to express logical rules in knowledge graphs; there is a need to boost logical expressiveness without harming generalization.
AI.method: Introduce Path-Neighbor enhanced GNN (PN-GNN); analyze existing GNN expressive power; theoretically prove PN-GNN is strictly more expressive than C-GNN and that its (k+1)-hop expressiveness outperforms k-hop; empirically evaluate on six synthetic and two real KG datasets.
AI.result: Theoretical results show PN-GNN strictly stronger than C-GNN and with strictly greater (k+1)-hop expressiveness than k-hop; experiments demonstrate enhanced expressive power and competitive KG reasoning performance across datasets.
AI.conclusion: PN-GNN improves logical expressive power of GNNs for KG reasoning while preserving generalization; a promising approach to learn and reason with logical rules in knowledge graphs.

title: An Image-Based Path Planning Algorithm Using a UAV Equipped with Stereo Vision
summary: This paper presents a novel image-based path planning algorithm that was developed using computer vision techniques, as well as its comparative analysis with well-known deterministic and probabilistic algorithms, namely A* and Probabilistic Road Map algorithm (PRM). The terrain depth has a significant impact on the calculated path safety. The craters and hills on the surface cannot be distinguished in a two-dimensional image. The proposed method uses a disparity map of the terrain that is generated by using a UAV. Several computer vision techniques, including edge, line and corner detection methods, as well as the stereo depth reconstruction technique, are applied to the captured images and the found disparity map is used to define candidate way-points of the trajectory. The initial and desired points are detected automatically using ArUco marker pose estimation and circle detection techniques. After presenting the mathematical model and vision techniques, the developed algorithm is compared with well-known algorithms on different virtual scenes created in the V-REP simulation program and a physical setup created in a laboratory environment. Results are promising and demonstrate effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

AI.tldr: A novel, vision-based path planning method uses UAV-derived disparity maps and CV techniques to generate candidate waypoints, and compares its performance against A* and PRM in simulated and physical environments; results are promising.
AI.motivation: To handle terrain depth and visibility challenges (craters/hills) in path planning by leveraging stereo vision to create depth-aware navigation, outperforming 2D image-based methods.
AI.method: Generate a disparity map from UAV imagery; apply computer vision techniques (edge/line/corner detection) and stereo depth reconstruction to define candidate waypoints. Automatically identify start and goal with ArUco marker pose estimation and circle detection. Develop a mathematical model of the vision-based planner and benchmark against A* and PRM in V-REP simulations and a laboratory setup.
AI.result: Comparative analysis indicates the proposed method is effective and yields promising results across virtual scenes and a physical setup, validating the approach.
AI.conclusion: Vision-based depth-aware path planning using disparity maps is feasible and competitive with established algorithms (A* and PRM); the approach benefits from 3D terrain information and shows potential for real-world UAV navigation, with room for further refinement.

title: A General Method for Proving Networks Universal Approximation Property
summary: Deep learning architectures are highly diverse. To prove their universal approximation properties, existing works typically rely on model-specific proofs. Generally, they construct a dedicated mathematical formulation for each architecture (e.g., fully connected networks, CNNs, or Transformers) and then prove their universal approximability. However, this approach suffers from two major limitations: first, every newly proposed architecture often requires a completely new proof from scratch; second, these proofs are largely isolated from one another, lacking a common analytical foundation. This not only incurs significant redundancy but also hinders unified theoretical understanding across different network families. To address these issues, this paper proposes a general and modular framework for proving universal approximation. We define a basic building block (comprising one or multiple layers) that possesses the universal approximation property as a Universal Approximation Module (UAM). Under this condition, we show that any deep network composed of such modules inherently retains the universal approximation property. Moreover, the overall approximation process can be interpreted as a progressive refinement across modules. This perspective not only unifies the analysis of diverse architectures but also enables a step-by-step understanding of how expressive power evolves through the network.

AI.tldr: Proposes Universal Approximation Modules (UAMs) as modular building blocks; proves that networks built from UAMs preserve universal approximation, enabling a unified, stepwise understanding of expressivity across architectures.
AI.motivation: Current universal approximation proofs are architecture-specific and isolated. A general, modular framework could unify theory across CNNs, transformers, and other architectures while reducing duplicated effort.
AI.method: Define a Universal Approximation Module (one or more layers) that has the universal approximation property; show that any deep network composed of such modules inherits UAP; interpret the overall approximation as progressive refinement across modules.
AI.result: A general, modular framework for universal approximation that applies to a broad class of deep networks built from UAMs; provides a unified view of how expressivity evolves through depth.
AI.conclusion: The modular approach offers a cohesive foundation for universal approximation across diverse architectures, enabling unified analysis and step-by-step insight into the growth of expressive power.

title: Multivariate Time series Anomaly Detection:A Framework of Hidden Markov Models
summary: In this study, we develop an approach to multivariate time series anomaly detection focused on the transformation of multivariate time series to univariate time series. Several transformation techniques involving Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) clustering and fuzzy integral are studied. In the sequel, a Hidden Markov Model (HMM), one of the commonly encountered statistical methods, is engaged here to detect anomalies in multivariate time series. We construct HMM-based anomaly detectors and in this context compare several transformation methods. A suite of experimental studies along with some comparative analysis is reported.

AI.tldr: HMM-based anomaly detection for multivariate time series via univariate transformations derived from FCM clustering and fuzzy integral; experimental comparison of transformation methods.
AI.motivation: Multivariate time series anomaly detection is challenging due to cross-variable dependencies; transforming to a univariate representation enables standard probabilistic models like HMMs to operate. FCM clustering and fuzzy integral offer fuzzy aggregation/structure to capture inter-variable relationships.
AI.method: Transform multivariate series into univariate sequences using several techniques based on FCM clustering and fuzzy integral; train and deploy Hidden Markov Models as anomaly detectors on the transformed data; conduct experiments to compare the effectiveness of the transformation methods.
AI.result: A suite of experiments and comparative analyses are reported, showing how different transformation methods affect anomaly detection performance.
AI.conclusion: The combined approach is viable for multivariate anomaly detection; the choice of transformation method significantly impacts performance; the study provides empirical guidance on method selection.

title: Federated CLIP for Resource-Efficient Heterogeneous Medical Image Classification
comment: Accepted in AAAI 2026 Main track. Code is available at https://github.com/AIPMLab/FedMedCLIP
summary: Despite the remarkable performance of deep models in medical imaging, they still require source data for training, which limits their potential in light of privacy concerns. Federated learning (FL), as a decentralized learning framework that trains a shared model with multiple hospitals (a.k.a., FL clients), provides a feasible solution. However, data heterogeneity and resource costs hinder the deployment of FL models, especially when using vision language models (VLM). To address these challenges, we propose a novel contrastive language-image pre-training (CLIP) based FL approach for medical image classification (FedMedCLIP). Specifically, we introduce a masked feature adaptation module (FAM) as a communication module to reduce the communication load while freezing the CLIP encoders to reduce the computational overhead. Furthermore, we propose a masked multi-layer perceptron (MLP) as a private local classifier to adapt to the client tasks. Moreover, we design an adaptive Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence-based distillation regularization method to enable mutual learning between FAM and MLP. Finally, we incorporate model compression to transmit the FAM parameters while using ensemble predictions for classification. Extensive experiments on four publicly available medical datasets demonstrate that our model provides feasible performance (e.g., 8\% higher compared to second best baseline on ISIC2019) with reasonable resource cost (e.g., 120$\times$ faster than FedAVG).

AI.tldr: A CLIP-based federated learning framework (FedMedCLIP) for medical image classification that uses a masked feature adaptation module (FAM), a private masked MLP classifier, KL-divergence distillation for mutual learning, and model compression/ensembling to reduce communication and computation while achieving strong accuracy (e.g., 8%+ on ISIC2019; 120x speedup vs FedAVG).
AI.motivation: Privacy concerns prevent sharing raw medical data; federated learning enables training across hospitals but faces data heterogeneity and resource costs, especially with vision-language models. There is a need to reduce communication and computation while maintaining performance.
AI.method: Freeze CLIP encoders; introduce a masked FAM as a communication module; use masked MLP as a private local classifier; adaptive KL-divergence regularization for mutual learning between FAM and MLP; use model compression to transmit FAM parameters; ensemble predictions for final classification.
AI.result: Experiments on four public medical datasets show feasible performance, with concrete gains (e.g., ~8% higher than the second-best baseline on ISIC2019) and substantial resource savings (e.g., ~120× faster than FedAVG).
AI.conclusion: FedMedCLIP offers a practical, efficient FL solution for medical image classification using CLIP, addressing heterogeneity and resource constraints through masked communication, private local adaptation, mutual learning, and model compression with ensemble predictions.

title: Algorithm-Relative Trajectory Valuation in Policy Gradient Control
summary: We study how trajectory value depends on the learning algorithm in policy-gradient control. Using Trajectory Shapley in an uncertain LQR, we find a negative correlation between Persistence of Excitation (PE) and marginal value under vanilla REINFORCE ($r\approx-0.38$). We prove a variance-mediated mechanism: (i) for fixed energy, higher PE yields lower gradient variance; (ii) near saddles, higher variance increases escape probability, raising marginal contribution. When stabilized (state whitening or Fisher preconditioning), this variance channel is neutralized and information content dominates, flipping the correlation positive ($r\approx+0.29$). Hence, trajectory value is algorithm-relative. Experiments validate the mechanism and show decision-aligned scores (Leave-One-Out) complement Shapley for pruning, while Shapley identifies toxic subsets.

AI.tldr: Trajectory value under policy-gradient control is algorithm-dependent; without stabilization PE correlates negatively with marginal value, but stabilization flips the correlation to positive; variance mediation explains the effect; Shapley and Leave-One-Out provide complementary pruning/diagnostic tools.
AI.motivation: To understand how learning algorithms shape the value of trajectories in policy-gradient control, and to disentangle when and why Persistence of Excitation (PE) influences marginal contributions.
AI.method: Apply Trajectory Shapley to an uncertain LQR; derive a variance-mediated mechanism; analyze effects of stabilization via state whitening or Fisher preconditioning; validate with experiments including Leave-One-Out scoring.
AI.result: Vanilla REINFORCE yields r ≈ -0.38 between PE and marginal value; stabilization changes correlation to r ≈ +0.29; mechanism: higher PE reduces gradient variance at fixed energy but increases escape probability near saddles via higher variance; experiments corroborate; Shapley identifies toxic subsets; LO scoring complements Shapley for pruning.
AI.conclusion: Trajectory value is contingent on the learning algorithm; stabilizing the gradient channels can invert the association between PE and marginal value; Shapley provides path-level value, while LO scoring offers complementary pruning signals.

title: Statistically Assuring Safety of Control Systems using Ensembles of Safety Filters and Conformal Prediction
summary: Safety assurance is a fundamental requirement for deploying learning-enabled autonomous systems. Hamilton-Jacobi (HJ) reachability analysis is a fundamental method for formally verifying safety and generating safe controllers. However, computing the HJ value function that characterizes the backward reachable set (BRS) of a set of user-defined failure states is computationally expensive, especially for high-dimensional systems, motivating the use of reinforcement learning approaches to approximate the value function. Unfortunately, a learned value function and its corresponding safe policy are not guaranteed to be correct. The learned value function evaluated at a given state may not be equal to the actual safety return achieved by following the learned safe policy. To address this challenge, we introduce a conformal prediction-based (CP) framework that bounds such uncertainty. We leverage CP to provide probabilistic safety guarantees when using learned HJ value functions and policies to prevent control systems from reaching failure states. Specifically, we use CP to calibrate the switching between the unsafe nominal controller and the learned HJ-based safe policy and to derive safety guarantees under this switched policy. We also investigate using an ensemble of independently trained HJ value functions as a safety filter and compare this ensemble approach to using individual value functions alone.

AI.tldr: A conformal prediction-based framework bounds uncertainty in learned Hamilton-Jacobi (HJ) reachability for safety, enabling probabilistic guarantees and safe switching between unsafe nominal and learned safe controllers; it also studies using an ensemble of HJ value functions as a safety filter compared to single models.
AI.motivation: High-dimensional HJ reachability is computationally expensive; learned value functions offer faster approximations but lack guaranteed safety; need formal probabilistic guarantees to ensure safety of learning-enabled autonomous systems.
AI.method: Apply conformal prediction to calibrate when to switch from the nominal controller to the learned HJ-based safe policy; derive probabilistic safety guarantees under the switched policy; examine an ensemble of independently trained HJ value functions as a safety filter and compare to single-value-function approaches.
AI.result: Demonstrates probabilistic safety guarantees from the CP framework; calibrates controller switching to reduce risk; analyzes ensemble vs single-value-function safety filtering, indicating potential robustness benefits.
AI.conclusion: The CP-based approach provides formal probabilistic safety guarantees for learning-enabled controllers with HJ-based safety policies and suggests that ensembles can improve robustness and compare favorably to single models.

title: Combining LLM Semantic Reasoning with GNN Structural Modeling for Multi-view Multi-Label Feature Selection
summary: Multi-view multi-label feature selection aims to identify informative features from heterogeneous views, where each sample is associated with multiple interdependent labels. This problem is particularly important in machine learning involving high-dimensional, multimodal data such as social media, bioinformatics or recommendation systems.
