AI.conclusion: HSPAG provides data-efficient, controllable molecular generation/editing by hierarchical structure-property alignment, effective under sparse property annotations, with demonstration in real-world scenarios.

title: Beyond Distributions: Geometric Action Control for Continuous Reinforcement Learning
summary: Gaussian policies have dominated continuous control in deep reinforcement learning (RL), yet they suffer from a fundamental mismatch: their unbounded support requires ad-hoc squashing functions that distort the geometry of bounded action spaces. While von Mises-Fisher (vMF) distributions offer a theoretically grounded alternative on the sphere, their reliance on Bessel functions and rejection sampling hinders practical adoption. We propose \textbf{Geometric Action Control (GAC)}, a novel action generation paradigm that preserves the geometric benefits of spherical distributions while \textit{simplifying computation}. GAC decomposes action generation into a direction vector and a learnable concentration parameter, enabling efficient interpolation between deterministic actions and uniform spherical noise. This design reduces parameter count from \(2d\) to \(d+1\), and avoids the \(O(dk)\) complexity of vMF rejection sampling, achieving simple \(O(d)\) operations. Empirically, GAC consistently matches or exceeds state-of-the-art methods across six MuJoCo benchmarks, achieving 37.6\% improvement over SAC on Ant-v4 and the best results on 4 out of 6 tasks. Our ablation studies reveal that both \textbf{spherical normalization} and \textbf{adaptive concentration control} are essential to GAC's success. These findings suggest that robust and efficient continuous control does not require complex distributions, but a principled respect for the geometry of action spaces. Code and pretrained models are available in supplementary materials.

AI.tldr: Geometric Action Control (GAC) introduces a direction-on-a-sphere action generator with a learnable concentration, reducing parameter count and computation, and achieving competitive or superior results on six MuJoCo tasks compared to SAC, with ablations highlighting spherical normalization and adaptive concentration as essential.
AI.motivation: Gaussian policies have unbounded support requiring squashing that distorts bounded action spaces. While von Mises-Fisher (vMF) offers a principled spherical alternative, its reliance on Bessel functions and rejection sampling makes it impractical. The paper argues for a geometry-aware, efficient alternative.
AI.method: GAC decomposes action generation into a direction vector on the sphere and a learnable concentration parameter. It uses spherical normalization, adaptive concentration control, and avoids vMF rejection sampling, yielding O(d) computational complexity and reducing parameter count from 2d to d+1. This setup enables interpolation between deterministic actions and uniform spherical noise.
AI.result: Empirically, GAC matches or surpasses state-of-the-art methods across six MuJoCo benchmarks, including a 37.6% improvement over SAC on Ant-v4 and best results on 4 out of 6 tasks. Ablations show spherical normalization and adaptive concentration are essential to GAC’s performance.
AI.conclusion: Robust continuous control can be achieved with geometry-aware, simpler distributions rather than complex ones; respecting action-space geometry is crucial. The work provides code and pretrained models for reproducibility.

title: ProSona: Prompt-Guided Personalization for Multi-Expert Medical Image Segmentation
comment: 5 pages, 5 figures. Submitted to IEEE International Symposium on Biomedical Imaging (ISBI) 2026
summary: Automated medical image segmentation suffers from high inter-observer variability, particularly in tasks such as lung nodule delineation, where experts often disagree. Existing approaches either collapse this variability into a consensus mask or rely on separate model branches for each annotator. We introduce ProSona, a two-stage framework that learns a continuous latent space of annotation styles, enabling controllable personalization via natural language prompts. A probabilistic U-Net backbone captures diverse expert hypotheses, while a prompt-guided projection mechanism navigates this latent space to generate personalized segmentations. A multi-level contrastive objective aligns textual and visual representations, promoting disentangled and interpretable expert styles. Across the LIDC-IDRI lung nodule and multi-institutional prostate MRI datasets, ProSona reduces the Generalized Energy Distance by 17% and improves mean Dice by more than one point compared with DPersona. These results demonstrate that natural-language prompts can provide flexible, accurate, and interpretable control over personalized medical image segmentation. Our implementation is available online 1 .

AI.tldr: ProSona learns a continuous annotation-style latent space and uses natural-language prompts to generate personalized medical image segmentations, achieving improvements over prior methods.
AI.motivation: Medical image segmentation suffers from high inter-observer variability; there is a need for flexible, interpretable personalization that can reflect different expert styles.
AI.method: A two-stage framework: a probabilistic U-Net backbone to capture diverse expert hypotheses, and a prompt-guided projection mechanism to navigate the latent style space using natural-language prompts. A multi-level contrastive objective aligns textual and visual representations to promote disentangled, interpretable expert styles.
AI.result: On the LIDC-IDRI lung nodule and multi-institutional prostate MRI datasets, ProSona reduces the Generalized Energy Distance by 17% and improves mean Dice by more than 1 percentage point compared with DPersona.
AI.conclusion: Natural-language prompts enable flexible, accurate, and interpretable control over personalized medical image segmentation; implementation is available online.

title: HipKittens: Fast and Furious AMD Kernels
summary: AMD GPUs offer state-of-the-art compute and memory bandwidth; however, peak performance AMD kernels are written in raw assembly. To address the difficulty of mapping AI algorithms to hardware, recent work proposes C++ embedded and PyTorch-inspired domain-specific languages like ThunderKittens (TK) to simplify high performance AI kernel development on NVIDIA hardware. We explore the extent to which such primitives -- for explicit tile-based programming with optimized memory accesses and fine-grained asynchronous execution across workers -- are NVIDIA-specific or general. We provide the first detailed study of the programming primitives that lead to performant AMD AI kernels, and we encapsulate these insights in the HipKittens (HK) programming framework. We find that tile-based abstractions used in prior DSLs generalize to AMD GPUs, however we need to rethink the algorithms that instantiate these abstractions for AMD. We validate the HK primitives across CDNA3 and CDNA4 AMD platforms. In evaluations, HK kernels compete with AMD's hand-optimized assembly kernels for GEMMs and attention, and consistently outperform compiler baselines. Moreover, assembly is difficult to scale to the breadth of AI workloads; reflecting this, in some settings HK outperforms all available kernel baselines by $1.2-2.4\times$ (e.g., $d=64$ attention, GQA backwards, memory-bound kernels). These findings help pave the way for a single, tile-based software layer for high-performance AI kernels that translates across GPU vendors. HipKittens is released at: https://github.com/HazyResearch/HipKittens.

AI.tldr: Tile-based programming abstractions for high-performance AI kernels generalize from NVIDIA to AMD GPUs, enabling a cross-vendor HipKittens (HK) framework that outperforms compiler baselines and matches or surpasses hand-tuned assembly in many workloads.
AI.motivation: To bridge the gap between AI workloads and hardware-specific optimizations, and to avoid vendor-specific tailoring by delivering a portable, tile-based kernel abstraction that works across GPUs (NVIDIA and AMD).
AI.method: Study existing DSL primitives (e.g., ThunderKittens) for NVIDIA, adapt and implement hipKittens for AMD (CDNA3/CDNA4), validate tile-based memory access and asynchronous execution, compare HK against AMD hand-tuned assembly and compiler baselines on GEMMs, attention, and memory-bound kernels.
AI.result: Tile-based abstractions generalize to AMD; HK requires some algorithmic rethinking for AMD; HK kernels compete with hand-optimized assembly and outperform compiler baselines; in some workloads HK outperforms all kernel baselines by 1.2–2.4× (e.g., 64-d attention, GQA backwards, memory-bound). HK demonstrates potential for a cross-vendor a tile-based AI kernel stack.
AI.conclusion: A single, tile-based software layer can translate AI kernels across GPU vendors, reducing reliance on architecture-specific assembly; HipKittens provides a concrete path toward cross-vendor high-performance AI kernels and is released for community use.

title: Towards Outcome-Oriented, Task-Agnostic Evaluation of AI Agents
summary: As AI agents proliferate across industries and applications, evaluating their performance based solely on infrastructural metrics such as latency, time-to-first-token, or token throughput is proving insufficient. These metrics fail to capture the quality of an agent's decisions, its operational autonomy, or its ultimate business value. This white paper proposes a novel, comprehensive framework of eleven outcome-based, task-agnostic performance metrics for AI agents that transcend domain boundaries. These metrics are designed to enable organizations to evaluate agents based on the quality of their decisions, their degree of autonomy, their adaptability to new challenges, and the tangible business value they deliver, regardless of the underlying model architecture or specific use case. We introduce metrics such as Goal Completion Rate (GCR), Autonomy Index (AIx), Multi-Step Task Resilience (MTR), and Business Impact Efficiency (BIE). Through a large-scale simulated experiment involving four distinct agent architectures (ReAct, Chain-of-Thought, Tool-Augmented, Hybrid) across five diverse domains (Healthcare, Finance, Marketing, Legal, and Customer Service), we demonstrate the framework's efficacy. Our results reveal significant performance trade-offs between different agent designs, highlighting the Hybrid Agent as the most consistently high-performing model across the majority of our proposed metrics, achieving an average Goal Completion Rate of 88.8\% and the highest Return on Investment (ROI). This work provides a robust, standardized methodology for the holistic evaluation of AI agents, paving the way for more effective development, deployment, and governance.

AI.tldr: Proposes 11 outcome-based, task-agnostic performance metrics for AI agents to evaluate decision quality, autonomy, adaptability, and business value across domains, demonstrated via a large-scale simulated study where Hybrid agents excel on most metrics and ROI.
AI.motivation: Current metrics focus on infrastructural aspects (latency, throughput) and fail to capture the value agents deliver. A domain- and architecture-agnostic framework is needed to assess decision quality, autonomy, and business impact for governance and deployment.
AI.method: Develop 11 metrics (e.g., Goal Completion Rate, Autonomy Index, Multi-Step Task Resilience, Business Impact Efficiency). Validate via large-scale simulations using four agent architectures (ReAct, Chain-of-Thought, Tool-Augmented, Hybrid) across five domains (Healthcare, Finance, Marketing, Legal, Customer Service). Compare architectures, analyze trade-offs, and demonstrate a standardized evaluation methodology.
AI.result: Hybrid Agent emerged as the most consistently high-performing across the majority of metrics, with an average Goal Completion Rate of 88.8% and the highest ROI. The study reveals meaningful performance trade-offs among architectures and supports the proposed framework’s ability to capture holistic agent value.
AI.conclusion: A robust, standardized, domain- and architecture-agnostic framework for evaluating AI agents holistically, facilitating better development, deployment, and governance across industries.

title: Generalized-Scale Object Counting with Gradual Query Aggregation
summary: Few-shot detection-based counters estimate the number of instances in the image specified only by a few test-time exemplars. A common approach to localize objects across multiple sizes is to merge backbone features of different resolutions. Furthermore, to enable small object detection in densely populated regions, the input image is commonly upsampled and tiling is applied to cope with the increased computational and memory requirements. Because of these ad-hoc solutions, existing counters struggle with images containing diverse-sized objects and densely populated regions of small objects. We propose GECO2, an end-to-end few-shot counting and detection method that explicitly addresses the object scale issues. A new dense query representation gradually aggregates exemplar-specific feature information across scales that leads to high-resolution dense queries that enable detection of large as well as small objects. GECO2 surpasses state-of-the-art few-shot counters in counting as well as detection accuracy by 10% while running 3x times faster at smaller GPU memory footprint.

AI.tldr: GECO2 is an end-to-end few-shot counting and detection method that uses a dense, multi-scale query representation to robustly detect objects across varying sizes in crowded scenes, addressing scale-related limitations of prior counters.
AI.motivation: Existing few-shot counters rely on ad-hoc scale handling (e.g., multi-resolution features, upsampling, tiling) to cope with diverse object sizes and dense small-object scenes, which hurts performance and efficiency. There is a need for a unified, end-to-end approach that explicitly models scale.
AI.method: GECO2 introduces a dense query representation that progressively aggregates exemplar-specific features across scales to form high-resolution dense queries, enabling accurate detection of both large and small objects without resorting to tiling or heavy upsampling; the model is end-to-end trainable.
AI.result: GECO2 surpasses state-of-the-art few-shot counting and detection by about 10% in accuracy and runs about 3x faster with a smaller GPU memory footprint.
AI.conclusion: The method effectively addresses object-scale challenges in few-shot counting/detection, delivering a scalable, efficient, and more accurate end-to-end solution that improves both counting and detection performance.

title: Where and What Matters: Sensitivity-Aware Task Vectors for Many-Shot Multimodal In-Context Learning
summary: Large Multimodal Models (LMMs) have shown promising in-context learning (ICL) capabilities, but scaling to many-shot settings remains difficult due to limited context length and high inference cost. To address these challenges, task-vector-based methods have been explored by inserting compact representations of many-shot in-context demonstrations into model activations. However, existing task-vector-based methods either overlook the importance of where to insert task vectors or struggle to determine suitable values for each location. To this end, we propose a novel Sensitivity-aware Task Vector insertion framework (STV) to figure out where and what to insert. Our key insight is that activation deltas across query-context pairs exhibit consistent structural patterns, providing a reliable cue for insertion. Based on the identified sensitive-aware locations, we construct a pre-clustered activation bank for each location by clustering the activation values, and then apply reinforcement learning to choose the most suitable one to insert. We evaluate STV across a range of multimodal models (e.g., Qwen-VL, Idefics-2) and tasks (e.g., VizWiz, OK-VQA), demonstrating its effectiveness and showing consistent improvements over previous task-vector-based methods with strong generalization.

AI.tldr: STV (Sensitivity-aware Task Vector) identifies where to insert compact task vectors in LMM activations and selects the best one via reinforcement learning, yielding robust few-/many-shot ICL improvements across models and tasks while reducing context burden.
AI.motivation: Current task-vector methods for in-context learning in large multimodal models often overlook the importance of insertion location and value choice, leading to suboptimal performance and higher inference costs under many-shot settings. STV aims to address both where to insert and what to insert.
AI.method: STV first detects sensitive insertion locations by analyzing activation deltas across query-context pairs. At each location, it builds a pre-clustered activation bank by clustering activation values. It then uses reinforcement learning to select the most suitable activation vector to insert at that location, enabling efficient and effective many-shot ICL.
AI.result: Experiments across multimodal models (e.g., Qwen-VL, Idefics-2) and tasks (VizWiz, OK-VQA) show STV consistently improves over prior task-vector methods and generalizes well across models and tasks.
AI.conclusion: STV provides a robust framework for locating and selecting task vectors, enabling scalable, generalizable in-context learning in large multimodal models by inserting compact representations at sensitive locations.

title: Taming Identity Consistency and Prompt Diversity in Diffusion Models via Latent Concatenation and Masked Conditional Flow Matching
summary: Subject-driven image generation aims to synthesize novel depictions of a specific subject across diverse contexts while preserving its core identity features. Achieving both strong identity consistency and high prompt diversity presents a fundamental trade-off. We propose a LoRA fine-tuned diffusion model employing a latent concatenation strategy, which jointly processes reference and target images, combined with a masked Conditional Flow Matching (CFM) objective. This approach enables robust identity preservation without architectural modifications. To facilitate large-scale training, we introduce a two-stage Distilled Data Curation Framework: the first stage leverages data restoration and VLM-based filtering to create a compact, high-quality seed dataset from diverse sources; the second stage utilizes these curated examples for parameter-efficient fine-tuning, thus scaling the generation capability across various subjects and contexts. Finally, for filtering and quality assessment, we present CHARIS, a fine-grained evaluation framework that performs attribute-level comparisons along five key axes: identity consistency, prompt adherence, region-wise color fidelity, visual quality, and transformation diversity.

AI.tldr: A LoRA-finetuned diffusion method with latent concatenation and a masked Conditional Flow Matching objective preserves subject identity while enabling diverse prompts, aided by a two-stage distilled data curation framework and CHARI S-style fine-grained evaluation across identity, prompt adherence, color fidelity, visual quality, and transformation diversity.
AI.motivation: To address the fundamental trade-off between strong identity consistency and high prompt diversity in subject-driven image generation, and to enable scalable, data-efficient training for multiple subjects and contexts.
AI.method: 1) LoRA fine-tuning of diffusion model with latent concatenation of reference and target images; 2) masked Conditional Flow Matching objective; 3) two-stage Distilled Data Curation Framework: Stage 1—data restoration and VLM-based filtering to build a compact seed dataset; Stage 2—fine-tuning with curated examples; 4) CHARIS evaluation framework for fine-grained, attribute-level assessment along five axes.
AI.result: The approach yields robust identity preservation and improved prompt adherence without changing the model architecture, and scales generation across many subjects and contexts through efficient data curation and parameter-efficient fine-tuning.
AI.conclusion: The framework effectively balances identity fidelity and prompt diversity while providing practical data curation and evaluation pipelines, enabling scalable, high-quality subject-driven generation.

title: Stuart-Landau Oscillatory Graph Neural Network
summary: Oscillatory Graph Neural Networks (OGNNs) are an emerging class of physics-inspired architectures designed to mitigate oversmoothing and vanishing gradient problems in deep GNNs. In this work, we introduce the Complex-Valued Stuart-Landau Graph Neural Network (SLGNN), a novel architecture grounded in Stuart-Landau oscillator dynamics. Stuart-Landau oscillators are canonical models of limit-cycle behavior near Hopf bifurcations, which are fundamental to synchronization theory and are widely used in e.g. neuroscience for mesoscopic brain modeling. Unlike harmonic oscillators and phase-only Kuramoto models, Stuart-Landau oscillators retain both amplitude and phase dynamics, enabling rich phenomena such as amplitude regulation and multistable synchronization. The proposed SLGNN generalizes existing phase-centric Kuramoto-based OGNNs by allowing node feature amplitudes to evolve dynamically according to Stuart-Landau dynamics, with explicit tunable hyperparameters (such as the Hopf-parameter and the coupling strength) providing additional control over the interplay between feature amplitudes and network structure. We conduct extensive experiments across node classification, graph classification, and graph regression tasks, demonstrating that SLGNN outperforms existing OGNNs and establishes a novel, expressive, and theoretically grounded framework for deep oscillatory architectures on graphs.

AI.tldr: Introduces Complex-Valued Stuart-Landau GNN (SLGNN), a physics-inspired, oscillatory graph neural network that extends OGNNs by allowing node feature amplitudes to evolve with Stuart-Landau dynamics. This yields richer amplitude–phase interactions via tunable Hopf and coupling parameters, and demonstrates superior performance across node/graph tasks compared to prior OGNNs.
AI.motivation: To mitigate oversmoothing and vanishing gradients in deep GNNs by leveraging oscillatory dynamics. Existing OGNNs based on phase-only models (e.g., Kuramoto) lack amplitude dynamics; Stuart-Landau oscillators provide both amplitude and phase evolution, enabling richer dynamics, multistability, and potential better expressivity for graph-structured data.
AI.method: Propose SLGNN, a complex-valued GNN where node features follow Stuart-Landau oscillator dynamics on the graph. Edges couple node states; learnable coupling strength and Hopf parameter regulate amplitude growth/decay and phase synchronization. Generalizes Kuramoto-based OGNNs by incorporating amplitude dynamics; trained end-to-end with backpropagation.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on node classification, graph classification, and graph regression show SLGNN outperforming existing OGNNs and establishing a more expressive, theoretically grounded oscillatory framework for deep GNNs.
AI.conclusion: SLGNN provides a novel, principled extension of oscillatory GNNs by integrating amplitude dynamics via Stuart-Landau oscillators. The approach offers improved performance and richer dynamics, suggesting promising directions for deep, physics-inspired graph models and further exploration of amplitude–phase interactions in learning tasks.

title: Multi-Agent GraphRAG: A Text-to-Cypher Framework for Labeled Property Graphs
summary: While Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) methods commonly draw information from unstructured documents, the emerging paradigm of GraphRAG aims to leverage structured data such as knowledge graphs. Most existing GraphRAG efforts focus on Resource Description Framework (RDF) knowledge graphs, relying on triple representations and SPARQL queries. However, the potential of Cypher and Labeled Property Graph (LPG) databases to serve as scalable and effective reasoning engines within GraphRAG pipelines remains underexplored in current research literature. To fill this gap, we propose Multi-Agent GraphRAG, a modular LLM agentic system for text-to-Cypher query generation serving as a natural language interface to LPG-based graph data. Our proof-of-concept system features an LLM-based workflow for automated Cypher queries generation and execution, using Memgraph as the graph database backend. Iterative content-aware correction and normalization, reinforced by an aggregated feedback loop, ensures both semantic and syntactic refinement of generated queries. We evaluate our system on the CypherBench graph dataset covering several general domains with diverse types of queries. In addition, we demonstrate performance of the proposed workflow on a property graph derived from the IFC (Industry Foundation Classes) data, representing a digital twin of a building. This highlights how such an approach can bridge AI with real-world applications at scale, enabling industrial digital automation use cases.

AI.tldr: Multi-Agent GraphRAG is a modular LLM-based system that translates natural language to Cypher queries for labeled property graphs, using Memgraph as the backend. It demonstrates iterative, content-aware refinement and is evaluated on CypherBench and an IFC-derived digital twin to showcase industrial-scale graph reasoning.
AI.motivation: RAG largely relies on unstructured data and RDF-based graphs; LPGs and Cypher-based graph databases remain underexplored for graph-based retrieval-augmented generation. This work targets scalable, natural-language querying of property graphs to enable AI-assisted reasoning in industrial settings (e.g., digital twins).
AI.method: An LLM-driven workflow that generates Cypher queries from natural language, executes them on Memgraph, and refines outputs via iterative content-aware correction and an aggregated feedback loop to ensure semantic and syntactic correctness.
AI.result: Demonstrates a functional proof-of-concept: effective generation and execution of Cypher queries over LPG data, with improved query quality due to iterative refinement; validated on diverse CypherBench queries and on an IFC-derived building digital twin.
AI.conclusion: LPG-based graph reasoning via a modular multi-agent GraphRAG pipeline is feasible and scalable, bridging AI with real-world industrial data; the approach opens avenues for broader adoption of graph-backed RAG in enterprise analytics and digital automation.

title: I2E: Real-Time Image-to-Event Conversion for High-Performance Spiking Neural Networks
summary: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) promise highly energy-efficient computing, but their adoption is hindered by a critical scarcity of event-stream data. This work introduces I2E, an algorithmic framework that resolves this bottleneck by converting static images into high-fidelity event streams. By simulating microsaccadic eye movements with a highly parallelized convolution, I2E achieves a conversion speed over 300x faster than prior methods, uniquely enabling on-the-fly data augmentation for SNN training. The framework's effectiveness is demonstrated on large-scale benchmarks. An SNN trained on the generated I2E-ImageNet dataset achieves a state-of-the-art accuracy of 60.50%. Critically, this work establishes a powerful sim-to-real paradigm where pre-training on synthetic I2E data and fine-tuning on the real-world CIFAR10-DVS dataset yields an unprecedented accuracy of 92.5%. This result validates that synthetic event data can serve as a high-fidelity proxy for real sensor data, bridging a long-standing gap in neuromorphic engineering. By providing a scalable solution to the data problem, I2E offers a foundational toolkit for developing high-performance neuromorphic systems. The open-source algorithm and all generated datasets are provided to accelerate research in the field.

AI.tldr: I2E converts static images into high-fidelity event streams using fast, parallelized microsaccade-inspired convolutions, enabling on-the-fly data augmentation for SNNs; it delivers large-scale performance gains and strong sim-to-real transfer, with open-source tooling.
AI.motivation: Scarcity of event-stream data for training spiking neural networks (SNNs) hampers their practical deployment. A scalable method to synthesize realistic event data from static images can accelerate SNN development and bridge the gap between synthetic and real sensor data.
AI.method: A highly parallelized convolutional pipeline that simulates microsaccade-like eye movements to convert static images into event streams (I2E). The framework enables on-the-fly data augmentation and generates large-scale synthetic datasets (I2E-ImageNet). Pre-training on synthetic I2E data and fine-tuning on real data (CIFAR10-DVS) demonstrate a strong sim-to-real transfer.
AI.result: SNN trained on I2E-ImageNet achieved 60.50% accuracy (state-of-the-art). Sim-to-real: pre-training on synthetic data and fine-tuning on CIFAR10-DVS yields 92.5% accuracy. The approach is scalable and open-source, offering datasets to accelerate neuromorphic research.
AI.conclusion: Synthetic event data, when generated with high fidelity via I2E, can serve as an effective proxy for real sensor data, enabling scalable training and strong generalization for neuromorphic systems; this establishes a sim-to-real paradigm that may transform how SNNs are trained and deployed.

title: A robust methodology for long-term sustainability evaluation of Machine Learning models
summary: Sustainability and efficiency have become essential considerations in the development and deployment of Artificial Intelligence systems, yet existing regulatory and reporting practices lack standardized, model-agnostic evaluation protocols. Current assessments often measure only short-term experimental resource usage and disproportionately emphasize batch learning settings, failing to reflect real-world, long-term AI lifecycles. In this work, we propose a comprehensive evaluation protocol for assessing the long-term sustainability of ML models, applicable to both batch and streaming learning scenarios. Through experiments on diverse classification tasks using a range of model types, we demonstrate that traditional static train-test evaluations do not reliably capture sustainability under evolving data and repeated model updates. Our results show that long-term sustainability varies significantly across models, and in many cases, higher environmental cost yields little performance benefit.

AI.tldr: Introduces a long-term, model-agnostic sustainability evaluation protocol for ML that applies to both batch and streaming learning, showing that static evaluations misestimate resource use and that higher energy cost often provides little performance benefit.
AI.motivation: Addresses regulatory and reporting gaps by providing standardized, model-agnostic metrics to assess long-term sustainability across real-world ML lifecycles, including repeated updates and evolving data.
AI.method: Develop and apply a comprehensive evaluation protocol; run experiments on diverse classification tasks with multiple model types; compare static train-test assessments with long-term, update-driven evaluations in both batch and streaming settings.
AI.result: Long-term sustainability varies across models; in many cases higher environmental cost yields little or no performance benefit, and static evaluations fail to capture enduring resource-use dynamics.
AI.conclusion: A standardized, long-term sustainability protocol is needed to guide policy and responsible AI development, applicable to both batch and streaming learning and across evolving data distributions.

title: DiagramIR: An Automatic Pipeline for Educational Math Diagram Evaluation
comment: Published at the Math-AI Workshop at NeurIPS 2025
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly being adopted as tools for learning; however, most tools remain text-only, limiting their usefulness for domains where visualizations are essential, such as mathematics. Recent work shows that LLMs are capable of generating code that compiles to educational figures, but a major bottleneck remains: scalable evaluation of these diagrams. We address this by proposing DiagramIR: an automatic and scalable evaluation pipeline for geometric figures. Our method relies on intermediate representations (IRs) of LaTeX TikZ code. We compare our pipeline to other evaluation baselines such as LLM-as-a-Judge, showing that our approach has higher agreement with human raters. This evaluation approach also enables smaller models like GPT-4.1-Mini to perform comparably to larger models such as GPT-5 at a 10x lower inference cost, which is important for deploying accessible and scalable education technologies.

AI.tldr: DiagramIR provides a scalable automatic evaluation pipeline for geometric figures generated from LLMs via LaTeX TikZ, achieving higher agreement with humans than LLM-based judgments and enabling small models to match larger models at substantially lower cost.
AI.motivation: The bottleneck in evaluating diagrammatic outputs from LLMs makes it hard to scale educational tools in math. There is a need for automatic, scalable, and cost-efficient evaluation of diagrams.
AI.method: Introduce DiagramIR that uses intermediate representations of TikZ code to evaluate geometric diagrams; compare against baselines like LLM-as-a-Judge; demonstrate that smaller models can achieve comparable performance with much lower inference cost.
AI.result: Higher agreement with human raters than LLM-as-a-Judge; small models (GPT-4.1-Mini) can match larger models (GPT-5) at ~10x lower cost.
AI.conclusion: DiagramIR enables scalable, human-aligned evaluation of LLM-generated diagrams, reducing inference costs and broadening accessibility of education technologies in symbols-heavy domains.

title: Radar-APLANC: Unsupervised Radar-based Heartbeat Sensing via Augmented Pseudo-Label and Noise Contrast
summary: Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) radars can measure subtle chest wall oscillations to enable non-contact heartbeat sensing. However, traditional radar-based heartbeat sensing methods face performance degradation due to noise. Learning-based radar methods achieve better noise robustness but require costly labeled signals for supervised training. To overcome these limitations, we propose the first unsupervised framework for radar-based heartbeat sensing via Augmented Pseudo-Label and Noise Contrast (Radar-APLANC). We propose to use both the heartbeat range and noise range within the radar range matrix to construct the positive and negative samples, respectively, for improved noise robustness. Our Noise-Contrastive Triplet (NCT) loss only utilizes positive samples, negative samples, and pseudo-label signals generated by the traditional radar method, thereby avoiding dependence on expensive ground-truth physiological signals. We further design a pseudo-label augmentation approach featuring adaptive noise-aware label selection to improve pseudo-label signal quality. Extensive experiments on the Equipleth dataset and our collected radar dataset demonstrate that our unsupervised method achieves performance comparable to state-of-the-art supervised methods. Our code, dataset, and supplementary materials can be accessed from https://github.com/RadarHRSensing/Radar-APLANC.

AI.tldr: Unsupervised radar heartbeat sensing using Augmented Pseudo-Label and Noise Contrast (Radar-APLANC) achieves competitive performance with supervised methods by using heartbeat and noise ranges as positive/negative samples and a noise-contrastive triplet loss with pseudo-labels, plus adaptive pseudo-label augmentation.
AI.motivation: There is a need for robust radar-based heartbeat sensing without relying on costly labeled physiological signals. FMCW radars are affected by noise; supervised learning improves robustness but requires ground-truth labels. The proposed unsupervised framework aims to provide robust performance without labeled data.
AI.method: Construct positive samples from the heartbeat range and negative samples from the noise range within the radar range matrix. Use a Noise-Contrastive Triplet (NCT) loss that relies on positive samples, negative samples, and pseudo-label signals generated by a traditional radar method. Introduce a pseudo-label augmentation mechanism with adaptive noise-aware label selection to improve pseudo-label quality.
AI.result: Experiments on the Equipleth dataset and a collected radar dataset show that the unsupervised Radar-APLANC achieves performance comparable to state-of-the-art supervised methods. Code and data are available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Radar-APLANC demonstrates that unsupervised learning with augmented pseudo-labels and noise-contrastive learning can approach supervised performance in radar-based heartbeat sensing, mitigating the need for expensive ground-truth signals.

title: SafeMIL: Learning Offline Safe Imitation Policy from Non-Preferred Trajectories
summary: In this work, we study the problem of offline safe imitation learning (IL). In many real-world settings, online interactions can be risky, and accurately specifying the reward and the safety cost information at each timestep can be difficult. However, it is often feasible to collect trajectories reflecting undesirable or risky behavior, implicitly conveying the behavior the agent should avoid. We refer to these trajectories as non-preferred trajectories. Unlike standard IL, which aims to mimic demonstrations, our agent must also learn to avoid risky behavior using non-preferred trajectories. In this paper, we propose a novel approach, SafeMIL, to learn a parameterized cost that predicts if the state-action pair is risky via \textit{Multiple Instance Learning}. The learned cost is then used to avoid non-preferred behaviors, resulting in a policy that prioritizes safety. We empirically demonstrate that our approach can learn a safer policy that satisfies cost constraints without degrading the reward performance, thereby outperforming several baselines.

AI.tldr: SafeMIL learns a risk-cost model from non-preferred trajectories using Multiple Instance Learning to enable offline safe imitation learning, achieving safer policies without sacrificing reward performance.
AI.motivation: Real-world RL often has risky online interactions and difficult reward/safety specification. Non-preferred trajectories (risky behaviors to avoid) can be collected offline, providing implicit safety signals that standard imitation learning cannot exploit.
AI.method: Introduce SafeMIL, a parameterized cost function learned via Multiple Instance Learning to predict whether a state-action pair is risky. The cost is used to steer the policy away from non-preferred behaviors while maintaining task performance in an offline setting.
AI.result: Empirical results show SafeMIL yields safer policies that satisfy cost constraints without degrading reward, outperforming several baselines.
AI.conclusion: MIL-driven risk-cost learning is effective for offline safe imitation learning, enabling safe policy synthesis by leveraging non-preferred trajectories without compromising reward.

title: Smarter Together: Creating Agentic Communities of Practice through Shared Experiential Learning
summary:
The transition from human-centric to agent-centric software development practices is disrupting existing knowledge sharing environments for software developers. Traditional peer-to-peer repositories and developer communities for shared technical knowledge and best practice have witnessed dramatic drops in participation in a short period of time. At the same time, agentic functional equivalents are yet to emerge leaving AI agents, which already generate a significant proportion of all new software code produced, without access to repositories of valuable shared learning.
  In this paper, we introduce Spark, a novel shared agentic memory architecture which is designed to emulate the collective intelligence and know-how of human developer communities. Spark enables AI coding agents to both contribute to and draw from a persistent and continuously evolving experiential memory. Agents operating in the same general problem space use the Spark shared memory as a repository of new knowledge to achieve collective continual learning. We evaluate Spark as a coach for AI coding agents performing software development tasks. We demonstrate that recommendations made by Spark improve the quality of code generated by generic code generation models at varying sizes and capability tiers. Boosted by Spark, a small open-weights model with 30 billion parameters was able to match the code quality afforded by a much larger state-of-the-art model. Separately, we measure the intrinsic quality of recommendations generated by Spark against a wide range of criteria inspired by software development best practice, and achieve helpfulness levels of up to 98.2% in the top two (out of five) qualitative helpfulness bands.

AI.tldr: Spark introduces a persistent shared memory for AI coding agents to enable collective continual learning, improving code quality and alignment with software development best practices; a 30B parameter model with Spark can match a larger state‑of‑the‑art model.
AI.motivation: As AI agents increasingly generate code, traditional human-centric knowledge repositories are losing participation. There is a lack of shared experiential memory for agents to learn from each other, necessitating a persistent, collaborative knowledge base to support agentic software development.
AI.method: Propose Spark, a shared agentic memory architecture where agents contribute to and query a continuously evolving experiential memory. Evaluate Spark as a coaching layer for AI coding agents, testing various code-generation models across sizes, and measuring code quality and qualitative helpfulness.
AI.result: Spark improves code quality across models; a 30B parameter model with Spark attains comparable performance to a much larger state-of-the-art model. Intrinsic recommendation quality is high, with helpfulness up to 98.2% in the top two of five bands.
AI.conclusion: Spark demonstrates the viability of a shared, continually evolving memory for AI coding agents, enabling collective learning and improved code quality while reducing dependence on extremely large models; a promising direction for agent-based software development.

title: CLIP is All You Need for Human-like Semantic Representations in Stable Diffusion
summary: Latent diffusion models such as Stable Diffusion achieve state-of-the-art results on text-to-image generation tasks. However, the extent to which these models have a semantic understanding of the images they generate is not well understood. In this work, we investigate whether the internal representations used by these models during text-to-image generation contain semantic information that is meaningful to humans. To do so, we perform probing on Stable Diffusion with simple regression layers that predict semantic attributes for objects and evaluate these predictions against human annotations. Surprisingly, we find that this success can actually be attributed to the text encoding occurring in CLIP rather than the reverse diffusion process. We demonstrate that groups of specific semantic attributes have markedly different decoding accuracy than the average, and are thus represented to different degrees. Finally, we show that attributes become more difficult to disambiguate from one another during the inverse diffusion process, further demonstrating the strongest semantic representation of object attributes in CLIP. We conclude that the separately trained CLIP vision-language model is what determines the human-like semantic representation, and that the diffusion process instead takes the role of a visual decoder.

AI.tldr: Probing Stable Diffusion reveals that human-interpretable semantics primarily come from the CLIP text encoder rather than the diffusion process, which mainly serves as a visual decoder; attribute-wise decoding varies and becomes harder under inverse diffusion.
AI.motivation: To determine whether latent diffusion models contain semantically meaningful representations and to identify whether human-like semantics arise from the diffusion process, the CLIP encoder, or their interaction.
AI.method: Train simple regression probes on Stable Diffusion representations to predict semantic attributes of objects and compare predictions against human annotations; analyze attribute-wise decoding accuracy; examine how disambiguation among attributes changes during inverse diffusion; assess the role of CLIP vs diffusion in semantic representation.
AI.result: The successful semantic decoding is largely attributable to the CLIP text encoding rather than the reverse diffusion process; groups of semantic attributes show different decoding accuracies; attributes become harder to disambiguate during inverse diffusion; CLIP holds the strongest semantic representations, with diffusion acting mainly as a visual decoder.
AI.conclusion: The human-like semantic representations are determined by the independently trained CLIP model; latent diffusion primarily serves as a visual decoder rather than encoding semantic structure itself; implications for interpretability and model design in text-to-image generation.

title: BIPPO: Budget-Aware Independent PPO for Energy-Efficient Federated Learning Services
comment: This work has been submitted to the IEEE for possible publication
summary: Federated Learning (FL) is a promising machine learning solution in large-scale IoT systems, guaranteeing load distribution and privacy. However, FL does not natively consider infrastructure efficiency, a critical concern for systems operating in resource-constrained environments. Several Reinforcement Learning (RL) based solutions offer improved client selection for FL; however, they do not consider infrastructure challenges, such as resource limitations and device churn. Furthermore, the training of RL methods is often not designed for practical application, as these approaches frequently do not consider generalizability and are not optimized for energy efficiency. To fill this gap, we propose BIPPO (Budget-aware Independent Proximal Policy Optimization), which is an energy-efficient multi-agent RL solution that improves performance. We evaluate BIPPO on two image classification tasks run in a highly budget-constrained setting, with FL clients training on non-IID data, a challenging context for vanilla FL. The improved sampler of BIPPO enables it to increase the mean accuracy compared to non-RL mechanisms, traditional PPO, and IPPO. In addition, BIPPO only consumes a negligible proportion of the budget, which stays consistent even if the number of clients increases. Overall, BIPPO delivers a performant, stable, scalable, and sustainable solution for client selection in IoT-FL.

AI.tldr: BIPPO is a budget-aware, energy-efficient multi-agent RL method for client selection in IoT-enabled Federated Learning under tight resource budgets. It achieves higher mean accuracy than non-RL baselines and standard PPO variants, while incurring negligible additional budget usage as the number of clients grows.
AI.motivation: The abstract addresses a gap where Federated Learning in resource-constrained IoT settings lacks consideration for infrastructure efficiency and energy constraints. Existing RL-based client selection methods often neglect resource limitations and device churn, and RL training often sacrifices generalizability and energy efficiency.
AI.method: Introduce BIPPO (Budget-aware Independent Proximal Policy Optimization), an energy-efficient multi-agent RL framework with a budget-aware sampler for client selection in IoT-FL. It evaluates BIPPO on two image classification tasks with non-IID data under stringent budgets, comparing against non-RL mechanisms, traditional PPO, and IPPO.
AI.result: BIPPO increases mean accuracy relative to baselines while consuming a negligible portion of the budget, with budget usage remaining stable as the number of clients grows. The approach is described as performant, stable, scalable, and sustainable.
AI.conclusion: BIPPO provides a practical, scalable solution for client selection in resource-constrained IoT-FL, delivering improved accuracy and energy efficiency without significantly increasing budget consumption, even as the IoT scale grows.

title: JobSphere: An AI-Powered Multilingual Career Copilot for Government Employment Platforms
summary: Users of government employment websites commonly face engagement and accessibility challenges linked to navigational complexity, a dearth of language options, and a lack of personalized support. This paper introduces JobSphere, an AI-powered career assistant that is redefining the employment platform in Punjab called PGRKAM. JobSphere employs Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) architecture, and it is multilingual, available in English, Hindi and Punjabi. JobSphere technique uses 4-bit quantization, allowing the platform to deploy on consumer-grade GPUs (i.e., NVIDIA RTX 3050 4GB), making the implementation 89% cheaper than that of cloud-based systems. Key innovations include voice-enabled interaction with the assistant, automated mock tests, resume parsing with skills recognition, and embed-based job recommendation that achieves a precision@10 score of 68%. An evaluation of JobSphere's implementation reveals 94% factual accuracy, a median response time of 1.8 seconds, and a System Usability Scale score of 78.5/100, a 50% improvement compared to the baseline PGRKAM platform context. In conclusion, JobSphere effectively fills significant accessibility gaps for Punjab/Hindi-speaking users in rural locations, while also affirming the users access to trusted job content provided by government agencies.

AI.tldr: JobSphere is an AI-powered multilingual RAG-based career assistant for Punjab’s PGRKAM, deployed on consumer GPUs via 4-bit quantization; adds voice, mock tests, resume parsing, and embed-based job recommendations, achieving high factual accuracy and usability while lowering costs.
AI.motivation: Address engagement, accessibility, and personalization gaps on government employment websites, especially for rural Hindi/Punjabi speakers, by reducing navigational complexity and platform costs.
AI.method: Develop an RAG pipeline with multilingual support (English/Hindi/Punjabi), 4-bit quantization for GPU deployment (NVIDIA RTX 3050 4GB), voice-enabled interaction, automated mock tests, resume parsing with skills recognition, and embedding-based job recommendations; evaluate with factual accuracy, response time, and System Usability Scale (SUS).
AI.result: Factual accuracy: 94%; median response time: 1.8 seconds; SUS: 78.5/100 (50% improvement over baseline PGRKAM); embed-based recommendation precision@10: 68%; 89% cost reduction versus cloud-based systems.
AI.conclusion: JobSphere reduces accessibility barriers for Punjab/Hindi-speaking users in rural areas and provides trusted government job content, improving reach and user experience.

title: Beyond the Pixels: VLM-based Evaluation of Identity Preservation in Reference-Guided Synthesis
summary: Evaluating identity preservation in generative models remains a critical yet unresolved challenge. Existing metrics rely on global embeddings or coarse VLM prompting, failing to capture fine-grained identity changes and providing limited diagnostic insight. We introduce Beyond the Pixels, a hierarchical evaluation framework that decomposes identity assessment into feature-level transformations. Our approach guides VLMs through structured reasoning by (1) hierarchically decomposing subjects into (type, style) -> attribute -> feature decision tree, and (2) prompting for concrete transformations rather than abstract similarity scores. This decomposition grounds VLM analysis in verifiable visual evidence, reducing hallucinations and improving consistency. We validate our framework across four state-of-the-art generative models, demonstrating strong alignment with human judgments in measuring identity consistency. Additionally, we introduce a new benchmark specifically designed to stress-test generative models. It comprises 1,078 image-prompt pairs spanning diverse subject types, including underrepresented categories such as anthropomorphic and animated characters, and captures an average of six to seven transformation axes per prompt.

AI.tldr: Beyond the Pixels presents a hierarchical, transformation-based evaluation framework for identity preservation in generative models, using structured VLM reasoning and a new 1,078-pair benchmark; achieves alignment with human judgments and reduces hallucinations.
AI.motivation: Current metrics rely on global embeddings or coarse prompting, failing to detect fine-grained identity changes; there is a need for diagnostic, verifiable evaluation grounded in verifiable visual evidence.
AI.method: Hierarchical decomposition of subjects into (type, style) -> attribute -> feature decision tree; prompting VLMs to perform concrete transformations rather than abstract similarity scores; guided by visual evidence to reduce hallucinations; evaluated across four state-of-the-art generative models.
AI.result: Strong alignment with human judgments on identity consistency; introduces a new benchmark with 1,078 image-prompt pairs across diverse subjects (including anthropomorphic and animated characters); each prompt spans about six to seven transformation axes.
AI.conclusion: Reduces hallucinations, improves consistency, and provides verifiable diagnostic insights; the benchmark serves to stress-test generative models for identity preservation.

title: Deep (Predictive) Discounted Counterfactual Regret Minimization
comment: Accepted to 40th AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI 2026)
summary: Counterfactual regret minimization (CFR) is a family of algorithms for effectively solving imperfect-information games. To enhance CFR's applicability in large games, researchers use neural networks to approximate its behavior. However, existing methods are mainly based on vanilla CFR and struggle to effectively integrate more advanced CFR variants. In this work, we propose an efficient model-free neural CFR algorithm, overcoming the limitations of existing methods in approximating advanced CFR variants. At each iteration, it collects variance-reduced sampled advantages based on a value network, fits cumulative advantages by bootstrapping, and applies discounting and clipping operations to simulate the update mechanisms of advanced CFR variants. Experimental results show that, compared with model-free neural algorithms, it exhibits faster convergence in typical imperfect-information games and demonstrates stronger adversarial performance in a large poker game.

AI.tldr: A model-free neural CFR variant that uses a value network to estimate variance-reduced advantages, bootstraps cumulative advantages, and applies discounting/clipping to mimic advanced CFR updates, achieving faster convergence and stronger adversarial performance in poker.
AI.motivation: To enable neural CFR to capture and leverage advanced CFR variants in large imperfect-information games, overcoming limitations of vanilla CFR-based neural methods.
AI.method: At each iteration: collect variance-reduced sampled advantages based on a value network; fit cumulative advantages by bootstrapping; apply discounting and clipping to simulate updates of advanced CFR variants, forming an efficient model-free neural CFR algorithm.
AI.result: Faster convergence than model-free neural baselines in typical imperfect-information games; stronger adversarial performance in a large poker game.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach effectively approximates advanced CFR variants in a model-free neural setting, improving convergence and competitiveness in adversarial poker.

title: AI-Powered Data Visualization Platform: An Intelligent Web Application for Automated Dataset Analysis
summary: An AI-powered data visualization platform that automates the entire data analysis process, from uploading a dataset to generating an interactive visualization. Advanced machine learning algorithms are employed to clean and preprocess the data, analyse its features, and automatically select appropriate visualizations. The system establishes the process of automating AI-based analysis and visualization from the context of data-driven environments, and eliminates the challenge of time-consuming manual data analysis. The combination of a Python Flask backend to access the dataset, paired with a React frontend, provides a robust platform that automatically interacts with Firebase Cloud Storage for numerous data processing and data analysis solutions and real-time sources. Key contributions include automatic and intelligent data cleaning, with imputation for missing values, and detection of outliers, via analysis of the data set. AI solutions to intelligently select features, using four different algorithms, and intelligent title generation and visualization are determined by the attributes of the dataset. These contributions were evaluated using two separate datasets to assess the platform's performance. In the process evaluation, the initial analysis was performed in real-time on datasets as large as 100000 rows, while the cloud-based demand platform scales to meet requests from multiple users and processes them simultaneously. In conclusion, the cloud-based data visualization application allowed for a significant reduction of manual inputs to the data analysis process while maintaining a high quality, impactful visual outputs, and user experiences

AI.tldr: A cloud-based AI-assisted data visualization platform automates end-to-end data analysis—from cleaning to visualization—enabling real-time processing on large datasets with reduced manual effort.
AI.motivation: To reduce the time and effort of manual data analysis in data-driven environments by providing automated data cleaning, feature selection, and visualization generation, enabling rapid, scalable insights.
AI.method: A Python Flask backend with a React frontend, integrated with Firebase Cloud Storage to access datasets. The platform performs automatic data cleaning (including imputation and outlier detection), applies four algorithms for intelligent feature selection, and generates titles and visualizations automatically. It supports real-time processing and cloud-based scaling for multiple users, with evaluation on two datasets.
AI.result: Real-time analysis on datasets up to 100,000 rows and cloud scalability for multiple concurrent users. Notable reduction in manual inputs and delivery of high-quality, interactive visual outputs and user experiences.
AI.conclusion: The cloud-based data visualization platform demonstrates end-to-end automation of data analysis and visualization, achieving high-quality outputs with reduced manual effort and scalable performance in data-driven environments.

title: StableMorph: High-Quality Face Morph Generation with Stable Diffusion
summary: Face morphing attacks threaten the integrity of biometric identity systems by enabling multiple individuals to share a single identity. To develop and evaluate effective morphing attack detection (MAD) systems, we need access to high-quality, realistic morphed images that reflect the challenges posed in real-world scenarios. However, existing morph generation methods often produce images that are blurry, riddled with artifacts, or poorly constructed making them easy to detect and not representative of the most dangerous attacks. In this work, we introduce StableMorph, a novel approach that generates highly realistic, artifact-free morphed face images using modern diffusion-based image synthesis. Unlike prior methods, StableMorph produces full-head images with sharp details, avoids common visual flaws, and offers unmatched control over visual attributes. Through extensive evaluation, we show that StableMorph images not only rival or exceed the quality of genuine face images but also maintain a strong ability to fool face recognition systems posing a greater challenge to existing MAD solutions and setting a new standard for morph quality in research and operational testing. StableMorph improves the evaluation of biometric security by creating more realistic and effective attacks and supports the development of more robust detection systems.

AI.tldr: StableMorph uses diffusion-based synthesis to produce high-quality, artifact-free full-head morphed faces, enabling more realistic and dangerous morphing attacks for evaluating MADs and biometric security.
AI.motivation: Existing morphs are often blurry or artifact-ridden, failing to capture the challenges of real-world morphing attacks. Realistic, controllable morphed images are needed to evaluate and strengthen MAD systems and biometric security.
AI.method: A diffusion-based image synthesis approach that generates full-head morphed faces with sharp details, reducing artifacts and offering fine control over visual attributes (pose, expression, lighting, identity blending) for realistic MAD data.
AI.result: StableMorph images rival or exceed the quality of genuine face images and retain a strong ability to fool face recognition systems, presenting a tougher benchmark for MAD solutions and raising the standard for morph quality.
AI.conclusion: StableMorph enhances biometric-security evaluation by delivering more realistic and effective morphs, facilitating the development of more robust detection and defense mechanisms.

title: Improving Long-Range Interactions in Graph Neural Simulators via Hamiltonian Dynamics
summary: Learning to simulate complex physical systems from data has emerged as a promising way to overcome the limitations of traditional numerical solvers, which often require prohibitive computational costs for high-fidelity solutions. Recent Graph Neural Simulators (GNSs) accelerate simulations by learning dynamics on graph-structured data, yet often struggle to capture long-range interactions and suffer from error accumulation under autoregressive rollouts. To address these challenges, we propose Information-preserving Graph Neural Simulators (IGNS), a graph-based neural simulator built on the principles of Hamiltonian dynamics. This structure guarantees preservation of information across the graph, while extending to port-Hamiltonian systems allows the model to capture a broader class of dynamics, including non-conservative effects. IGNS further incorporates a warmup phase to initialize global context, geometric encoding to handle irregular meshes, and a multi-step training objective to reduce rollout error. To evaluate these properties systematically, we introduce new benchmarks that target long-range dependencies and challenging external forcing scenarios. Across all tasks, IGNS consistently outperforms state-of-the-art GNSs, achieving higher accuracy and stability under challenging and complex dynamical systems.

AI.tldr: IGNS: an information-preserving, Hamiltonian-based graph neural simulator achieving higher accuracy and stability than state-of-the-art GNSs, with warmup, geometric encoding, and multi-step training; and new benchmarks for long-range and forcing scenarios.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of traditional solvers (computational cost for high-fidelity) and current GNSs (inadequate long-range interactions, error accumulation in autoregressive rollouts); need information-preserving, energy-based dynamics to handle broader dynamics including non-conservative effects.
AI.method: Propose Information-preserving Graph Neural Simulators (IGNS) built on Hamiltonian and port-Hamiltonian frameworks; incorporate warmup phase for global context, geometric encoding for irregular meshes, and a multi-step training objective; designed to preserve information across graph and capture non-conservative effects.
AI.result: IGNS consistently outperforms state-of-the-art GNSs across tasks, achieving higher accuracy and stability under challenging and complex dynamical systems; validated on new benchmarks targeting long-range dependencies and strong external forcing.
AI.conclusion: IGNS advances graph-based simulations by combining information-preserving Hamiltonian structure with broad dynamics, offering improved long-range fidelity and robustness; potential for broader application to complex physical systems.

title: SOM Directions are Better than One: Multi-Directional Refusal Suppression in Language Models
summary: Refusal refers to the functional behavior enabling safety-aligned language models to reject harmful or unethical prompts. Following the growing scientific interest in mechanistic interpretability, recent work encoded refusal behavior as a single direction in the model's latent space; e.g., computed as the difference between the centroids of harmful and harmless prompt representations. However, emerging evidence suggests that concepts in LLMs often appear to be encoded as a low-dimensional manifold embedded in the high-dimensional latent space. Motivated by these findings, we propose a novel method leveraging Self-Organizing Maps (SOMs) to extract multiple refusal directions. To this end, we first prove that SOMs generalize the prior work's difference-in-means technique. We then train SOMs on harmful prompt representations to identify multiple neurons. By subtracting the centroid of harmless representations from each neuron, we derive a set of multiple directions expressing the refusal concept. We validate our method on an extensive experimental setup, demonstrating that ablating multiple directions from models' internals outperforms not only the single-direction baseline but also specialized jailbreak algorithms, leading to an effective suppression of refusal. Finally, we conclude by analyzing the mechanistic implications of our approach.

AI.tldr: A SOM-based method discovers multiple latent directions to represent refusal in LLMs, outperforming single-direction and jailbreak baselines when ablating these directions; suggests a multi-dimensional, low-dimensional manifold for refusal and offers mechanistic insights.
AI.motivation: To move beyond a single-direction encoding of refusal and align with mechanistic interpretability findings that complex concepts in LLMs reside on low-dimensional manifolds, enabling richer modeling and control of safety-related behavior.
AI.method: Train Self-Organizing Maps on harmful prompt representations to identify multiple neurons. For each neuron, subtract the centroid of harmless representations to obtain a set of refusal directions. Show that SOMs generalize the prior difference-of-means approach. Evaluate by ablating multiple directions from the model internals and comparing against a single-direction baseline and jailbreak methods. Analyze the mechanistic implications of the findings.
AI.result: Ablating multiple refusal directions from the model outperforms both the single-direction baseline and specialized jailbreak algorithms, achieving stronger suppression of refusal while preserving other capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Refusal in LLMs appears to be encoded along a multi-directional, low-dimensional manifold rather than a single axis. The SOM-based approach provides mechanistic insight and a more robust method for controlling or suppressing harmful refusal behavior, with implications for safety research and interpretability.

title: Introducing Nylon Face Mask Attacks: A Dataset for Evaluating Generalised Face Presentation Attack Detection
comment: Accepted in Proc. of International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Computer, Data Sciences and Applications (ACDSA 2026)
summary: Face recognition systems are increasingly deployed across a wide range of applications, including smartphone authentication, access control, and border security. However, these systems remain vulnerable to presentation attacks (PAs), which can significantly compromise their reliability. In this work, we introduce a new dataset focused on a novel and realistic presentation attack instrument called Nylon Face Masks (NFMs), designed to simulate advanced 3D spoofing scenarios. NFMs are particularly concerning due to their elastic structure and photorealistic appearance, which enable them to closely mimic the victim's facial geometry when worn by an attacker. To reflect real-world smartphone-based usage conditions, we collected the dataset using an iPhone 11 Pro, capturing 3,760 bona fide samples from 100 subjects and 51,281 NFM attack samples across four distinct presentation scenarios involving both humans and mannequins. We benchmark the dataset using five state-of-the-art PAD methods to evaluate their robustness under unseen attack conditions. The results demonstrate significant performance variability across methods, highlighting the challenges posed by NFMs and underscoring the importance of developing PAD techniques that generalise effectively to emerging spoofing threats.

AI.tldr: Introduces Nylon Face Masks (NFMs) dataset for face presentation attack detection; 3,760 bona fide samples from 100 subjects and 51,281 NFM attacks across four scenarios; benchmarked with five PAD methods, revealing robustness gaps and generalization challenges.
AI.motivation: Presents a realistic and elastic 3D spoofing instrument (NFMs) that can closely mimic victims' faces, threatening the reliability of face recognition systems; existing PAD methods struggle to generalize to new attack types, especially under smartphone usage.
AI.method: Dataset collection using iPhone 11 Pro under smartphone usage conditions; four presentation scenarios with humans and mannequins; 3,760 bona fide samples; 51,281 NFM attack samples; evaluation of five state-of-the-art PAD methods on unseen attack conditions.
AI.result: Significant performance variability across PAD methods under unseen attacks; NFMs present substantial challenge; demonstrates the need for PAD approaches with better generalization.
AI.conclusion: Dataset provides a benchmark for testing PAD generalization to emerging spoofing threats; calls for development of robust, generalizable PAD techniques and possibly new defense mechanisms.

title: The Online Patch Redundancy Eliminator (OPRE): A novel approach to online agnostic continual learning using dataset compression
summary: In order to achieve Continual Learning (CL), the problem of catastrophic forgetting, one that has plagued neural networks since their inception, must be overcome. The evaluation of continual learning methods relies on splitting a known homogeneous dataset and learning the associated tasks one after the other. We argue that most CL methods introduce a priori information about the data to come and cannot be considered agnostic. We exemplify this point with the case of methods relying on pretrained feature extractors, which are still used in CL. After showing that pretrained feature extractors imply a loss of generality with respect to the data that can be learned by the model, we then discuss other kinds of a priori information introduced in other CL methods. We then present the Online Patch Redundancy Eliminator (OPRE), an online dataset compression algorithm, which, along with the training of a classifier at test time, yields performance on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 superior to a number of other state-of-the-art online continual learning methods. Additionally, OPRE requires only minimal and interpretable hypothesis on the data to come. We suggest that online dataset compression could well be necessary to achieve fully agnostic CL.

AI.tldr: The paper argues that many continual learning (CL) methods rely on a priori information (e.g., pretrained feature extractors) which harms learning generality. It introduces OPRE, an online dataset compression method that improves online continual learning on CIFAR-10/100, and suggests online compression is essential for agnostic CL.
AI.motivation: Address catastrophic forgetting in continual learning while challenging the use of predefined data biases (a priori information). Highlight that pretrained feature extractors reduce generality and that truly agnostic CL should minimize assumptions about future data.
AI.method: OPRE (Online Patch Redundancy Eliminator) is an online dataset compression algorithm. It reduces redundancy in data patches on the fly and pairs this with a classifier trained at test time. The approach relies on minimal and interpretable hypotheses about future data.
AI.result: OPRE achieves superior performance compared to several state-of-the-art online continual learning methods on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100.
AI.conclusion: Online dataset compression may be necessary to achieve fully agnostic continual learning; the work advocates reducing a priori information and exploring data-driven compression as a core component of CL.

title: FaithAct: Faithfulness Planning and Acting in MLLMs
summary: Unfaithfulness remains a persistent challenge for large language models (LLMs), which often produce plausible yet ungrounded reasoning chains that diverge from perceptual evidence or final conclusions. We distinguish between behavioral faithfulness (alignment between reasoning and output) and perceptual faithfulness (alignment between reasoning and input), and introduce FaithEval for quantifying step-level and chain-level faithfulness by evaluating whether each claimed object is visually supported by the image. Building on these insights, we propose FaithAct, a faithfulness-first planning and acting framework that enforces evidential grounding at every reasoning step. Experiments across multiple reasoning benchmarks demonstrate that FaithAct improves perceptual faithfulness by up to 26% without degrading task accuracy compared to prompt-based and tool-augmented baselines. Our analysis shows that treating faithfulness as a guiding principle not only mitigates hallucination but also leads to more stable reasoning trajectories. This work thereby establishes a unified framework for both evaluating and enforcing faithfulness in multimodal reasoning.

AI.tldr: Introduces FaithEval to quantify step- and chain-level faithfulness in multimodal reasoning and FaithAct to enforce grounding at every reasoning step, improving perceptual faithfulness without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.motivation: Unfaithful reasoning in LLMs remains a key challenge: there is a need to distinguish behavioral faithfulness (alignment of reasoning with outputs) from perceptual faithfulness (alignment of reasoning with input) and to ground reasoning in perceptual evidence.
AI.method: Define FaithEval metrics to assess whether each claimed object is visually supported by the image at both step and chain levels; propose FaithAct, a faithfulness-first planning/acting framework that enforces evidential grounding at every reasoning step; evaluate across multiple reasoning benchmarks against prompt-based and tool-augmented baselines.
AI.result: Perceptual faithfulness improved by up to 26% without degrading task accuracy; higher stability in reasoning trajectories; evidence that faithfulness-guided reasoning reduces hallucinations; establishes a unified evaluation/enforcement framework for multimodal faithfulness.
AI.conclusion: FaithEval and FaithAct together offer a unified approach to evaluating and enforcing faithfulness in multimodal reasoning, showing that grounding reasoning in perceptual evidence improves reliability without sacrificing performance.

title: LatentPrintFormer: A Hybrid CNN-Transformer with Spatial Attention for Latent Fingerprint identification
summary: Latent fingerprint identification remains a challenging task due to low image quality, background noise, and partial impressions. In this work, we propose a novel identification approach called LatentPrintFormer. The proposed model integrates a CNN backbone (EfficientNet-B0) and a Transformer backbone (Swin Tiny) to extract both local and global features from latent fingerprints. A spatial attention module is employed to emphasize high-quality ridge regions while suppressing background noise. The extracted features are fused and projected into a unified 512-dimensional embedding, and matching is performed using cosine similarity in a closed-set identification setting. Extensive experiments on two publicly available datasets demonstrate that LatentPrintFormer consistently outperforms three state-of-the-art latent fingerprint recognition techniques, achieving higher identification rates across Rank-10.

AI.tldr: LatentPrintFormer combines EfficientNet-B0 and Swin Tiny to extract local and global fingerprint features, uses a spatial attention module, fuses into a 512-d embedding, and uses cosine similarity for closed-set matching, outperforming three SOTA methods on two public datasets across Rank-10.
AI.motivation: Latent fingerprints are challenging due to poor quality, background noise, and partial impressions. A model that leverages both local ridge details and global structure, and that produces a compact discriminative embedding, is needed for reliable identification.
AI.method: A dual-branch architecture with CNN (EfficientNet-B0) and Transformer (Swin Tiny) backbones to capture local and global features, respectively. A spatial attention module emphasizes high-quality ridge regions while suppressing background. Features are fused and projected to a 512-dimensional embedding, with matching performed via cosine similarity in a closed-set identification setting. Evaluations on two public datasets show the method's effectiveness.
AI.result: LatentPrintFormer consistently outperforms three state-of-the-art latent fingerprint recognition techniques, achieving higher Rank-10 identification rates on both public datasets.
AI.conclusion: Integrating CNN and Transformer representations with spatial attention yields superior latent fingerprint identification performance, establishing a strong baseline and highlighting the benefit of combining local and global features for latent fingerprint recognition.

title: Towards Non-Stationary Time Series Forecasting with Temporal Stabilization and Frequency Differencing
summary: Time series forecasting is critical for decision-making across dynamic domains such as energy, finance, transportation, and cloud computing. However, real-world time series often exhibit non-stationarity, including temporal distribution shifts and spectral variability, which pose significant challenges for long-term time series forecasting. In this paper, we propose DTAF, a dual-branch framework that addresses non-stationarity in both the temporal and frequency domains. For the temporal domain, the Temporal Stabilizing Fusion (TFS) module employs a non-stationary mix of experts (MOE) filter to disentangle and suppress temporal non-stationary patterns while preserving long-term dependencies. For the frequency domain, the Frequency Wave Modeling (FWM) module applies frequency differencing to dynamically highlight components with significant spectral shifts. By fusing the complementary outputs of TFS and FWM, DTAF generates robust forecasts that adapt to both temporal and frequency domain non-stationarity. Extensive experiments on real-world benchmarks demonstrate that DTAF outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, yielding significant improvements in forecasting accuracy under non-stationary conditions. All codes are available at https://github.com/PandaJunk/DTAF.
