In a pilot study with four pathologists annotating 600 mitotic figure image patches, we compared SWAN against a traditional folder-sorting workflow. SWAN enabled rapid annotations with pairwise percent agreement ranging from 86.52% to 93.68% (Cohen's Kappa = 0.61-0.80), while for the folder-based method, the pairwise percent agreement ranged from 86.98% to 91.32% (Cohen's Kappa = 0.63-0.75) for the task of classifying atypical versus normal mitotic figures, demonstrating high consistency between annotators and comparable performance. Participants rated the tool as highly usable and appreciated the ability to annotate on mobile devices. These results suggest that SWAN can accelerate image annotation while maintaining annotation quality, offering a scalable and user-friendly alternative to conventional workflows.

AI.tldr: SWAN is an open-source, swipe-based annotation tool for histopathology patches. In a pilot with four pathologists classifying 600 mitotic figure patches, it achieved annotation consistency comparable to a folder-based workflow and was rated highly usable, indicating faster and scalable annotation.
AI.motivation: Large-scale histopathology datasets require scalable, efficient annotation methods; folder-based workflows are slow and fatiguing, hindering model development for tasks like mitotic figure classification.
AI.method: Introduce SWAN, a web application enabling patch classification via swipe gestures, supporting desktop and mobile, with real-time metadata capture and customizable gesture-to-label mapping. In a pilot study, four pathologists annotated 600 mitotic figure image patches, comparing SWAN to a traditional folder-sorting workflow, assessing pairwise agreement and Cohen's kappa.
AI.result: SWAN achieved pairwise agreement 86.52%–93.68% and Cohen's kappa 0.61–0.80; the folder-based workflow achieved 86.98%–91.32% agreement and 0.63–0.75 kappa, indicating high inter-annotator consistency and comparable performance. Participants reported high usability and appreciated mobile annotation.
AI.conclusion: SWAN can accelerate image annotation without compromising quality, offering a scalable, user-friendly alternative to conventional folder-based workflows.

title: The Path Not Taken: RLVR Provably Learns Off the Principals
comment: Preliminary version accepted as a spotlight in NeurIPS 2025 Workshop on Efficient Reasoning
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) reliably improves the reasoning performance of large language models, yet it appears to modify only a small fraction of parameters. We revisit this paradox and show that sparsity is a surface artifact of a model-conditioned optimization bias: for a fixed pretrained model, updates consistently localize to preferred parameter regions, highly consistent across runs and largely invariant to datasets and RL recipes. We mechanistically explain these dynamics with a Three-Gate Theory: Gate I (KL Anchor) imposes a KL-constrained update; Gate II (Model Geometry) steers the step off principal directions into low-curvature, spectrum-preserving subspaces; and Gate III (Precision) hides micro-updates in non-preferred regions, making the off-principal bias appear as sparsity. We then validate this theory and, for the first time, provide a parameter-level characterization of RLVR's learning dynamics: RLVR learns off principal directions in weight space, achieving gains via minimal spectral drift, reduced principal-subspace rotation, and off-principal update alignment. In contrast, SFT targets principal weights, distorts the spectrum, and even lags RLVR.
  Together, these results provide the first parameter-space account of RLVR's training dynamics, revealing clear regularities in how parameters evolve. Crucially, we show that RL operates in a distinct optimization regime from SFT, so directly adapting SFT-era parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) methods can be flawed, as evidenced by our case studies on advanced sparse fine-tuning and LoRA variants. We hope this work charts a path toward a white-box understanding of RLVR and the design of geometry-aware, RLVR-native learning algorithms, rather than repurposed SFT-era heuristics.

AI.tldr: RLVR's improvements arise from learning off-principal directions under a model-conditioned optimization bias, explained by a Three-Gate Theory; RLVR is distinct from SFT and requires geometry-aware methods.
AI.motivation: To resolve why RLVR improves reasoning with few parameter updates and to provide a parameter-space account of its dynamics, contrasting with SFT.
AI.method: Proposes a Three-Gate Theory: Gate I KL Anchor constrains updates; Gate II Model Geometry steers steps into low-curvature subspaces; Gate III Precision hides micro-updates; empirical analysis shows updates localize to certain regions and spectral drift is minimal; comparisons with SFT/SFT-based PEFT.
AI.result: Updates localize to preferred weight regions with consistency across runs/datasets; RLVR achieves gains with minimal spectral drift and off-principal updates; SFT distorts spectrum and lags RLVR; RLVR operates in a distinct optimization regime from SFT.
AI.conclusion: Provides the first parameter-space account of RLVR's training dynamics, enabling geometry-aware RLVR-native methods and cautions against direct import of SFT-era PEFT techniques.

title: MAUGIF: Mechanism-Aware Unsupervised General Image Fusion via Dual Cross-Image Autoencoders
summary: Image fusion aims to integrate structural and complementary information from multi-source images. However, existing fusion methods are often either highly task-specific, or general frameworks that apply uniform strategies across diverse tasks, ignoring their distinct fusion mechanisms. To address this issue, we propose a mechanism-aware unsupervised general image fusion (MAUGIF) method based on dual cross-image autoencoders. Initially, we introduce a classification of additive and multiplicative fusion according to the inherent mechanisms of different fusion tasks. Then, dual encoders map source images into a shared latent space, capturing common content while isolating modality-specific details. During the decoding phase, dual decoders act as feature injectors, selectively reintegrating the unique characteristics of each modality into the shared content for reconstruction. The modality-specific features are injected into the source image in the fusion process, generating the fused image that integrates information from both modalities. The architecture of decoders varies according to their fusion mechanisms, enhancing both performance and interpretability. Extensive experiments are conducted on diverse fusion tasks to validate the effectiveness and generalization ability of our method. The code is available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/MAUGIF.

AI.tldr: MAUGIF introduces a mechanism-aware unsupervised general image fusion framework using dual cross-image autoencoders to unify additive and multiplicative fusion across tasks, with mechanism-specific decoders and modality feature injection.
AI.motivation: Existing image fusion methods are either task-specific or rely on general-purpose, uniform strategies that neglect each fusion task's distinct mechanism; a general, interpretable, mechanism-aware approach is needed.
AI.method: MAUGIF classifies fusion tasks into additive and multiplicative mechanisms. Dual encoders map source images to a shared latent space to capture common content while isolating modality-specific details. Dual decoders act as feature injectors that reintegrate modality-specific characteristics into the shared content during reconstruction and fusion. The decoder architecture is adapted to the specific fusion mechanism, and fusion is performed by injecting modality-specific features into the source image in an unsupervised framework.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across diverse fusion tasks demonstrate the effectiveness and generalization of MAUGIF. The approach achieves improved performance and interpretability. Code is available at the provided URL.
AI.conclusion: MAUGIF offers a general, mechanism-aware framework for image fusion. By tailoring decoder designs to additive vs multiplicative fusion, and using dual cross-image autoencoders with modality-specific feature injection in an unsupervised setting, it improves performance and interpretability across diverse fusion tasks.

title: Automatic Grid Updates for Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks using Layer Histograms
summary: Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) are a class of neural networks that have received increased attention in recent literature. In contrast to MLPs, KANs leverage parameterized, trainable activation functions and offer several benefits including improved interpretability and higher accuracy on learning symbolic equations. However, the original KAN architecture requires adjustments to the domain discretization of the network (called the "domain grid") during training, creating extra overhead for the user in the training process. Typical KAN layers are not designed with the ability to autonomously update their domains in a data-driven manner informed by the changing output ranges of previous layers. As an added benefit, this histogram algorithm may also be applied towards detecting out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs in a variety of settings. We demonstrate that AdaptKAN exceeds or matches the performance of prior KAN architectures and MLPs on four different tasks: learning scientific equations from the Feynman dataset, image classification from frozen features, learning a control Lyapunov function, and detecting OOD inputs on the OpenOOD v1.5 benchmark.

AI.tldr: AdaptKAN is an enhanced Kolmogorov-Arnold Network that autonomously updates its domain grid via a histogram-based algorithm, reducing training overhead and enabling data-driven domain adaptation, while also enabling OOD detection. It matches or surpasses prior KANs and MLPs across four tasks.
AI.motivation: KANs offer interpretability and accuracy for learning symbolic equations but require manual, domain-specific adjustments to the domain grid during training, creating overhead. Automating domain updates and providing OOD detection would improve usability and performance.
AI.method: Introduce AdaptKAN, a KAN with a histogram-based algorithm to autonomously update the network's domain grid in a data-driven manner informed by output ranges of preceding layers. Evaluate on four tasks: (1) learning scientific equations from the Feynman dataset, (2) image classification from frozen features, (3) learning a control Lyapunov function, (4) detecting OOD inputs on the OpenOOD v1.5 benchmark. Compare performance to prior KAN architectures and MLPs.
AI.result: AdaptKAN attains performance that exceeds or matches prior KAN architectures and MLPs across all four tasks. The histogram-driven domain updates enable effective adaptation and contribute to robust OOD detection as demonstrated on the OpenOOD benchmark.
AI.conclusion: Autonomous domain-grid updates via histogram-based adaptation in KANs (AdaptKAN) reduce user overhead, preserve or improve accuracy, and provide reliable OOD detection, broadening the applicability of KANs to symbolic learning, control, and out-of-distribution scenarios.

title: SynWeather: Weather Observation Data Synthesis across Multiple Regions and Variables via a General Diffusion Transformer
summary: With the advancement of meteorological instruments, abundant data has become available. Current approaches are typically focus on single-variable, single-region tasks and primarily rely on deterministic modeling. This limits unified synthesis across variables and regions, overlooks cross-variable complementarity and often leads to over-smoothed results. To address above challenges, we introduce SynWeather, the first dataset designed for Unified Multi-region and Multi-variable Weather Observation Data Synthesis. SynWeather covers four representative regions: the Continental United States, Europe, East Asia, and Tropical Cyclone regions, as well as provides high-resolution observations of key weather variables, including Composite Radar Reflectivity, Hourly Precipitation, Visible Light, and Microwave Brightness Temperature. In addition, we introduce SynWeatherDiff, a general and probabilistic weather synthesis model built upon the Diffusion Transformer framework to address the over-smoothed problem. Experiments on the SynWeather dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our network compared with both task-specific and general models.

AI.tldr: SynWeather introduces a unified multi-region, multi-variable weather data synthesis framework: a dataset (SynWeather) and a probabilistic model (SynWeatherDiff) built on Diffusion Transformer to address over-smoothing, with experiments showing improvements over task-specific and general models.
AI.motivation: Current weather synthesis studies are typically single-variable, single-region and deterministic, limiting cross-variable complementarity and cross-region synthesis and causing over-smoothed outputs. A unified dataset and probabilistic model are needed.
AI.method: Proposes SynWeather dataset across four key regions and multiple weather variables; introduces SynWeatherDiff, a diffusion-transformer-based model for probabilistic synthesis; conducts experiments comparing to task-specific and general models.
AI.result: SynWeather and SynWeatherDiff demonstrate effective synthesis, outperforming baselines (task-specific and general models) in producing coherent multi-variable, multi-region weather observations.
AI.conclusion: A unified dataset + probabilistic diffusion-model approach enables robust, non-deterministic synthesis across regions and variables, reducing over-smoothing and enabling cross-variable complementarity.

title: SkelSplat: Robust Multi-view 3D Human Pose Estimation with Differentiable Gaussian Rendering
summary: Accurate 3D human pose estimation is fundamental for applications such as augmented reality and human-robot interaction. State-of-the-art multi-view methods learn to fuse predictions across views by training on large annotated datasets, leading to poor generalization when the test scenario differs. To overcome these limitations, we propose SkelSplat, a novel framework for multi-view 3D human pose estimation based on differentiable Gaussian rendering. Human pose is modeled as a skeleton of 3D Gaussians, one per joint, optimized via differentiable rendering to enable seamless fusion of arbitrary camera views without 3D ground-truth supervision. Since Gaussian Splatting was originally designed for dense scene reconstruction, we propose a novel one-hot encoding scheme that enables independent optimization of human joints. SkelSplat outperforms approaches that do not rely on 3D ground truth in Human3.6M and CMU, while reducing the cross-dataset error up to 47.8% compared to learning-based methods. Experiments on Human3.6M-Occ and Occlusion-Person demonstrate robustness to occlusions, without scenario-specific fine-tuning. Our project page is available here: https://skelsplat.github.io.

AI.tldr: SkelSplat introduces a differentiable Gaussian rendering framework that models each human joint as a 3D Gaussian, enabling multi-view pose estimation without 3D ground-truth and improving generalization, especially under occlusion.
AI.motivation: Current multi-view pose estimation relies on large annotated datasets and often fails to generalize to new test scenarios. There is a need for supervision-free fusion across views and robustness to occlusion.
AI.method: Model joints as 3D Gaussians (one per joint); use differentiable Gaussian rendering to fuse multi-view cues; introduce a one-hot encoding scheme to independently optimize joints; enable fusion across arbitrary cameras without requiring 3D ground-truth.
AI.result: Outperforms methods that don't use 3D ground-truth on Human3.6M and CMU; reduces cross-dataset error by up to 47.8% versus learning-based approaches; robust to occlusions across datasets (Human3.6M-Occ, Occlusion-Person) without scenario-specific fine-tuning.
AI.conclusion: SkelSplat demonstrates effective 3D pose estimation without 3D supervision, leveraging Gaussian splatting for flexible multi-view fusion and improved generalization and occlusion robustness.

title: NeuSpring: Neural Spring Fields for Reconstruction and Simulation of Deformable Objects from Videos
summary: In this paper, we aim to create physical digital twins of deformable objects under interaction. Existing methods focus more on the physical learning of current state modeling, but generalize worse to future prediction. This is because existing methods ignore the intrinsic physical properties of deformable objects, resulting in the limited physical learning in the current state modeling. To address this, we present NeuSpring, a neural spring field for the reconstruction and simulation of deformable objects from videos. Built upon spring-mass models for realistic physical simulation, our method consists of two major innovations: 1) a piecewise topology solution that efficiently models multi-region spring connection topologies using zero-order optimization, which considers the material heterogeneity of real-world objects. 2) a neural spring field that represents spring physical properties across different frames using a canonical coordinate-based neural network, which effectively leverages the spatial associativity of springs for physical learning. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that our NeuSping achieves superior reconstruction and simulation performance for current state modeling and future prediction, with Chamfer distance improved by 20% and 25%, respectively.

AI.tldr: NeuSpring introduces a neural spring field with a piecewise topology to reconstruct and simulate deformable objects from videos, achieving better current-state modeling and future prediction.
AI.motivation: Existing methods focus on modeling the current state but generalize poorly to future predictions due to ignoring intrinsic physical properties and material heterogeneity of deformable objects.
AI.method: Two key innovations: (1) a piecewise topology solution using zero-order optimization to model multi-region spring connections, capturing material heterogeneity; (2) a canonical coordinate-based neural network (neural spring field) that represents spring properties across frames by leveraging spatial associativity of springs.
AI.result: On real-world datasets, NeuSpring achieves superior reconstruction and simulation for current state modeling and future prediction, with Chamfer distance improvements of 20% and 25%, respectively.
AI.conclusion: NeuSpring effectively improves both current state modeling and future prediction for deformable objects under interaction by combining physics-inspired spring models with neural representations that capture material heterogeneity and dynamic properties.

title: Mitigating Negative Flips via Margin Preserving Training
summary: Minimizing inconsistencies across successive versions of an AI system is as crucial as reducing the overall error. In image classification, such inconsistencies manifest as negative flips, where an updated model misclassifies test samples that were previously classified correctly. This issue becomes increasingly pronounced as the number of training classes grows over time, since adding new categories reduces the margin of each class and may introduce conflicting patterns that undermine their learning process, thereby degrading performance on the original subset. To mitigate negative flips, we propose a novel approach that preserves the margins of the original model while learning an improved one. Our method encourages a larger relative margin between the previously learned and newly introduced classes by introducing an explicit margin-calibration term on the logits. However, overly constraining the logit margin for the new classes can significantly degrade their accuracy compared to a new independently trained model. To address this, we integrate a double-source focal distillation loss with the previous model and a new independently trained model, learning an appropriate decision margin from both old and new data, even under a logit margin calibration. Extensive experiments on image classification benchmarks demonstrate that our approach consistently reduces the negative flip rate with high overall accuracy.

AI.tldr: A method to minimize negative flips during class expansion by calibrating logits margins and distilling knowledge from both the old and a newly trained model, achieving lower negative flip rates without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.motivation: Negative flips escalate as more classes are added; preserving the margins of the original model while learning new ones is essential to maintain performance on the original subset.
AI.method: Introduce a margin-calibration term on logits to enlarge the relative margin between old and new classes. Use double-source focal distillation loss from both the previous model and a newly trained model to learn an appropriate decision margin under calibration.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on image classification benchmarks shows consistent reduction in negative flip rate with high overall accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Margin calibration plus double-source distillation effectively mitigates negative flips during continual learning of expanding class sets, preserving old performance while integrating new classes.

title: The Impact of Longitudinal Mammogram Alignment on Breast Cancer Risk Assessment
summary:
Regular mammography screening is crucial for early breast cancer detection. By leveraging deep learning-based risk models, screening intervals can be personalized, especially for high-risk individuals. While recent methods increasingly incorporate longitudinal information from prior mammograms, accurate spatial alignment across time points remains a key challenge. Misalignment can obscure meaningful tissue changes and degrade model performance. In this study, we provide insights into various alignment strategies, image-based registration, feature-level (representation space) alignment with and without regularization, and implicit alignment methods, for their effectiveness in longitudinal deep learning-based risk modeling. Using two large-scale mammography datasets, we assess each method across key metrics, including predictive accuracy, precision, recall, and deformation field quality.
  Our results show that image-based registration consistently outperforms the more recently favored feature-based and implicit approaches across all metrics, enabling more accurate, temporally consistent predictions and generating smooth, anatomically plausible deformation fields. Although regularizing the deformation field improves deformation quality, it reduces the risk prediction performance of feature-level alignment. Applying image-based deformation fields within the feature space yields the best risk prediction performance.
  These findings underscore the importance of image-based deformation fields for spatial alignment in longitudinal risk modeling, offering improved prediction accuracy and robustness. This approach has strong potential to enhance personalized screening and enable earlier interventions for high-risk individuals. The code is available at https://github.com/sot176/Mammogram_Alignment_Study_Risk_Prediction.git, allowing full reproducibility of the results.

AI.tldr: Image-based registration outperforms feature-level and implicit alignment for longitudinal mammography risk prediction; integrating image-based deformation fields within the feature space yields the best performance; regularization improves deformation quality but may reduce feature-based risk accuracy; code available for reproducibility.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of spatial misalignment in longitudinal deep learning-based breast cancer risk modeling and to systematically compare alignment strategies (image-based, feature-space, and implicit) on predictive performance and deformation quality.
AI.method: A comparative study using two large-scale mammography datasets evaluating multiple alignment strategies: image-based registration, feature-level alignment with and without regularization, and implicit alignment. Metrics include predictive accuracy, precision, recall, and deformation-field quality.
AI.result: Image-based registration consistently outperforms feature-level and implicit approaches across all evaluated metrics, enabling more accurate, temporally consistent predictions and smoother, anatomically plausible deformation fields. Regularizing the deformation field improves deformation quality but can hurt risk prediction in feature-level approaches; applying image-based deformation fields within the feature space yields the best risk prediction performance.
AI.conclusion: Image-based deformation fields are key for effective spatial alignment in longitudinal risk modeling, enhancing prediction accuracy and robustness and supporting more personalized screening. The work provides a reproducible pipeline, with code available at the provided GitHub repository.

title: Empowering DINO Representations for Underwater Instance Segmentation via Aligner and Prompter
summary: Underwater instance segmentation (UIS), integrating pixel-level understanding and instance-level discrimination, is a pivotal technology in marine resource exploration and ecological protection. In recent years, large-scale pretrained visual foundation models, exemplified by DINO, have advanced rapidly and demonstrated remarkable performance on complex downstream tasks. In this paper, we demonstrate that DINO can serve as an effective feature learner for UIS, and we introduce DiveSeg, a novel framework built upon two insightful components: (1) The AquaStyle Aligner, designed to embed underwater color style features into the DINO fine-tuning process, facilitating better adaptation to the underwater domain. (2) The ObjectPrior Prompter, which incorporates binary segmentation-based prompts to deliver object-level priors, provides essential guidance for instance segmentation task that requires both object- and instance-level reasoning. We conduct thorough experiments on the popular UIIS and USIS10K datasets, and the results show that DiveSeg achieves the state-of-the-art performance. Code: https://github.com/ettof/Diveseg.

AI.tldr: DiveSeg uses DINO as a feature learner for underwater instance segmentation, introducing AquaStyle Aligner for underwater color style adaptation and ObjectPrior Prompter for object-level priors, achieving state-of-the-art results on UIIS and USIS10K.
AI.motivation: Underwater imagery suffers from domain shift due to color distortion and scattering, making UIS challenging. Leveraging large pretrained models like DINO can help, but requires adaptation to underwater styles and incorporation of object-level priors to support instance-level discrimination.
AI.method: DiveSeg builds on DINO and adds two components: (1) AquaStyle Aligner to embed underwater color/style features into DINO fine-tuning, aligning representations with the underwater domain; (2) ObjectPrior Prompter that injects binary segmentation-based prompts to supply object-level priors, guiding both object- and instance-level reasoning for UIS.
AI.result: Experimental evaluation on UIIS and USIS10K shows that DiveSeg achieves state-of-the-art performance in underwater instance segmentation.
AI.conclusion: DiveSeg demonstrates that coupling style-aware fine-tuning of a large pretrained model with object-prior prompts yields strong UIS performance, validating the utility of AquaStyle Aligner and ObjectPrior Prompter; code is available at the provided repository.

title: Towards Open-Set Myoelectric Gesture Recognition via Dual-Perspective Inconsistency Learning
summary: Surface electromyography (sEMG)-based gesture recognition plays a critical role in human-machine interaction (HMI), particularly for rehabilitation and prosthetic control. However, sEMG-based systems often suffer from the scarcity of informative training data, leading to overfitting and poor generalization in deep learning models. Data augmentation offers a promising approach to increasing the size and diversity of training data, where faithfulness and diversity are two critical factors to effectiveness. However, promoting untargeted diversity can result in redundant samples with limited utility. To address these challenges, we propose a novel diffusion-based data augmentation approach, Sparse-Aware Semantic-Guided Diffusion Augmentation (SASG-DA). To enhance generation faithfulness, we introduce the Semantic Representation Guidance (SRG) mechanism by leveraging fine-grained, task-aware semantic representations as generation conditions. To enable flexible and diverse sample generation, we propose a Gaussian Modeling Semantic Modeling (GMSS) strategy, which models the semantic representation distribution and allows stochastic sampling to produce both faithful and diverse samples. To enhance targeted diversity, we further introduce a Sparse-Aware Semantic Sampling strategy to explicitly explore underrepresented regions, improving distribution coverage and sample utility. Extensive experiments on benchmark sEMG datasets, Ninapro DB2, DB4, and DB7, demonstrate that SASG-DA significantly outperforms existing augmentation methods. Overall, our proposed data augmentation approach effectively mitigates overfitting and improves recognition performance and generalization by offering both faithful and diverse samples.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based data augmentation method (SASG-DA) improves sEMG gesture recognition by generating faithful and diverse samples via semantic-guided diffusion, Gaussian semantic modeling, and sparse-aware sampling, outperforming existing methods on Ninapro datasets.
AI.motivation: sEMG-based gesture recognition suffers from scarce informative training data, leading to overfitting and poor generalization; effective augmentation requires both faithfulness and diversity while avoiding redundant samples.
AI.method: Propose Sparse-Aware Semantic-Guided Diffusion Augmentation (SASG-DA). Key components: Semantic Representation Guidance (SRG) uses fine-grained, task-aware semantic representations as diffusion conditions; Gaussian Modeling Semantic Modeling (GMSS) models the distribution of semantic representations to enable stochastic sampling for faithful and diverse samples; Sparse-Aware Semantic Sampling targets underrepresented regions to improve distribution coverage and sample utility.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on Ninapro DB2, DB4, and DB7 show SASG-DA significantly outperforms existing augmentation methods, reducing overfitting and improving recognition performance and generalization by providing both faithful and diverse samples.
AI.conclusion: SASG-DA effectively mitigates overfitting and enhances sEMG gesture recognition by generating faithful and diverse samples through guided diffusion, probabilistic semantic modeling, and sparsity-aware sampling.

title: VideoChain: A Transformer-Based Framework for Multi-hop Video Question Generation
summary: Multi-hop Question Generation (QG) effectively evaluates reasoning but remains confined to text; Video Question Generation (VideoQG) is limited to zero-hop questions over single segments. To address this, we introduce VideoChain, a novel Multi-hop Video Question Generation (MVQG) framework designed to generate questions that require reasoning across multiple, temporally separated video segments. VideoChain features a modular architecture built on a modified BART backbone enhanced with video embeddings, capturing textual and visual dependencies. Using the TVQA+ dataset, we automatically construct the large-scale MVQ-60 dataset by merging zero-hop QA pairs, ensuring scalability and diversity. Evaluations show VideoChain's strong performance across standard generation metrics: ROUGE-L (0.6454), ROUGE-1 (0.6854), BLEU-1 (0.6711), BERTScore-F1 (0.7967), and semantic similarity (0.8110). These results highlight the model's ability to generate coherent, contextually grounded, and reasoning-intensive questions.

AI.tldr: VideoChain introduces a multi-hop video question generation framework that reasons across temporally separated video segments, using a BART-based model with video embeddings and a large MVQG dataset built from TVQA+. It achieves strong generation metrics, indicating coherent and grounded, reasoning-rich questions.
AI.motivation: Current QG research is limited to text or single-segment, zero-hop video QG. There is a need to enable multi-hop reasoning across temporally separated video content.
AI.method: A modular architecture built on a modified BART backbone with video embeddings to capture textual and visual dependencies. Constructs MVQ-60 by merging zero-hop QA pairs from TVQA+ to enable scalable, diverse MVQG data.
AI.result: Strong results on standard metrics: ROUGE-L 0.6454, ROUGE-1 0.6854, BLEU-1 0.6711, BERTScore-F1 0.7967, semantic similarity 0.8110, indicating coherent, grounded, and reasoning-intensive questions.
AI.conclusion: VideoChain demonstrates the feasibility and effectiveness of MVQG across multiple video segments and provides a scalable dataset (MVQ-60), highlighting the potential for reasoning-intensive video QA generation.

title: Extreme Model Compression with Structured Sparsity at Low Precision
summary: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are used in many applications, but their large size and high computational cost make them hard to run on devices with limited resources. Two widely used techniques to address this challenge are weight quantization, which lowers the precision of all weights, and structured sparsity, which removes unimportant weights while retaining the important ones at full precision. Although both are effective individually, they are typically studied in isolation due to their compounded negative impact on model accuracy when combined. In this work, we introduce SLOPE Structured Sparsity at Low Precision), a unified framework, to effectively combine structured sparsity and low-bit quantization in a principled way. We show that naively combining sparsity and quantization severely harms performance due to the compounded impact of both techniques. To address this, we propose a training-time regularization strategy that minimizes the discrepancy between full-precision weights and their sparse, quantized counterparts by promoting angular alignment rather than direct matching. On ResNet-18, SLOPE achieves $\sim20\times$ model size reduction while retaining $\sim$99% of the original accuracy. It consistently outperforms state-of-the-art quantization and structured sparsity methods across classification, detection, and segmentation tasks on models such as ResNet-18, ViT-Small, and Mask R-CNN.

AI.tldr: A unified training framework SLOPE combines structured sparsity and low-bit quantization with angular alignment regularization to compress models while preserving accuracy.
AI.motivation: Quantization and structured sparsity, when combined naively, severely degrades performance. A principled method is needed to jointly exploit both for resource-constrained deployment.
AI.method: Introduce training-time regularization that minimizes discrepancy between full-precision weights and their sparse, quantized counterparts by promoting angular alignment instead of direct weight matching; apply structured sparsity and low-precision quantization within a unified training objective.
AI.result: On ResNet-18, achieves ~20x model size reduction while retaining ~99% of accuracy; outperforms state-of-the-art methods across classification, detection, segmentation on architectures including ResNet-18, ViT-Small, and Mask R-CNN.
AI.conclusion: SLOPE offers a principled, effective means to jointly leverage sparsity and low-precision quantization for compact models with minimal accuracy loss across vision tasks.

title: Retrospective motion correction in MRI using disentangled embeddings
summary: Physiological motion can affect the diagnostic quality of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). While various retrospective motion correction methods exist, many struggle to generalize across different motion types and body regions. In particular, machine learning (ML)-based corrections are often tailored to specific applications and datasets. We hypothesize that motion artifacts, though diverse, share underlying patterns that can be disentangled and exploited. To address this, we propose a hierarchical vector-quantized (VQ) variational auto-encoder that learns a disentangled embedding of motion-to-clean image features. A codebook is deployed to capture finite collection of motion patterns at multiple resolutions, enabling coarse-to-fine correction. An auto-regressive model is trained to learn the prior distribution of motion-free images and is used at inference to guide the correction process. Unlike conventional approaches, our method does not require artifact-specific training and can generalize to unseen motion patterns. We demonstrate the approach on simulated whole-body motion artifacts and observe robust correction across varying motion severity. Our results suggest that the model effectively disentangled physical motion of the simulated motion-effective scans, therefore, improving the generalizability of the ML-based MRI motion correction. Our work of disentangling the motion features shed a light on its potential application across anatomical regions and motion types.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical vector-quantized VAE disentangles motion-related image features to enable coarse-to-fine motion correction in MRI, using a multi-resolution codebook and an autoregressive prior to generalize to unseen motion patterns without artifact-specific training, demonstrated on simulated whole-body motion artifacts.
AI.motivation: Motion artifacts reduce MRI diagnostic quality and current ML corrections struggle to generalize across motion types/body regions; a generalized, motion-disentangled representation could improve robustness.
AI.method: Train a hierarchical vector-quantized variational auto-encoder that learns a disentangled embedding of motion-to-clean image features. Use a multi-resolution, coarse-to-fine motion pattern codebook. Train an autoregressive model to learn the prior distribution of motion-free images and use it at inference to guide correction.
AI.result: Demonstrated robustness of correction across varying motion severity on simulated whole-body motion artifacts. Evidence that motion features were effectively disentangled, supporting generalization across regions/motion types.
AI.conclusion: Disentangling motion features can enhance generalizability of ML-based MRI motion correction across anatomical regions and motion types and may enable artifact-agnostic correction in broader applications.

title: A Circular Argument : Does RoPE need to be Equivariant for Vision?
summary: Rotary Positional Encodings (RoPE) have emerged as a highly effective technique for one-dimensional sequences in Natural Language Processing spurring recent progress towards generalizing RoPE to higher-dimensional data such as images and videos. The success of RoPE has been thought to be due to its positional equivariance, i.e. its status as a relative positional encoding. In this paper, we mathematically show RoPE to be one of the most general solutions for equivariant positional embedding in one-dimensional data. Moreover, we show Mixed RoPE to be the analogously general solution for M-dimensional data, if we require commutative generators -- a property necessary for RoPE's equivariance. However, we question whether strict equivariance plays a large role in RoPE's performance. We propose Spherical RoPE, a method analogous to Mixed RoPE, but assumes non-commutative generators. Empirically, we find Spherical RoPE to have the equivalent or better learning behavior compared to its equivariant analogues. This suggests that relative positional embeddings are not as important as is commonly believed, at least within computer vision. We expect this discovery to facilitate future work in positional encodings for vision that can be faster and generalize better by removing the preconception that they must be relative.

AI.tldr: RoPE is a very general equivariant positional embedding for 1D data; Mixed RoPE generalizes to M-D with commutative generators; Spherical RoPE uses non-commutative generators and matches or exceeds performance, challenging the necessity of strict equivariance and relative encodings in vision.
AI.motivation: To reassess the central role of equivariant/relative positional encodings (RoPE) in performance, generalize to higher dimensions, and explore whether strict equivariance is essential for vision tasks.
AI.method: Theoretically characterize RoPE as a general solution for 1D equivariant embeddings; extend to M-D via Mixed RoPE under commutative generators; introduce Spherical RoPE with non-commutative generators; empirically compare learning behavior across variants on vision tasks.
AI.result: RoPE is among the most general equivariant solutions in 1D; Mixed RoPE generalizes to higher dimensions with commutative generators; Spherical RoPE performs equivalently or better than equivariant counterparts; relative positional embeddings may be less critical than previously thought in computer vision.
AI.conclusion: Relinquishing the presumption that relative/commutative, strictly equivariant encodings are necessary can lead to faster, more generalizable positional embeddings for vision models.

title: Text-based Aerial-Ground Person Retrieval
summary: This work introduces Text-based Aerial-Ground Person Retrieval (TAG-PR), which aims to retrieve person images from heterogeneous aerial and ground views with textual descriptions. Unlike traditional Text-based Person Retrieval (T-PR), which focuses solely on ground-view images, TAG-PR introduces greater practical significance and presents unique challenges due to the large viewpoint discrepancy across images. To support this task, we contribute: (1) TAG-PEDES dataset, constructed from public benchmarks with automatically generated textual descriptions, enhanced by a diversified text generation paradigm to ensure robustness under view heterogeneity; and (2) TAG-CLIP, a novel retrieval framework that addresses view heterogeneity through a hierarchically-routed mixture of experts module to learn view-specific and view-agnostic features and a viewpoint decoupling strategy to decouple view-specific features for better cross-modal alignment. We evaluate the effectiveness of TAG-CLIP on both the proposed TAG-PEDES dataset and existing T-PR benchmarks. The dataset and code are available at https://github.com/Flame-Chasers/TAG-PR.

AI.tldr: TAG-PR extends text-based person retrieval to heterogeneous aerial and ground views by introducing TAG-PEDES and TAG-CLIP. It uses a hierarchically-routed mixture of experts and a viewpoint decoupling strategy to handle view disparity, with publicly available code and dataset.
AI.motivation: Current text-based person retrieval (T-PR) focuses on ground-view images, but practical applications require cross-view retrieval across aerial and ground images, which exhibit large viewpoint gaps that hinder cross-modal alignment.
AI.method: 1) TAG-PEDES dataset created from public benchmarks with automatically generated, diversified textual descriptions to tolerate view heterogeneity. 2) TAG-CLIP model employing a hierarchically-routed mixture of experts to learn view-specific and view-agnostic features, plus a viewpoint decoupling strategy to separate view-specific cues and improve cross-modal alignment.
AI.result: The authors evaluate TAG-CLIP on both the proposed TAG-PEDES dataset and existing T-PR benchmarks, demonstrating effectiveness and robustness to view heterogeneity.
AI.conclusion: TAG-PR provides a practical cross-view text-based retrieval framework for aerial-ground scenarios, and the dataset and code are released to spur further research.

title: RAPTR: Radar-based 3D Pose Estimation using Transformer
summary: Radar-based indoor 3D human pose estimation typically relied on fine-grained 3D keypoint labels, which are costly to obtain especially in complex indoor settings involving clutter, occlusions, or multiple people. In this paper, we propose \textbf{RAPTR} (RAdar Pose esTimation using tRansformer) under weak supervision, using only 3D BBox and 2D keypoint labels which are considerably easier and more scalable to collect. Our RAPTR is characterized by a two-stage pose decoder architecture with a pseudo-3D deformable attention to enhance (pose/joint) queries with multi-view radar features: a pose decoder estimates initial 3D poses with a 3D template loss designed to utilize the 3D BBox labels and mitigate depth ambiguities; and a joint decoder refines the initial poses with 2D keypoint labels and a 3D gravity loss. Evaluated on two indoor radar datasets, RAPTR outperforms existing methods, reducing joint position error by $34.3\%$ on HIBER and $76.9\%$ on MMVR. Our implementation is available at https://github.com/merlresearch/radar-pose-transformer.

AI.tldr: Weakly supervised RAPTR for radar-based indoor 3D pose estimation using 3D bbox + 2D keypoints with a two-stage transformer-based decoder; achieves significant error reductions; open-source implementation.
AI.motivation: 3D keypoint labels are expensive to collect in cluttered indoor radar scenarios; need scalable supervision leveraging easier-to-obtain 3D bbox and 2D keypoints.
AI.method: A two-stage pose decoder with pseudo-3D deformable attention over multi-view radar features. Pose stage uses a 3D template loss with 3D bbox labels to produce initial 3D poses; joint stage refines using 2D keypoints and a 3D gravity loss.
AI.result: On two indoor radar datasets (HIBER, MMVR), RAPTR reduces joint position error by 34.3% and 76.9% respectively compared to baselines; strong performance under weak supervision.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates viability of weakly supervised radar-based 3D pose estimation with improved accuracy and scalable labeling; code available at the provided GitHub repository.

title: Anatomy-VLM: A Fine-grained Vision-Language Model for Medical Interpretation
comment: Accepted to Winter Conference on Applications of Computer Vision (WACV) 2026
summary: Accurate disease interpretation from radiology remains challenging due to imaging heterogeneity. Achieving expert-level diagnostic decisions requires integration of subtle image features with clinical knowledge. Yet major vision-language models (VLMs) treat images as holistic entities and overlook fine-grained image details that are vital for disease diagnosis. Clinicians analyze images by utilizing their prior medical knowledge and identify anatomical structures as important region of interests (ROIs). Inspired from this human-centric workflow, we introduce Anatomy-VLM, a fine-grained, vision-language model that incorporates multi-scale information. First, we design a model encoder to localize key anatomical features from entire medical images. Second, these regions are enriched with structured knowledge for contextually-aware interpretation. Finally, the model encoder aligns multi-scale medical information to generate clinically-interpretable disease prediction. Anatomy-VLM achieves outstanding performance on both in- and out-of-distribution datasets. We also validate the performance of Anatomy-VLM on downstream image segmentation tasks, suggesting that its fine-grained alignment captures anatomical and pathology-related knowledge. Furthermore, the Anatomy-VLM's encoder facilitates zero-shot anatomy-wise interpretation, providing its strong expert-level clinical interpretation capabilities.

AI.tldr: Anatomy-VLM is a fine-grained, anatomy-aware vision-language model thatlocalizes key ROIs in medical images, enriches them with structured knowledge, and aligns multi-scale information to produce clinically interpretable disease predictions, achieving strong in-/out-of-distribution performance and enabling zero-shot anatomy-wise interpretation and segmentation support.
AI.motivation: Radiology diagnosis is hampered by image heterogeneity and reliance on holistic image representations. Clinicians diagnose by identifying anatomical regions of interest (ROIs) and applying prior medical knowledge. Existing vision-language models treat images as whole, missing fine-grained, anatomy-specific cues. A model that localizes anatomical features, augments them with structured knowledge, and aligns multi-scale information can bridge expert reasoning and AI output.
AI.method: 1) An encoder localizes key anatomical features from full medical images. 2) Localized regions are enriched with structured medical knowledge for context-aware interpretation. 3) The encoder aligns multi-scale medical information to generate disease predictions that are clinically interpretable. 4) The model is evaluated on in- and out-of-distribution data and for downstream segmentation tasks. 5) The encoder enables zero-shot anatomy-wise interpretation.
AI.result: Anatomy-VLM achieves outstanding performance on both in-distribution and out-of-distribution datasets. It also shows efficacy on downstream image segmentation tasks, indicating its fine-grained alignment captures anatomical and pathology-related knowledge. The encoder enables zero-shot, anatomy-aware interpretation, providing strong expert-level clinical interpretability.
AI.conclusion: Fine-grained, ROI-centric alignment with structured knowledge and multi-scale fusion yields clinically interpretable disease predictions and robust generalization, while supporting segmentation tasks and zero-shot anatomy-wise interpretation, advancing radiology-vision collaboration.

title: OmniAID: Decoupling Semantic and Artifacts for Universal AI-Generated Image Detection in the Wild
summary: A truly universal AI-Generated Image (AIGI) detector must simultaneously generalize across diverse generative models and varied semantic content. Current state-of-the-art methods learn a single, entangled forgery representation--conflating content-dependent flaws with content-agnostic artifacts--and are further constrained by outdated benchmarks. To overcome these limitations, we propose OmniAID, a novel framework centered on a decoupled Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture. The core of our method is a hybrid expert system engineered to decouple: (1) semantic flaws across distinct content domains, and (2) these content-dependent flaws from content-agnostic universal artifacts. This system employs a set of Routable Specialized Semantic Experts, each for a distinct domain (e.g., human, animal), complemented by a Fixed Universal Artifact Expert. This architecture is trained using a bespoke two-stage strategy: we first train the experts independently with domain-specific hard-sampling to ensure specialization, and subsequently train a lightweight gating network for effective input routing. By explicitly decoupling "what is generated" (content-specific flaws) from "how it is generated" (universal artifacts), OmniAID achieves robust generalization. To address outdated benchmarks and validate real-world applicability, we introduce Mirage, a new large-scale, contemporary dataset. Extensive experiments, using both traditional benchmarks and our Mirage dataset, demonstrate our model surpasses existing monolithic detectors, establishing a new, robust standard for AIGI authentication against modern, in-the-wild threats.

AI.tldr: OmniAID introduces a decoupled Mixture-of-Experts detector with semantic experts per content domain and a universal artifact expert, trained in two stages, plus a new Mirage dataset, achieving superior generalization to modern AIGI threats over monolithic detectors.
AI.motivation: There is a need for a universal, robust AIGI detector that generalizes across diverse generative models and semantic content. Current methods entangle content-dependent flaws with content-agnostic artifacts and rely on outdated benchmarks, limiting real-world effectiveness.
AI.method: A decoupled MoE architecture with Routable Specialized Semantic Experts for distinct domains (e.g., human, animal) and a Fixed Universal Artifact Expert. Training involves two stages: (1) domain-specific hard-sampling to specialize experts, and (2) a lightweight gating network to route inputs to appropriate experts. A new Mirage dataset is introduced for validation.
AI.result: Experiments show OmniAID outperforms existing monolithic detectors on traditional benchmarks and the Mirage dataset, demonstrating robust generalization to modern, in-the-wild generative threats and setting a new standard for AIGI authentication.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling content-specific flaws from universal artifacts yields better generalization. OmniAID, along with the Mirage dataset, provides a robust framework and practical evaluation for reliable AIGI authentication against contemporary threats.

title: Cross-pyramid consistency regularization for semi-supervised medical image segmentation
summary: Semi-supervised learning (SSL) enables training of powerful models with the assumption of limited, carefully labelled data and a large amount of unlabeled data to support the learning. In this paper, we propose a hybrid consistency learning approach to effectively exploit unlabeled data for semi-supervised medical image segmentation by leveraging Cross-Pyramid Consistency Regularization (CPCR) between two decoders. First, we design a hybrid Dual Branch Pyramid Network (DBPNet), consisting of an encoder and two decoders that differ slightly, each producing a pyramid of perturbed auxiliary predictions across multiple resolution scales. Second, we present a learning strategy for this network named CPCR that combines existing consistency learning and uncertainty minimization approaches on the main output predictions of decoders with our novel regularization term. More specifically, in this term, we extend the soft-labeling setting to pyramid predictions across decoders to support knowledge distillation in deep hierarchical features. Experimental results show that DBPNet with CPCR outperforms five state-of-the-art self-supervised learning methods and has comparable performance with recent ones on a public benchmark dataset.

AI.tldr: Hybrid dual-branch pyramid network (DBPNet) with Cross-Pyramid Consistency Regularization (CPCR) for semi-supervised medical image segmentation improves performance by leveraging pyramid-level consistency and knowledge distillation across two decoders.
AI.motivation: Semi-supervised medical image segmentation is hampered by limited labeled data. There is a need to more effectively exploit unlabeled data to improve segmentation accuracy and generalization.
AI.method: Propose DBPNet: an encoder with two similar but differently perturbed decoders producing pyramid predictions at multiple resolutions. Introduce CPCR: a learning strategy that combines standard consistency learning and uncertainty minimization on main outputs, extended to pyramid predictions to enable knowledge distillation across hierarchical features.
AI.result: DBPNet with CPCR outperforms five state-of-the-art self-supervised methods and is comparable to recent methods on a public benchmark dataset.
AI.conclusion: The proposed cross-pyramid consistency framework with a dual-branch pyramid network effectively leverages unlabeled data for medical image segmentation, yielding strong performance and indicating the value of pyramid-level consistency and hierarchical knowledge distillation.

title: Generalizable Blood Cell Detection via Unified Dataset and Faster R-CNN
comment: 7 pages, 7 tables, 3 figures, 2 algorithms, Submitted for review at Next-Gen Quantum and Advanced Computing: Algorithms, Security, and Beyond (NQComp-2026)
summary: This paper presents a comprehensive methodology and comparative performance analysis for the automated classification and object detection of peripheral blood cells (PBCs) in microscopic images. Addressing the critical challenge of data scarcity and heterogeneity, robust data pipeline was first developed to standardize and merge four public datasets (PBC, BCCD, Chula, Sickle Cell) into a unified resource. Then employed a state-of-the-art Faster R-CNN object detection framework, leveraging a ResNet-50-FPN backbone. Comparative training rigorously evaluated a randomly initialized baseline model (Regimen 1) against a Transfer Learning Regimen (Regimen 2), initialized with weights pre-trained on the Microsoft COCO dataset. The results demonstrate that the Transfer Learning approach achieved significantly faster convergence and superior stability, culminating in a final validation loss of 0.08666, a substantial improvement over the baseline. This validated methodology establishes a robust foundation for building high-accuracy, deployable systems for automated hematological diagnosis.

AI.tldr: Merged multi-dataset PBC images, trained Faster R-CNN with ResNet-50-FPN; transfer learning from COCO yields faster convergence and lower validation loss (0.08666) compared to a random-init baseline.
AI.motivation: Data scarcity and heterogeneity in peripheral blood cell image datasets hinder accurate, deployable detection/classification; a unified resource and robust learning framework are needed.
AI.method: Standardize and merge four public datasets (PBC, BCCD, Chula, Sickle Cell) into a single resource; train Faster R-CNN with a ResNet-50-FPN backbone; compare two regimens: Regimen 1 (random initialization) vs Regimen 2 (COCO-pretrained transfer learning); assess convergence and validation loss.
AI.result: Transfer learning (Regimen 2) achieves faster convergence and greater training stability; final validation loss 0.08666, substantially better than the baseline; supports development of high-accuracy, deployable automated hematology diagnostics.
AI.conclusion: A robust, deployable workflow for automated hematology image analysis is established; addressing data scarcity and heterogeneity via dataset unification and leveraging transfer learning yields superior performance in PBC detection/dsIC.

title: Contrastive Integrated Gradients: A Feature Attribution-Based Method for Explaining Whole Slide Image Classification
summary: Interpretability is essential in Whole Slide Image (WSI) analysis for computational pathology, where understanding model predictions helps build trust in AI-assisted diagnostics. While Integrated Gradients (IG) and related attribution methods have shown promise, applying them directly to WSIs introduces challenges due to their high-resolution nature. These methods capture model decision patterns but may overlook class-discriminative signals that are crucial for distinguishing between tumor subtypes. In this work, we introduce Contrastive Integrated Gradients (CIG), a novel attribution method that enhances interpretability by computing contrastive gradients in logit space. First, CIG highlights class-discriminative regions by comparing feature importance relative to a reference class, offering sharper differentiation between tumor and non-tumor areas. Second, CIG satisfies the axioms of integrated attribution, ensuring consistency and theoretical soundness. Third, we propose two attribution quality metrics, MIL-AIC and MIL-SIC, which measure how predictive information and model confidence evolve with access to salient regions, particularly under weak supervision. We validate CIG across three datasets spanning distinct cancer types: CAMELYON16 (breast cancer metastasis in lymph nodes), TCGA-RCC (renal cell carcinoma), and TCGA-Lung (lung cancer). Experimental results demonstrate that CIG yields more informative attributions both quantitatively, using MIL-AIC and MIL-SIC, and qualitatively, through visualizations that align closely with ground truth tumor regions, underscoring its potential for interpretable and trustworthy WSI-based diagnostics

AI.tldr: A new attribution method, Contrastive Integrated Gradients (CIG), improves interpretability of Whole Slide Images (WSIs) by producing class-discriminative, logit-space gradients. It preserves integrated attribution axioms and introduces MIL-AIC and MIL-SIC metrics for attribution quality, validated on CAMELYON16, TCGA-RCC, and TCGA-Lung datasets, showing sharper, ground-truth-aligned attributions and better interpretability for tumor subtypes.
AI.motivation: Interpretability in WSIs is crucial for trustworthy AI in computational pathology. Standard attribution methods like Integrated Gradients can miss class-discriminative signals due to the high-resolution, multi-instance nature of WSIs, limiting their usefulness for distinguishing tumor subtypes.
AI.method: Introduce Contrastive Integrated Gradients (CIG) that compute contrastive gradients in logit space to highlight class-discriminative regions by contrasting against a reference class. CIG satisfies integrated attribution axioms. Propose two attribution quality metrics, MIL-AIC and MIL-SIC, to quantify how predictive information and model confidence improve as salient regions are revealed, especially under weak supervision. Validate on three datasets: CAMELYON16, TCGA-RCC, TCGA-Lung.
AI.result: CIG yields more informative attributions than baseline methods, as demonstrated by MIL-AIC and MIL-SIC metrics and qualitative visualizations that align with ground-truth tumor regions, across three cancer types.
AI.conclusion: CIG enhances interpretability of WSI-based diagnostics by producing sharper, class-discriminative attributions and by providing quantitative metrics to assess attribution quality, supporting more trustworthy AI-assisted pathology.

title: CleverBirds: A Multiple-Choice Benchmark for Fine-grained Human Knowledge Tracing
comment: To appear at NeurIPS 2025 - Datasets and Benchmarks Track
summary: Mastering fine-grained visual recognition, essential in many expert domains, can require that specialists undergo years of dedicated training. Modeling the progression of such expertize in humans remains challenging, and accurately inferring a human learner's knowledge state is a key step toward understanding visual learning. We introduce CleverBirds, a large-scale knowledge tracing benchmark for fine-grained bird species recognition. Collected by the citizen-science platform eBird, it offers insight into how individuals acquire expertize in complex fine-grained classification. More than 40,000 participants have engaged in the quiz, answering over 17 million multiple-choice questions spanning over 10,000 bird species, with long-range learning patterns across an average of 400 questions per participant. We release this dataset to support the development and evaluation of new methods for visual knowledge tracing. We show that tracking learners' knowledge is challenging, especially across participant subgroups and question types, with different forms of contextual information offering varying degrees of predictive benefit. CleverBirds is among the largest benchmark of its kind, offering a substantially higher number of learnable concepts. With it, we hope to enable new avenues for studying the development of visual expertize over time and across individuals.

AI.tldr: CleverBirds is a large-scale knowledge-tracing benchmark for fine-grained bird recognition, using eBird quiz data from 40k participants to support evaluating visual knowledge tracing on 10k species with 17M questions.
AI.motivation: To understand and model how humans acquire fine-grained visual expertise and infer learners' knowledge states; address the lack of large-scale benchmarks for visual knowledge tracing and the challenges of tracking learning across diverse subgroups and question types.
AI.method: Assemble and release CleverBirds: a dataset from the citizen-science platform eBird containing 40k participants answering 17 million multiple-choice questions across 10k bird species, with long-range learning patterns (avg ~400 questions per participant); evaluate the predictive value of different contextual information and establish a benchmark for visual knowledge tracing.
AI.result: Show that tracking learners' knowledge is challenging, especially across participant subgroups and question types; contextual information yields varying predictive benefits; CleverBirds is among the largest benchmarks with a very large set of learnable concepts.
AI.conclusion: The dataset enables new avenues for studying the development of visual expertise over time and across individuals and provides a valuable resource for developing and evaluating methods for visual knowledge tracing.

title: SENCA-st: Integrating Spatial Transcriptomics and Histopathology with Cross Attention Shared Encoder for Region Identification in Cancer Pathology
summary: Spatial transcriptomics is an emerging field that enables the identification of functional regions based on the spatial distribution of gene expression. Integrating this functional information present in transcriptomic data with structural data from histopathology images is an active research area with applications in identifying tumor substructures associated with cancer drug resistance. Current histopathology-spatial-transcriptomic region segmentation methods suffer due to either making spatial transcriptomics prominent by using histopathology features just to assist processing spatial transcriptomics data or using vanilla contrastive learning that make histopathology images prominent due to only promoting common features losing functional information. In both extremes, the model gets either lost in the noise of spatial transcriptomics or overly smoothed, losing essential information. Thus, we propose our novel architecture SENCA-st (Shared Encoder with Neighborhood Cross Attention) that preserves the features of both modalities. More importantly, it emphasizes regions that are structurally similar in histopathology but functionally different on spatial transcriptomics using cross-attention. We demonstrate the superior performance of our model that surpasses state-of-the-art methods in detecting tumor heterogeneity and tumor micro-environment regions, a clinically crucial aspect.

AI.tldr: A novel architecture SENCA-st integrates spatial transcriptomics with histopathology to improve region segmentation by preserving information from both modalities and using neighborhood cross attention to highlight regions structurally similar in histopathology but functionally distinct in spatial transcriptomics; it outperforms state-of-the-art in identifying tumor heterogeneity and tumor micro-environment regions.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations in current histopathology–spatial-transcriptomics segmentation approaches, which either over-privilege histology at the expense of transcriptomic functional signals or rely on vanilla contrastive learning that loses functional detail, leading to noise or excessive smoothing.
AI.method: Propose SENCA-st (Shared Encoder with Neighborhood Cross Attention), a cross-modal architecture that preserves features from both histopathology images and spatial transcriptomics. It employs a shared encoder and neighborhood cross-attention to align regions that look structurally similar yet have different gene-expression profiles, thereby maintaining functional information while leveraging structural cues.
AI.result: Demonstrates superior performance over state-of-the-art methods in detecting tumor heterogeneity and tumor micro-environment regions, highlighting its clinical relevance for cancer drug resistance studies.
AI.conclusion: SENCA-st effectively integrates histopathology and spatial transcriptomics, preserving modality-specific information and using cross-attention to reveal functionally distinct but structurally similar regions, enabling more accurate tumor region segmentation and potential clinical impact.

title: Compression then Matching: An Efficient Pre-training Paradigm for Multimodal Embedding
summary: Vision-language models advance multimodal representation learning by acquiring transferable semantic embeddings, thereby substantially enhancing performance across a range of vision-language tasks, including cross-modal retrieval, clustering, and classification. An effective embedding is expected to comprehensively preserve the semantic content of the input while simultaneously emphasizing features that are discriminative for downstream tasks. Recent approaches demonstrate that VLMs can be adapted into competitive embedding models via large-scale contrastive learning, enabling the simultaneous optimization of two complementary objectives. We argue that the two aforementioned objectives can be decoupled: a comprehensive understanding of the input facilitates the embedding model in achieving superior performance in downstream tasks via contrastive learning. In this paper, we propose CoMa, a compressed pre-training phase, which serves as a warm-up stage for contrastive learning. Experiments demonstrate that with only a small amount of pre-training data, we can transform a VLM into a competitive embedding model. CoMa achieves new state-of-the-art results among VLMs of comparable size on the MMEB, realizing optimization in both efficiency and effectiveness.

AI.tldr: CoMa introduces a compressed pre-training warm-up for vision-language models that makes embedding production data-efficient and competitive, achieving state-of-the-art results among similarly sized VLMs on MMEB.
AI.motivation: Proposes decoupling the comprehensive understanding of inputs from discriminative contrastive objectives, arguing a warm-up can improve downstream embedding quality. A data-efficient pre-training phase could enhance contrastive learning performance.
AI.method: CoMa is a compressed pre-training phase that serves as a warm-up stage before standard contrastive learning for vision-language models, enabling efficient optimization with limited data.
AI.result: With only a small amount of pre-training data, a VLM can be transformed into a competitive embedding model; CoMa achieves new state-of-the-art results among VLMs of comparable size on MMEB in terms of efficiency and effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: A simple, data-efficient pre-training strategy (CoMa) can meaningfully boost embedding quality and downstream performance of vision-language models, while reducing data and compute requirements.

title: Fast Multi-Organ Fine Segmentation in CT Images with Hierarchical Sparse Sampling and Residual Transformer
summary: Multi-organ segmentation of 3D medical images is fundamental with meaningful applications in various clinical automation pipelines. Although deep learning has achieved superior performance, the time and memory consumption of segmenting the entire 3D volume voxel by voxel using neural networks can be huge. Classifiers have been developed as an alternative in cases with certain points of interest, but the trade-off between speed and accuracy remains an issue. Thus, we propose a novel fast multi-organ segmentation framework with the usage of hierarchical sparse sampling and a Residual Transformer. Compared with whole-volume analysis, the hierarchical sparse sampling strategy could successfully reduce computation time while preserving a meaningful hierarchical context utilizing multiple resolution levels. The architecture of the Residual Transformer segmentation network could extract and combine information from different levels of information in the sparse descriptor while maintaining a low computational cost. In an internal data set containing 10,253 CT images and the public dataset TotalSegmentator, the proposed method successfully improved qualitative and quantitative segmentation performance compared to the current fast organ classifier, with fast speed at the level of ~2.24 seconds on CPU hardware. The potential of achieving real-time fine organ segmentation is suggested.

AI.tldr: A fast multi-organ segmentation framework using hierarchical sparse sampling and a Residual Transformer to reduce computation on 3D CT volumes, achieving ~2.24 s CPU inference and improved accuracy over existing fast organ classifiers, suggesting potential for real-time segmentation.
AI.motivation: To overcome the high time and memory costs of full-volume 3D segmentation and the speed–accuracy trade-off seen in classifier-based approaches.
AI.method: Introduce hierarchical sparse sampling to preserve multi-resolution context with reduced computation, and employ a Residual Transformer segmentation network to fuse information from multiple levels in the sparse descriptor with low cost.
AI.result: On an internal dataset of 10,253 CT images and the public TotalSegmentator, the method improves qualitative and quantitative segmentation performance compared with current fast organ classifiers and runs at ~2.24 seconds on CPU.
AI.conclusion: The approach shows promise for real-time fine organ segmentation by balancing speed and accuracy, indicating potential for practical clinical automation.

title: UniVA: Universal Video Agent towards Open-Source Next-Generation Video Generalist
comment: Technical Report. 24 figures, 37 pages. Website: https://univa.online/
summary: While specialized AI models excel at isolated video tasks like generation or understanding, real-world applications demand complex, iterative workflows that combine these capabilities. To bridge this gap, we introduce UniVA, an open-source, omni-capable multi-agent framework for next-generation video generalists that unifies video understanding, segmentation, editing, and generation into cohesive workflows. UniVA employs a Plan-and-Act dual-agent architecture that drives a highly automated and proactive workflow: a planner agent interprets user intentions and decomposes them into structured video-processing steps, while executor agents execute these through modular, MCP-based tool servers (for analysis, generation, editing, tracking, etc.). Through a hierarchical multi-level memory (global knowledge, task context, and user-specific preferences), UniVA sustains long-horizon reasoning, contextual continuity, and inter-agent communication, enabling interactive and self-reflective video creation with full traceability. This design enables iterative and any-conditioned video workflows (e.g., text/image/video-conditioned generation $\rightarrow$ multi-round editing $\rightarrow$ object segmentation $\rightarrow$ compositional synthesis) that were previously cumbersome to achieve with single-purpose models or monolithic video-language models. We also introduce UniVA-Bench, a benchmark suite of multi-step video tasks spanning understanding, editing, segmentation, and generation, to rigorously evaluate such agentic video systems. Both UniVA and UniVA-Bench are fully open-sourced, aiming to catalyze research on interactive, agentic, and general-purpose video intelligence for the next generation of multimodal AI systems. (https://univa.online/)

AI.tldr: UniVA is an open-source, omni-capable multi-agent framework that unifies video understanding, segmentation, editing, and generation into interactive, plan-and-act workflows using a planner and executor agents, with hierarchical memory and a new UniVA-Bench benchmark.
AI.motivation: Bridges the gap between single-task video models and real-world, complex, long-horizon workflows by providing a cohesive, interactive system for video intelligence with traceability.
AI.method: Plan-and-Act dual-agent architecture: a planner interprets user intent and decomposes it into structured steps; executor agents run these steps via modular MCP-based tool servers for analysis, generation, editing, tracking, etc. Hierarchical memory (global knowledge, task context, user preferences) supports long-horizon reasoning and inter-agent communication. Includes UniVA-Bench for multi-step evaluation.
AI.result: Proposes a working, open-source framework and benchmark for agentic video systems, enabling interactive, self-reflective video creation with full traceability and support for iterative, conditioned workflows.
AI.conclusion: UniVA enables scalable, interactive, and general-purpose video intelligence through agentic workflows, aiming to catalyze research in multimodal, general-purpose video systems.

title: Large Sign Language Models: Toward 3D American Sign Language Translation
summary: We present Large Sign Language Models (LSLM), a novel framework for translating 3D American Sign Language (ASL) by leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) as the backbone, which can benefit hearing-impaired individuals' virtual communication. Unlike existing sign language recognition methods that rely on 2D video, our approach directly utilizes 3D sign language data to capture rich spatial, gestural, and depth information in 3D scenes. This enables more accurate and resilient translation, enhancing digital communication accessibility for the hearing-impaired community. Beyond the task of ASL translation, our work explores the integration of complex, embodied multimodal languages into the processing capabilities of LLMs, moving beyond purely text-based inputs to broaden their understanding of human communication. We investigate both direct translation from 3D gesture features to text and an instruction-guided setting where translations can be modulated by external prompts, offering greater flexibility. This work provides a foundational step toward inclusive, multimodal intelligent systems capable of understanding diverse forms of language.

AI.tldr: A novel framework called Large Sign Language Models (LSLM) translates 3D American Sign Language by using Large Language Models as the backbone, directly leveraging 3D gesture data for text translation and enabling instruction-guided prompts, aiming to broaden LLMs to embodied multimodal languages.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitations of 2D sign language recognition by capturing depth, spatial, and gestural information in 3D; improve accessibility for hearing-impaired users; explore integrating embodied multimodal languages into LLMs for more flexible, non-text inputs.
AI.method: Employ LLMs as the backbone to translate 3D sign language features into text, directly from 3D gesture data. Support an instruction-guided setting where translations can be modulated by external prompts, moving beyond pure text inputs to enable multimodal processing.
AI.result: The abstract claims more accurate and resilient translation and enhanced accessibility, driven by 3D data and LLM-based translation, but does not present concrete experimental metrics or results.
AI.conclusion: This work positions itself as a foundational step toward inclusive, multimodal intelligent systems that understand diverse forms of language by integrating embodied 3D sign language with LLM capabilities.

title: 3D4D: An Interactive, Editable, 4D World Model via 3D Video Generation
summary: We introduce 3D4D, an interactive 4D visualization framework that integrates WebGL with Supersplat rendering. It transforms static images and text into coherent 4D scenes through four core modules and employs a foveated rendering strategy for efficient, real-time multi-modal interaction. This framework enables adaptive, user-driven exploration of complex 4D environments. The project page and code are available at https://yunhonghe1021.github.io/NOVA/.

AI.tldr: 3D4D introduces a modular 4D visualization framework that blends WebGL and Supersplat rendering, using four modules and foveated rendering to support real-time, interactive exploration of 4D scenes derived from static images and text; project page and code are available.
