AI.motivation: Address the challenge of turning static 2D content into coherent, navigable 4D environments and enabling efficient real-time, multi-modal interaction.
AI.method: Four core modules; integration of WebGL with Supersplat rendering; foveated rendering for performance; interactive, adaptive, user-driven exploration.
AI.result: Claims support for adaptive, user-driven exploration of complex 4D environments in real time; abstract emphasizes feasibility and provides a project page and code rather than detailed empirical results.
AI.conclusion: 3D4D offers a modular framework for 4D visualization that leverages existing rendering technologies to enable interactive exploration; code and project page are provided.

title: RePose-NeRF: Robust Radiance Fields for Mesh Reconstruction under Noisy Camera Poses
comment: Several figures are included to illustrate the reconstruction and rendering quality of the proposed method, which is why the submission exceeds the 50MB file size limit. > Several figures are included to illustrate the reconstruction and rendering quality of the proposed method, which is why the submission exceeds the 50,000 KB file size limit (Now this has been resolved)
summary: Accurate 3D reconstruction from multi-view images is essential for downstream robotic tasks such as navigation, manipulation, and environment understanding. However, obtaining precise camera poses in real-world settings remains challenging, even when calibration parameters are known. This limits the practicality of existing NeRF-based methods that rely heavily on accurate extrinsic estimates. Furthermore, their implicit volumetric representations differ significantly from the widely adopted polygonal meshes, making rendering and manipulation inefficient in standard 3D software. In this work, we propose a robust framework that reconstructs high-quality, editable 3D meshes directly from multi-view images with noisy extrinsic parameters. Our approach jointly refines camera poses while learning an implicit scene representation that captures fine geometric detail and photorealistic appearance. The resulting meshes are compatible with common 3D graphics and robotics tools, enabling efficient downstream use. Experiments on standard benchmarks demonstrate that our method achieves accurate and robust 3D reconstruction under pose uncertainty, bridging the gap between neural implicit representations and practical robotic applications.

AI.tldr: A robust framework that jointly refines camera poses and learns a neural implicit scene representation to reconstruct high-quality, editable 3D meshes from multi-view images with noisy extrinsic parameters.
AI.motivation: Accurate 3D reconstruction from multi-view imagery hinges on precise extrinsic camera poses; NERF-based methods struggle when extrinsics are uncertain, and implicit representations differ from polygonal meshes used in standard 3D tools, hindering practical robotics and rendering workflows.
AI.method: Joint optimization of camera poses and an implicit/mesh-friendly scene representation that yields editable meshes compatible with common 3D graphics and robotics pipelines, while capturing fine geometric detail and photorealistic appearance under pose noise.
AI.result: Demonstrates accurate and robust 3D reconstruction under pose uncertainty on standard benchmarks, producing editable meshes that bridge neural implicit representations with practical robotic applications.
AI.conclusion: Offers a practical pathway from multi-view data with noisy extrinsics to high-quality, editable meshes, bridging the gap between neural implicit representations and real-world robotics/graphics workflows.

title: Vision Transformer Based User Equipment Positioning
comment: The results are accepted in parts at IEEE CCNC2026
summary: Recently, Deep Learning (DL) techniques have been used for User Equipment (UE) positioning. However, the key shortcomings of such models is that: i) they weigh the same attention to the entire input; ii) they are not well suited for the non-sequential data e.g., when only instantaneous Channel State Information (CSI) is available. In this context, we propose an attention-based Vision Transformer (ViT) architecture that focuses on the Angle Delay Profile (ADP) from CSI matrix. Our approach, validated on the `DeepMIMO' and `ViWi' ray-tracing datasets, achieves an Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 0.55m indoors, 13.59m outdoors in DeepMIMO, and 3.45m in ViWi's outdoor blockage scenario. The proposed scheme outperforms state-of-the-art schemes by $\sim$ 38\%. It also performs substantially better than other approaches that we have considered in terms of the distribution of error distance.

AI.tldr: An attention-based Vision Transformer (ViT) uses the Angle-Delay Profile (ADP) extracted from CSI for UE positioning, yielding sub-meter indoor RMSE and strong outdoor results, and outperforming baselines by ~38% on DeepMIMO and ViWi datasets.
AI.motivation: DL-based UE positioning often treats inputs uniformly and struggles with non-sequential, instantaneous CSI data. The Angle-Delay Profile succinctly captures propagation geometry, offering a informative representation; ViT can focus attention on informative ADP features rather than the full CSI spectrum.
AI.method: A ViT architecture is proposed that operates on the ADP derived from CSI, applying attention to ADP features to handle non-sequential data. The approach is validated on the DeepMIMO and ViWi ray-tracing datasets, using RMSE and error-distance distribution as metrics, with comparisons to state-of-the-art methods.
AI.result: RMSE: indoors 0.55 m; DeepMIMO outdoor 13.59 m; ViWi outdoor blockage 3.45 m. Reported improvement over state-of-the-art ≈ 38%, and better distribution of positioning error.
AI.conclusion: An ADP-focused ViT for UE positioning from instantaneous CSI is effective across indoor and outdoor scenarios, outperforming existing methods and offering improved error distributions, indicating robustness to non-sequential data.
